Section Title: SUMMARY
Subsection Title: Our Company
Subsubsection Text: We are a highly diversified, leading independent insurance broker based in the United Kingdom (“UK”) operating at scale across numerous segments of the non-life insurance market in the UK and internationally. We provide a full range of non-life insurance products and related services across commercial, personal and wholesale insurance. As an insurance distribution intermediary, our business primarily consists of working with insurers to design, price, and administer insurance-related products and services, and as such, we do not assume any underwriting or principal risk. From our formation in 2017 to the end of 2023, we have increased our revenue (excluding Retail) by over three times and our Adjusted EBITDA (excluding Retail) by over five times, due to consistent strong organic growth and our proven acquisition strategy. The foundations laid over the past five years have provided a platform for further growth, which has positioned us, pro forma for all material acquisitions and disposals completed or committed as of November 2, 2023, as a top 10 independent insurance broker and a top 20 insurance broker globally according to Reinsurance News. In September 2023, we announced the merger and sale of our Retail Business to Markerstudy in a transaction valuing the business at £1.2 billion. See “Summary—Recent Developments—Retail Transaction.” For the twelve months ended September 30, 2023 and excluding Retail, we generated gross written premiums (“GWP”) of £12 billion, commissions and fees of £1.2 billion, Total Pro Forma Income of £1.6 billion, organic growth of 11.6%, Total Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA of £555.8 million and Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA margin of 33%. We offer a broad range of non-life insurance products in multiple geographies, ranging from higher value and lower volume bespoke corporate insurance products placed in the London Market, to SMB business insurance policies. Each aspect of our business is highly diversified with limited concentration or dependence on any single product, channel, carrier, income producer, or supplier. We combine this diversified operating model with a highly collaborative culture across the Group to provide our clients, carriers, and employees with a high-quality product and service offering. We serve a wide range of clients that include large multinational corporations (“MNCs”), small and medium enterprises (“SMEs”), individual consumers, and other third-party brokers and managing general agents (“MGAs”). We distribute our insurance products across multiple channels, including through a network of over 120 local offices in the United Kingdom and more than 150 offices worldwide, and online. Our global network provides the basis for deep, embedded local relationships and “trusted advisor” status with clients and benefits from long-standing trusted insurer partner relationships. We also maintain regional hubs to support our businesses through shared resources and expertise. Following the signing of the Retail Transaction, we have taken steps to organize our business into two main reporting segments, which we refer to as platforms, that focus on distinct but complementary aspects of the insurance brokerage and services value chain. See “Summary—Recent Developments— _Retail Transaction.”_ 1 ----- - **_Global Property and Casualty (“Global P&C”), which is our global broking platform with strong market positions across key geographies and is comprised of two subsegments: `o` _UK Advisory, an advice-led, community-focused set of businesses with an extensive local footprint of experts across sectors and specialisms with national and international reach, through which we provide a broad array of insurance broking products and advice on insurance, risk management and employee benefits to SMEs, large corporations and individual customers from our network of local offices in the United Kingdom. UK Advisory is one of the leading community-based broking and advisory platforms in the UK by revenue, driving growth through trusted relationships and local partnerships, and also includes an independent general insurance SME broker in the UK, a health, wellbeing and protection broker, complex claims specialists and one of the most widespread and well-developed networks of independent brokers in the UK. UK Advisory accounted for 36.7% of our Total Income Pro Forma for Completed Transactions for the twelve months ended September 30, 2023. `o` _International Advisory, which consists of our non-UK broking business and includes a growing portfolio of buy-and-build companies in attractive international markets, such as Ireland, Australia, the Netherlands, Greece, Switzerland, Austria, Portugal and Brazil. International Advisory accounted for 29.4% of our Total Income Pro Forma for Completed Transactions for the twelve months ended September 30, 2023. Global P&C generated organic growth of 10.6% in the twelve months ended September 30, 2023. - **_Specialty Broking, which is the largest independent specialty broker in the London market with global distribution and significant market position in key specialty lines. Specialty Broking combines expertise in specialist underwriting with the placing of bespoke global complex risks into Lloyd’s of London and the London Market. The platform also includes our specialist risk strategy and reinsurance broker, Inver Re, an important player in this space. Specialty Broking accounted for 34.0% of our Total Income Pro Forma for Completed Transactions and organic growth of 13.2% for the twelve months ended September 30, 2023. The following chart shows a breakdown of the key brands that we operate in each of our platforms. 2 ----- (1) Based on Total Pro Forma Income

Section Title: SUMMARY
Subsection Title: Our Strengths
Subsubsection Title: Leading global independent broker positioned in resilient insurance markets
Subsubsection Text: We are a highly diversified, leading, global independent insurance broker based in the United Kingdom. Following our creation in 2017 as the result of a combination of long-established leading insurance broking brands, we have rapidly grown into a top 20 global insurance broker by revenue. _ Source: A.M. Best Top 20 Global Brokers 2023 edition ranked by 2022 total revenue, company public information_ 1) Risk & Insurance business of Marsh only. 2) Pro forma for acquisition of Tiger Risk and Marsh R.S. 3) Pro forma for all material acquisitions and disposals completed or contractually committed as of November 2, 2023, and converted to U.S. dollars at an exchange rate of £1 to $1.22. We have a depth of specialist and local knowledge built-up over many years, and entrenched client relationships and deep community penetration. We believe that our scale and diversified proposition provides us with the ability to effectively compete with even our largest competitors and service over four million clients as a result of our broad industry knowledge and depth of understanding of customer needs from our team of over 8,000 professionals across more than 150 offices globally. The scale of premium we place in the market also allows us to capture incremental earnings across the insurance value chain and reduce costs. As a leading global independent insurance broker, we are well positioned to continue to benefit from the resilient and growing global non-life insurance market. The global non-life insurance market has proven highly resilient across cycles and recessions, and has been continually growing. The global nonlife market has experienced growth of approximately 3% per annum over the past twenty years, and has demonstrated resilience through a long track record of stable GWP growth with limited impact from past economic or capital market downturns as demonstrated by the below chart. 3 ----- _Source: Swiss Re Institute_ As compared to other sectors, our sector benefits from low volatility and proved to be one of the most resilient sectors through the COVID-19 pandemic. The growth in the industry is supported by favorable market dynamics. Brokers can, in middle market segments, promote strong client relations as a result of this low volatility and foster recurring revenue. We were able to maintain organic growth of approximately 3% from 2017 through 2020, and increased organic growth (excluding Retail) of 10.2%, 12.5% and 11.6% in 2021, 2022 and the twelve months ended September 30, 2023, respectively. We are regionally diversified, earning 34% of our GWPs for the twelve months ended September 30, 2023 (excluding the Retail Transaction) in the UK, 30% in North America, 15% in Europe, 10% in the APAC region, 8% in the LATAM region and 3% in the AMEA region, and our worldwide business is positioned at the center of global insurance markets as shown on the map below. 4 ----- Our global presence covers the major global insurance hubs and provides us with global access and insight. We established Ardonagh Global Partners in 2021 to invest in strong platforms operating in attractive markets and verticals outside the UK and Europe and to partner with management teams who want to grow faster as part of a larger group while retaining operational independence. Since its inception, Ardonagh Global Partners has grown to include Resilium, one of Australia’s largest independently-owned intermediary networks and the founding business of our Australia platform, and Ethos Broking Australia, which invests in or directly acquires brokers. Ardonagh Global Partners also includes Hemsley Wynne Furlonge, a specialist M&A warranty and indemnity insurance broker and advisor, MDS Group, an insurance broker and risk management advisor across the Portuguese-speaking world and Europe, the only Portuguese Lloyd’s Broker and the largest independent broker in Brazil, and Envest, an Australian-based insurance investment and distribution group, which now houses Australian assets Resilium and Epsilon Underwriting within the Group.

Section Title: SUMMARY
Subsection Title: Our Strengths
Subsubsection Title: Scaled platform with significant diversification across geographies and capabilities
Subsubsection Text: Our business is highly diversified across products, customers, channels, geographies and carriers. We offer a wide-ranging product portfolio across both general and bespoke insurance products and services across the insurance value chain, including personal and commercial lines, wholesale distribution, underwriting and insurance outsourcing services to large corporations, insurers, third-party brokers, SMEs, and individual consumers at a variety of price points, without assuming any underwriting or principal risk in relation to any of the services or products that we provide. For the twelve months ended September 30, 2023, no single line of business accounted for more than 20% of GWP. We reach customers through diverse distribution channels, including through our digital platform, telephone contact centers, and traditional face-to-face customer contact via our network of over 150 offices globally. As a result of our international presence, our GWP is diversified by geography, with 66% of our premium (excluding the Retail Transaction) placed outside the UK (specifically, 30% of our premium is placed in North America and 15% is placed in Europe). We have long-standing partnerships with key carriers, and relationships more broadly with a wide range of insurance carriers in each of the markets that we serve. Our large number of carrier relationships mitigates potential carrier concentration risks and enables us to enhance and improve our product offerings for clients as well as pricing and our own 5 ----- commercial terms. For the twelve months ended September 30, 2023, no single carrier accounted for more than 7% of our total GWP, with the top five carriers in aggregate representing less than 25% of total GWP. Our gross written premiums by geographical region, class of business and carrier are shown in the chart below: (1) LTM premiums to September 2023; pro forma to exclude Retail and include Assepro. Our highly diversified offering ensures minimal reliance on any particular product, distribution channel, customer, or market, limiting our exposure to any adverse industry developments and macroeconomic factors and thereby mitigating volatility in our overall financial performance. In addition, the breadth of our offering provides us with various avenues through which we can identify gaps in the market and develop specialized products to capture unmet demand. We are thus able take advantage of cross-selling opportunities to increase our customer penetration and drive incremental growth.

Section Title: SUMMARY
Subsection Title: Our Strengths
Subsubsection Title: Robust, accelerating organic growth benefitting from the realization of key strategic initiatives
Subsubsection Text: We have a track record of delivering strong organic income and margin growth. By leveraging our scaled platform and best practices, we have negotiated superior terms with insurer counterparties, industry participants, and suppliers, enabling us to offer a better experience and pricing to our customers. We also value diversity and keeping up with current technologic trends, prioritizing investments in people and data and technology. As a result, we have grown the business every quarter (compared with the prior year period) since our establishment in 2017 and have achieved double-digit organic growth since 2021, growing 10.2% in 2021, 12.5% in 2022 and 11.6% (excluding Retail) in the twelve months ended September 30, 2023. Our organic growth is driven, in part, by our key strategic initiatives across our segments, as outlined below. _Global P&C: UK Advisory_ - _Drive new business: Targeting large corporate clients with focused expertise and leveraging data and single customer view to cross-sell products within Advisory and between platforms - _Enhanced placement: Reducing the number of markets from 750 to 185 to improve client outcomes and reduce costs, giving partners white label access to existing binders and specialties, which allows them the opportunity to re-brand such binders and products, and leveraging increased scale to increase commission rates paid by customers across business - _Grow our digital proposition: Enhancing our online offering to improve the customer journey and reduce costs, and entering into affinity partner deals 6 ----- - _Integration:_ Focusing on integration through significant new opportunities for value creation with rapid integration of further “add-on” accretive acquisitions _Global P&C: International Advisory_ - _Identify strategic markets: Focusing on select regions that fulfill our acquisition criteria and clearly focus on larger, more sophisticated markets with growing macroeconomic conditions and a developed regulatory environment - _Utilize networks:_ Leveraging our networks and the wider broker networks to identify suitable assets and targeting attractive off-market opportunities at below market multiples - _Realize synergies:_ Rapidly integrating acquisitions to realize significant cost and revenue synergies - _Roll-out best practices: Establishing initiatives to accelerate organic growth and improve margin and cash flow conversion, and to provide access to new products and capacity _Specialty Broking_ - _Producer hires:_ Driving existing producer hires to maturity and hiring new individuals who can add value quickly with a relentless focus on renewal retention, leveraging existing retail and wholesale relationships - _Digital solutions:_ Leveraging and overlaying external tools to attract new business and protect existing business, employing digital solutions to get us closer to our end client - _Portfolio & Placement:_ Engaging with Ardonagh Portfolio Solutions (“APS”) for select lines such as terrorism, financial institution, personal injury and cyber in order to increase commissions, and actively managing portfolio to reduce exposure to underperforming lines - _Global strategy: Maximizing inflow from growing Global P&C platform, leveraging network memberships to increase existing business and inflow and capitalizing on footprint to drive further growth Our organic growth has been further supported over the past five years by delivering value from our new producer hires. We have generated Adjusted EBITDA of approximately £30 million for the twelve months ended September 30, 2023 from 29 maturing producer teams hired since 2020. Teams typically mature to their full profitability potential approximately three years after the expiry of capacity or covenant restriction. We have seven teams hired in 2020 that were at 75% maturity as of September 30, 2023, seven teams hired in 2021 at 58% maturity as of September 30, 2023, seven teams hired in 2022 at 37% maturity as of September 30, 2023 and eight teams that started trading in the nine months ended September 30, 2023. As a result, we expect to realize additional Adjusted EBITDA as a result of these hires over the next three years.

Section Title: SUMMARY
Subsection Title: Our Strengths
Subsubsection Title: Proven ability to grow through thoughtful, highly accretive acquisitions and disciplined integration
Subsubsection Text: We have a long-term track record and well-established process for identifying, executing, and integrating highly accretive acquisitions across many geographies. We have completed or entered into acquisition agreements for more than 150 acquisitions since our establishment in 2017, which represents an enterprise value of over £3.2 billion with a year-to-date average “add-on” enterprise value multiple of 6.6 times and a “platform” enterprise value multiple of 9.6 times. We also have a further 36 acquisitions that are contractually committed or under signed letter of intent as of February 1, 2024, which would contribute an additional £32.2 million of Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA.This track record of successful acquisitions is shown in the below chart. 7 ----- 1) Reflects enterprise value of acquisitions completed in the relevant time period 2) Includes all material completed acquisitions 3) Reflects average EV / EBITDA multiple of “add-on” acquisitions from 2020 through Q3’23 4) Reflects average EV / EBITDA multiple of “platform” acquisitions from 2020 - Q3’23 We have built our Global P&C franchise by building on our UK Advisory business and carefully selected regional platforms. We have built our Specialty Broking business by investing in carefully strategic producer hires and specialisms. In the past three years, we have expanded our addressable markets through acquisitions in new synergistic geographies. In 2020, we acquired our first non-UK business, Arachas, Ireland’s largest commercial insurance broker, which kick-started our international operations. We have since established our latest standalone platform, International Advisory, under which we are consolidating our non-UK broking enterprises and related investments and under which we have launched our Ardonagh Europe and our Ardonagh Global Partners businesses. We established Ardonagh Global Partners in 2021 to invest in leading platforms operating in attractive markets and verticals outside the UK and Europe and to partner with management teams who want to grow faster as part of a larger group while retaining operational independence. Since its inception, Ardonagh Global Partners has grown to include various brands, including Resilium, one of Australia’s largest independently owned intermediary networks and the founding business of our Australian platform and Ethos Broking Australia, which invests in or directly acquires brokers. We continue to have a robust M&A pipeline, and we continue to explore larger transaction opportunities both in the UK and internationally with a strong focus on market-leading platforms in our international business. To successfully complete and integrate such a large amount of acquisitions, we follow a clear, disciplined and highly selective acquisition strategy. We encourage competition between segments in order to receive centrally controlled capital for acquisitions, and we employ a rigorous due diligence process that is implemented by our highly experienced and dedicated team of investment professionals. Given the scope of our operational footprint, we are also able to leverage deep local knowledge in our markets in order to further understand our targets. Our primary focus when reviewing potential opportunities is on the customer proposition and financial returns. We have also implemented a robust and efficient integration and post-deal tracking process after closing. 8 ----- Our disciplined execution focuses on a clear, orderly and highly selective strategy based on ten principles: strategic fit, cultural fit, integration commitment, aligned incentives, financial returns, synergy discipline, cash discipline, realistic plan, risk assessment and clear accountability. We perform a rigorous due diligence process through a highly experienced and dedicated team of investment professionals, leveraging deep local knowledge in the markets where we operate and a robust and efficient integration and post-deal tracking process. We are able to present ourselves as the acquirer of choice by emphasizing our culture, aligning interests and maintaining discipline. In addition, we have made significant investments in our technology platform, which allows us to integrate new acquisitions at low cost and with low integration risk.

Section Title: SUMMARY
Subsection Title: Our Strengths
Subsubsection Title: Leading data and analytics capabilities driving platform efficiencies
Subsubsection Text: Our leading centralized data and analytics capabilities allow us to enhance risk solutions for capacity providers and improve outcomes for our clients and to drive cost savings. These capabilities have been primarily utilized to support the building of broker facilities, which then allow us to access predominantly traditional capacity in more efficient ways for the client. For example, we have used data and analytics to significantly improve and re-package older previous products into better terms, cover and product for our clients, including improvements on the Terrorism, Fine Art Jewellery and Specie facilities. We have also used data and analytics to introduce brand new facilities to the market, such as a Construction facility and a cross-class facility named LECTIO. The following chart shows our centralized data analytics structure, where we have centralized global premium and carrier information using our data center based in Mullingar, Ireland. As an example, in our Specialty Broking platform, we have built facilities such as the Ardonagh Portfolio Solutions (“APS”) business to use data analytics and capabilities to bring benefits to both clients, in terms of wider market placement, and our Group, in terms of increased revenues. Our technology and scale facilities have also allowed us to identify cost savings totalling approximately £15.8 million that we expect to achieve within the next 12 months. In our Global P&C: UK Advisory segment, we expect cost savings of £3.2 million, primarily as a result of a target model implementation project that has reduced headcount through efficiency gains from optimizing policy administration systems, an IT transformation from improving the office network, which is aimed at removing legacy applications and outsourcing, and an onshoring finance project expected to deliver benefits from process efficiencies and automation. In our Global P&C: International Advisory segment, we expect cost savings of £3.9 million from synergies through our hub-and-spoke model and by integrating further acquisitions into our existing platforms. In our Specialty Broking segment, we expect cost savings of 9 ----- £8.2 million from a technology-led transformation of middle- and back-office functions. We have also identified cost synergies in connection with the acquisition of Corant Global, including harmonization of reward structures, footprint consolidation and back-office optimization, and the acquisition of the Oxford Insurance Group. We have also identified cost savings of £0.5 million through back-office optimization in our Corporate function.

Section Title: SUMMARY
Subsection Title: Our Strengths
Subsubsection Title: Attractive financial profile with strong growth, profitability and cash flow conversion
Subsubsection Text: Since our establishment in 2017, we have delivered a transformational improvement in our quality of earnings and have had strong performance across all metrics. We experienced a four times increase in revenue (including Retail) from 2017 to Total Pro Forma Income (excluding Retail) in the twelve months ended September 30, 2023 and a seven times increase in Adjusted EBITDA (including Retail) to Total Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA (excluding Retail) during the same period. We also experienced a more than eight percentage points increase in organic growth from 2017 to the twelve months ended September 30, 2023 (excluding Retail) and a more than 13 percentage point increase in Adjusted EBITDA margin over the same time period (excluding Retail). We have designed our business model to generate high EBITDA margins with limited working capital and maintenance capital expenditure requirements, resulting in management operating cash flow of £420 million and an operating cash conversion of 86% in the twelve months ended September 30, 2023. Since our establishment, we have delivered a transformational improvement in quality of earnings, primarily as a result of significant investments towards transformative cost-savings programs and synergy initiatives in our business to create a scalable and efficient platform that is conducive to future growth, resulting in approximately £150 million of realized cost-savings since the start of 2018. Our investments have resulted in a continued and rapid improvement in our quality of earnings as cost savings are delivered and one-time costs have decreased. We believe that our cash generative business model is highly scalable and that we will be able to leverage our well-invested infrastructure as we continue to grow organically and via acquisitions. (1) Includes reported EBITDA and the following adjustments: acquisitions and financing costs, gains on revaluation of associate and investment, profit on disposal of business, pro forma impact of completed transactions and pro forma for transactions under LOI. Total Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA also includes an adjustment for organic growth in Q4 2023. See “Summary Historical Financial _Information and Other Data—Other Consolidated and Pro Forma Data.”_ (2) Includes the following adjustments: business transformation and legacy costs, other costs and regulatory costs. 10 ----- (3) Reflects Total Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA. See “Summary Historical Financial Information and Other Data—Other _Consolidated and Pro Forma Data.”_ Our transformational improvement in quality of earnings has improved cash generation. In the twelve months ended September 30, 2023, we had management operating cash flow of £420 million and an operating cash conversion of 86% in the twelve months ended September 30, 2023. We believe that our cash generative business model is highly scalable and that we will be able to leverage our well-invested infrastructure as we continue to grow organically and via acquisitions. The continuing contribution from new producer hires already made but not yet at maturity and from enhanced and alternative capacity arrangements in place to better serve our existing customers also supports our cash generation.

Section Title: SUMMARY
Subsection Title: Our Strengths
Subsubsection Title: Deep, aligned management team well positioned to drive culture and lead ongoing growth
Subsubsection Text: Our management team is highly experienced in leading and growing successful insurance intermediary organizations. Our Chief Executive Officer, David Ross, has over 25 years of industry experience building and leading brokerage businesses including leading transformative mergers and acquisitions in the insurance intermediary field. Mr. Ross is supported by a highly experienced management team with over 25 years of industry experience on average, with a strong track record of delivering on transformative change and investment. Our Chief Financial Officer, Diane Cougill, has over 20 years of industry experience and has held senior leadership positions at RAC and at Aviva. Our senior management team also includes Aurelio Cusaro, our Chief Investment Officer, John Tiner, our Chairman, Geoff Gouriet, our General Counsel, and Sarah Dalgarno, our Chief Risk Officer. Our Global P&C senior management includes Rob Worrell, Chief Executive Officer of our UK Advisory segment, Conor Brennan, Chairman of our International Advisory segment and Des O’Connor, Chief Investment Officer of our International Advisory segment. Our Specialty Broking senior management includes Chief Executive Officer Andrew Wallin and Chairman James Masterson. Together, this team leads a deep bench of revenue-producing talent and committed operational support staff, all of whom have been specifically targeted for their entrepreneurial spirit and ability to drive sustainable revenue growth. The culture cultivated by our senior management team leads to our continued success in the insurance market and differentiates itself from other competitors in various ways, including: - An emphasis on entrepreneurship at a local level with strong organizational alignment, resulting in colleagues working together towards common, Group-wide objectives, - Continuous cross-group collaboration to amplify the best of our collective experience and insight, - The application of the depth and breadth of our specialist expertise, built through years of market leadership, - Our tailored and innovative solutions and ability to understand what works for each industry, market and client, - Our deep relationships with clients built through longstanding service, accountability and trust, and - Our regular programming to celebrate special accomplishments and promote internal events. These factors have resulted in over 90% client retention based on strong relationships, knowledge and expertise, stickiness of specialist products and high barriers to entry, and 95% average producer retention across last five years (excluding non-regrettable leavers), as a result of our ability to leverage a broader platform, our emphasis on training, development and support, our aligned incentives with producers and our collaborative and cohesive culture. Management and employees are incentivized directly or indirectly through a combination of B ordinary share ownership at Tara Topco Limited and/or participation in various broad equity and performance 11 ----- schemes, the value of which are linked to the achievement of long term, sustainable, and profitable growth. We also benefit from the support, significant investment experience and industry network in the insurance broking and underwriting market of our long-term majority shareholders, HPS Investment Partners and Madison Dearborn Partners, who in aggregate directly or indirectly own over 90% of our equity capital. HPS Investment Partners and Madison Dearborn Partners have been highly supportive of our management and have demonstrated their continued commitment to Ardonagh by investing $2.7 billion in common equity over the past years.

Section Title: SUMMARY
Subsection Title: Our Strategies
Subsubsection Title: Accelerate organic growth by optimizing placement strategy and driving new business through new products, cross-selling and up-selling
Subsubsection Text: We seek to consistently achieve double-digit organic growth across our overall business by expanding product portfolios, streamlining operations, increasing penetration of our customer base—particularly in new synergistic geographies—through concerted sales efforts across our Group and capitalizing on a targeted acquisitions pipeline. We have a growing pipeline of new specialist products that is highly complementary to our existing offerings, including high net worth, political violence, specialty terrorism facility. These products are being developed on existing systems and channels at limited upfront cost and are largely linked to new hires, who can contribute the relevant product and channel expertise. As an example, new products launched in our Specialty Broking platform contributed towards organic growth of approximately 11.6% in the twelve months ended September 30, 2023. As part of our organic growth strategy, we are also focused on cross-selling and up-selling and customer retention and expansion. We seek to improve cross-selling and up-selling across Group clients, including by leveraging data. We have rolled out of a Group-wide database in which we collate data from each of our platforms to enable a “single view of the client” (i.e., how many policies are linked to each client across personal and commercial lines) to facilitate retention, cross-selling and up-selling. This database continues to provide a more granular understanding of our clients’ needs, allowing us to offer them tailored cross-selling opportunities. We have also implemented a bespoke pricing system and leveraged our data infrastructure, fraud detection capabilities and access to third-party data sources to improve retention and increase customer lifetime value across most products. In our Specialty Broking platform, we have developed a highly sophisticated customer and broker-facing software which interfaces with several market-leading policy administrative systems and substantially improves ease of access to customer and broker data. We are also in discussions with several third-party brokers who are clients of our wholesale platform to roll-out this software in order to maximize efficiency and centralization within our platform and improve the experience of third-party brokers on our platform. We also intend to leverage our membership of the Worldwide Broker Network to increase existing business and in-flow through the establishment of new relationships and intend to capitalize on our existing global footprint to drive further growth. In the UK, our UK Advisory business launched a focused client strategy aimed at large UK corporates, which is already bearing fruit with the successful signing of several marquee clients, including a global broadcaster that has a £5 billion turnover and also the UK’s largest charity. In addition, in 2021, we launched Inver Re, a new risk strategy and reinsurance broker with ambitions to harness our scale, resources and reach to offer a credible alternative to global brokers and become our industry’s independent reinsurance broker of choice. We plan to further strengthen our reinsurance operations by (i) consolidating our existing reinsurance operations while organically building out our brand, talent and capabilities in key global hubs (such as London, North America & Bermuda), (ii) developing our first party business through leveraging key group carrier relationships, (iii) hiring industry leading talent and building further revenue streams and (iv) deploying M&A to expand geographic focus beyond key hubs (such as in Latin America and Asia). 12 -----

Section Title: SUMMARY
Subsection Title: Our Strategies
Subsubsection Title: Streamline operations through our continued focus on capacity excellence, talent excellence and operational excellence
Subsubsection Text: We are constantly re-examining our operating models to incrementally streamline lower value-add operations and further support our front-office distribution and client service capabilities. We have developed a range of strategies to streamline operations and optimize middle and back-office functions. Our strategy is based on three key pillars of excellence, which are: - _Capacity excellence. We seek to reach capacity excellence by operating a strategic capacity model through our Ardonagh Portfolio Solutions (“APS”) business, part of our Specialty Broking platform. APS utilizes data captured from across the Group’s platforms and businesses to enhance income through a centralized placement. We expect our APS business to be a key growth driver going forward by allowing us to capitalize on a select number of strategic carrier relationships, create market leading products which offer better terms for our customers and access alternative capital providers either directly or in connection with our MGA business. We intend to engage with APS for select high-profitability lines and actively manage the portfolio to reduce exposure to underperforming lines. - _Talent excellence. We believe that we will be able to deliver significant incremental income and EBITDA growth by nurturing talent excellence. We are working to attract the best people in our industry and are ideally placed to capitalize on market dislocation. We believe that incoming hires bring capabilities and are highly accretive. We have a strong track record of income hires and producer recruitment, delivering significant incremental income and EBITDA. We intend to leverage our success to date to continue selective transformational hires, focusing on hiring exceptional individuals who can swiftly add value to our Group. Since 2019, we have secured at least five new specialist team hires per year, and currently have a deep pipeline of future hires. We also intend to deliver on exceptional existing hires, relentlessly focusing on renewal retention, leveraging existing retail and wholesale relationships. - _Operational excellence. We believe that through operational excellence we can continue our track record of delivering value through our focus on operational expertise. We have delivered cost efficiencies to drive margin expansion across all divisions, resulting in approximately £150 million of synergies and cost savings delivered to date since the start of 2018, and £15.8 million of cost savings and cost synergies expected to be delivered within the next twelve months, consisting of (i) £3.2 million within the UK Advisory platform resulting from benefits from a target operating model implementation project that has reduced headcount through efficiency gains from optimizing policy administration systems, IT transformations from improving the office network, removing legacy applications and outsourcing and an onshoring finance project expected to deliver benefits from process efficiencies and automation, (ii) £8.2 million within the Specialty Broking platform resulting from the technology-led transformation of our middle and back office functions and the cost synergies identified with the acquisition of Corant Global, including the harmonization of reward structures, footprint consolidation and backoffice optimization, as well as the acquisition of Oxford Insurance, (iii) £3.9 million within the International Advisory platform through the ‘hub and spoke’ model and the integration of further acquisitions into existing platforms and (iv) £0.5 million through back-office optimization in our Corporate segment. We also continue to make significant investments into our technology platform, as we believe that digital solutions will get us closer to our end client, allowing us to leverage and overlay external tools to attract new business and protect existing business.

Section Title: SUMMARY
Subsection Title: Our Strategies
Subsubsection Title: Expand our addressable markets in new synergistic geographies
Subsubsection Text: We intend to continue expanding our addressable markets in synergistic geographies. In 2021 we established our International Advisory platform, under which we are consolidating our non-UK broking enterprises and related investments and under which we have launched our Ardonagh Europe and our 13 ----- Ardonagh Global Partners businesses. We established Ardonagh Global Partners in 2021 to invest in leading platforms operating in attractive markets and verticals outside the UK and Europe and to partner with management teams who want to grow faster as part of a larger group while retaining operational independence. We intend to continue growing our International Advisory platform with the aim of consolidating our presence in a selected portfolio of fast-growing markets and expanding participation in select new products and markets where there is significant synergy between our UK platforms and our International Advisory platform. We are focusing on a number of regions which fulfil our acquisition criteria, and intend to employ the hub and spoke methodology to quickly expand our regional presence. Our aim is to develop a number of regional hubs, with specialist knowledge, technology and product expertise, to support in-country assets, and we intend to focus on strategic markets with assets that are capable of executing further in-country expansion.

Section Title: SUMMARY
Subsection Title: Our Strategies
Subsubsection Title: Continue to grow by capitalizing on targeted acquisitions pipeline
Subsubsection Text: As part of our strategy, we target additional growth expected from accretive acquisitions, and intend to further strengthen our position and broaden our portfolio by continuing to consolidate smaller players in the highly fragmented and competitive UK and international insurance markets. Any acquisition we pursue will be in line with our targeted and selective acquisition criteria focused on companies with attractive profitability, growth potential and complementary business operations. We utilize our network to identify suitable targets at reasonable multiples. We support acquired assets post-acquisition in order to achieve our organic growth plans going forward, utilizing our expertise and networks. We also manage the realization of identified revenue and cost synergies on an ongoing basis. We have a highly disciplined and proven acquisition program, which includes a standardized approach to integration and synergy delivery, which, together with the proven execution ability of our management team and our strong focus on value creation and financial metrics, allows us to maximize synergies and rapidly deploy economies of scale to acquired businesses. We have a robust M&A pipeline underpinned by a rigorous evaluation and assessment process driven by an experienced and dedicated team of M&A professionals, and we continue to explore larger transaction opportunities both in the UK and internationally with a strong focus on market-leading platforms in our international business. Acquisitions completed during the fourth quarter of 2023 (including the impact of the AccuRisk disposal) contributed Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA of £13.6 million for the twelve months ended September 30, 2023, and acquisitions completed between January 1, 2024 and February 1, 2024 contributed an additional £3.0 million. We have a further 36 acquisitions that are contractually committed or under signed letter of intent as of February 1, 2024, which would contribute an additional £32.2 million of Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA. Our pipeline includes targets on multiple continents. We are also actively pursuing other acquisitions in the near-term or very nearterm, including one or more potentially material acquisitions.

Section Title: SUMMARY
Subsection Title: Recent Developments
Subsubsection Text: In September 2023, we announced the merger and disposal of the Retail Business with the Markerstudy Group Limited (the “Merged Business”), with our shareholders maintaining a minority stake in the Merged Business. The transaction values the Retail Business at £1.2 billion and will be funded by a new investment led by Pollen Street Capital and Bain Capital Special Situations. We expect to receive upfront cash consideration of up to £820 million (on a debt free/cash free basis, excluding transaction fees and expenses, and deferred cash consideration linked to related investments) and an approximately £400 million promissory note receivable from a related-party entity (“RP Entity”). The RP Entity is wholly owned by our shareholders and will, with Retail management, receive a 23% equity stake in the Merged Business. The promissory note receivable to be entered into in connection with the completion of the Retail Transaction will accrue interest at a fixed rate of 15% (compounding annually), which will be mandatorily prepaid on any realization of the stake in the Merged Business or a change of control of the RP Entity, and will require the RP Entity not to incur debt, grant security or make distributions 14 ----- without the consent of our Group. We expect to distribute this promissory note receivable to a parent entity of the Parent following the completion of the Retail Transactions. In addition, certain exiting managers will continue to hold shares in management incentive plans within the Group following the completion of the Retail Transactions, and we will buyback such manager’s shares upon exit or otherwise winding up such plan. The Retail Transaction is subject to the satisfaction of certain closing conditions, including customary regulatory and antitrust approvals from both the FCA and the CMA. We expect completion of the Retail Transaction to occur in the second or third quarter of 2024. The Retail Transaction is subject to customary transaction risks, including of delay due to longer than expected regulatory reviews or actions. See “Risk Factors—Risks Related to Our Business and Industry—The Retail Transaction may _be delayed or may not proceed to completion.”_ As a result of the Retail Transaction, in our Unaudited Interim Financial Statements, we have presented Retail as held for sale on our consolidated statement of financial position as of September 30, 2023 and as a discontinued operation on our consolidated statement of profit or loss and other comprehensive income for the nine months period ended September 30, 2023 and the period ended September 30, 2022. We expect a significant portion of the cash proceeds from the Retail Transaction will be applied, subject to certain exceptions and limits, in mandatorily prepaying at par a portion of our New Senior Secured Credit Facilities. More generally, we expect the Retail Transaction to release capital to invest in our higher-growth Specialty Broking and our Global P&C Platforms. See also “Business—Retail—Retail _Transaction.”_ If the Retail Transaction does not proceed to completion, our ratio of as adjusted total net debt to Total Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA would be 5.8x, as calculated by adjusting as adjusted total net debt to remove the net proceeds from the Retail Transaction, including Retail Total EBITDA, and adding Lease Liabilities associated with the Retail Divestiture.

Section Title: SUMMARY
Subsection Title: Recent Developments
Subsubsection Text: We completed 16 acquisitions between October 1, 2023 and December 31, 2023 and have completed 6 acquisitions from January 1, 2024 to February 1, 2024. Notable acquisitions during this period included: - Assepro, one of the largest independent commercial brokers for SMEs in Switzerland, with further operations in Austria and Liechtenstein. Assepro places CHF1.2 billion of premium annually and further strengthens Ardonagh International’s presence across Europe. - RiskSTOP Group, a provider of insurance technology and risk management services to UK insurer and broking communities. The acquisition is highly complementary to Ardonagh UK Advisory’s existing digital client offering. - London Australia Underwriting (“LAUW”), an underwriting agency specializing in professional and financial lines exclusively on behalf of Lloyd’s of London syndicates. This extends agency coverage in Australia and further diversifies Ardonagh International Advisory’s Australian platform. Additionally, 36 acquisitions are contractually committed or under signed letter of intent across Europe, Australia, the UK, Brazil and Ireland as of February 1, 2024. In December 2023, we disposed of the subsidiaries of Alpha Investment Holdings Limited, which includes the AccuRisk Solutions LLC group of entities. They were acquired by Ryan Specialty, an international specialty insurance firm. 15 -----

Section Title: SUMMARY
Subsection Title: Recent Developments
Subsubsection Title: The New Senior Secured Credit Facilities
Subsubsection Text: The Company, among others, as of the date of this offering memorandum, is in the proceeds of negotiating and expect to establish, new additional facilities under its credit facility agreement dated as of June 26, 2020, among the Company and, among others, the administrative agent and the lenders party thereto (as amended and/or restated from time to time, the “Senior Secured Credit Facilities

Subsection Title: Term Facility”) and a Australian dollar-denominated Facility B of up to £111 million (equivalent) (the
Subsubsection Text: “AUD Term Facility” and together with the USD Term Facility and the EUR Term Facility, the “New

Subsection Title: Term Facilities”) and senior secured delayed draw term loan facility in an aggregate principal amount

See “Use of _Proceeds”._ The entry into the Senior Secured Credit Facilities Agreement, the Offering, the entry into the Intercreditor Agreement and the application of the proceeds from the Senior Secured Credit Facilities Agreement and the Offering are collectively referred to in this offering memorandum as the “Transactions.” Escrow Account Concurrently with the closing of the Offering, the initial purchasers will deposit the gross proceeds of the Notes into escrow accounts (the “Escrow Accounts”) in the names of the respective Issuers, but controlled by the Trustee, Ankura Trust Company, LLC, as escrow agent (in such capacity, together with its successors, the “Escrow Agent”) pending funding under the New Term Facilities as described under as described in “—Recent Developments—The Refinancing,” and pledged on a first-ranking basis in favor of the Trustee on behalf of the holders of the respective series of Notes. The release of the escrow proceeds will be subject to the satisfaction of certain conditions. Section Title: SUMMARY
Subsection Title: Term Facilities”) and senior secured delayed draw term loan facility in an aggregate principal amount
Subsubsection Text: of $175 million, a senior secured delayed draw term loan facility in an aggregate principal amount of €165 million and a senior secured delayed draw term loan facility in an aggregate principal amount of AUD 100 million (collectively, the “CAR Facility”). We are, as of the date of this offering memorandum, in the process of negotiating, and expect to amend, our existing multi-currency new revolving credit facility to provide for borrowings of between £240-300 million (equivalent) (the “Revolving Credit Facility” and together with the New Term Facilities and the CAR Facility, the “New Senior Secured Credit Facilities”). The New Senior Secured Credit Facilities will be secured on a first-priority basis by the Shared Collateral and guaranteed by the Guarantors on a senior basis. See “Description of Other Indebtedness _and Financing Arrangements—Senior Secured Credit Facilities Agreement.” Proceeds from the New_ Term Facilities will be used to repay the outstanding drawings under the Senior Secured Facilities Agreement on or about the Escrow Release Date. See “Use of Proceeds”. To the extent we do not receive the required third-party consent required to refinance the Australian Local Facility, we may not fund the AUD Term Facility and the Australian Local Facility may remain outstanding.

Subsubsection Text: _The below information for the year ended December 31, 2023 is derived from AGHL’s internal accounting records and are subject to our financial closing procedures. This information has been prepared by management. It has not been audited, reviewed, verified or subject to any procedures by our auditors and you should not place undue reliance on it, and no opinion or any other form of assurance is provided with respect thereto. This information is based upon a number of assumptions and judgments that are subject to inherent uncertainties and are subject to change, and are not intended to be a comprehensive statement of the financial or operational results as of and for the period indicated. Because this information is preliminary, it is subject to change and should not be considered indicative of actual results that would be achieved for the entire annual period and it does not purport to indicate our future consolidated results of operations or financial position. The above information also includes forward-looking information, which by its nature involves risk and uncertainty because it relates to future circumstances. See “Forward-Looking Statements” and “Risk Factors.”_

Section Title: SUMMARY
Subsection Title: Constant Perimeter[(3) ]
Subsubsection Text: Total Income .............................................. 322,301 348,280 8.1% 1,257,950 1,388,045 10.3% Adjusted EBITDA ...................................... 91,183 109,891 20.5% 393,964 454,747 15.4% Adjusted EBITDA margin ......................... 28.3% 31.6% 330 bps 31.3% 32.8% 150 bps (1) Retail is presented as a discontinued operation in the consolidated statement of profit and loss and other comprehensive income in the financial information of AGHL for the three months and the years ended December 31, 2022 and December 31, 2023, and therefore excluded from the results presented in the above table. Please see “—Summary Historical Financial and Other _Information—Other Consolidated and Pro Forma Data.”_ (2) Figures for the three months and year ended December 31, 2023 are approximates. (3) Based on the perimeter of the Group as of December 31, 2023. The increase in Total Income for the year ended December 31, 2023 compared to the year ended December 31, 2022 was primarily due to organic performance growth combined with further acquisitions. The increase in Adjusted EBITDA for the year ended December 31, 2023 compared to the year ended December 31, 2022 was primarily driven by organic performance growth combined with further acquisitions. During the three months ended December 31, 2023, we entered into certain transactions that impacted our statement of financial position. In October 2023, we increased our borrowings by drawing $130.0 million of USD Facility B6 under our Senior Secured Credit Facilities Agreement. As of December 31, 2023, we had £283 million equivalent of undrawn Facilities consisting of $182.5 million and $171.7 million respectively under USD Facilities B5 and B6 of our Senior Secured Credit Facilities Agreement. On January 10, 2024, we drew the remaining $182.5 million USD B5 Facility and have $171.7 million undrawn of the USD Facility B6 as of February 2, 2024. In addition to this, the £191.5 million RCF remains undrawn as of February 2, 2024. We may draw down the remaining USD Facility B6 prior to the closing of the Transactions to fund acquisitions in February and March. We also entered into a large 17 ----- new lease in its Specialty Broking segment, which increased its IFRS lease liabilities by approximately £14 million. In addition, the calculation of the amount of our debt based on our foreign exchange rates changed. We are currently using an exchange rate of $1.25/£1.00 and €1.15/£1.00. We disposed of AccuRisk (and received the cash from the disposal on December 1, 2023) and acquired Assepro along with other acquisitions. See “—Recent Acquisitions and Disposals” above. We also received a AUD 150 million equity investment into its Australian business. Our Available Cash as of December 31, 2023 was approximately £308 million.

Section Title: SUMMARY
Subsection Title: Our Sponsors
Subsubsection Text: HPS Investment Partners is a leading global investment firm that seeks to provide creative capital solutions and generate attractive risk-adjusted returns for our clients. We manage various strategies across the capital structure that include syndicated leveraged loans and high yield bonds to privately negotiated senior secured debt and mezzanine investments, asset-based leasing and private equity. The scale and breadth of our platform offers the flexibility to invest in companies large and small, through standard or customized solutions. At our core, we share a common thread of intellectual rigor and discipline that enables us to create value for our clients, who have entrusted us with approximately $108 billion of assets under management as of December 2023. Madison Dearborn Partners, LLC (“MDP”), based in Chicago, is a leading private equity investment firm. Since its formation in 1992, MDP has raised eight funds with aggregate capital of approximately $28 billion and has completed investments in more than 160 companies. MDP invests across a broad spectrum of industries, including: technology and government; basic industries; financial and transaction services; and health care. A flexible investment approach, encompassing both buyout and growth equity investments and a focus on upper middle market and middle market companies have been and continue to be key tenets of MDP’s investment strategy. 18 -----

Section Title: SUMMARY CORPORATE AND FINANCING STRUCTURE
Subsubsection Text: The diagram below provides a simplified overview of our corporate and financing structure on a consolidated basis as of the date of this offering memorandum, after giving effect to the Transactions and the use of proceeds from the Offering. The diagram does not include all entities in our group and does not include management shareholders, nor does it show all liabilities in our group. For a summary of the material financing arrangements identified in the diagram, see “Description of Other _Indebtedness and Financing Arrangements” and “Description of the Notes.” _ (1) As of the date of this offering memorandum, 31.15% of the voting interests in Tara Topco Limited are owned, indirectly, by funds managed, advised and/or controlled by HPS Investment Partners, LLC (“HPS”) or its affiliates, 67.48% of the voting interests are owned by entities affiliated with MDP and the remaining 1.37% of voting interests are held by other minority shareholders. See “Shareholders” and “Management—Management Equity Interests.” (2) Following completion of the Tara Transactions on May 30, 2022, the corporate structure of the Group changed. This impacted our financial information as we previously reported our results at the level of The Ardonagh Group Limited. On May 31, 2022, The Ardonagh Group Limited merged into the Group’s new indirect parent company, Tara Topco Limited. Following this merger, AGHL acquired Ardonagh New Midco 3 Limited, including the Group companies that were previously owned by The Ardonagh Group Limited, on June 1, 2022, and has become the reporting entity for the Group. See “Presentation of Financial Information.” (3) The Parent, which will be a Guarantor of the Senior Notes, is the top entity in the restricted group under the Senior Indenture and the direct parent of the Senior Notes Issuer. Upon consummation of the Offering, the Senior Notes Issuer will on-loan the proceeds of the Senior Notes Offering to the Parent and enter into the Senior Proceeds Loan. (4) The Senior Notes Issuer is a private limited liability company incorporated under the laws of Jersey for the purpose of the Transactions and other potential transactions and is not expected to engage in any activities other than those related to its formation, the Transactions and other future transactions permitted by the Senior Indenture. The Senior Notes Issuer is a wholly owned, direct subsidiary of the Parent. The Senior Notes Issuer’s only material assets and liabilities will be its outstanding indebtedness under the Senior Notes, the receivable under the Senior Proceeds Loan, any other future indebtedness and certain intercompany balances, and any other assets or liabilities that arise as a result of transactions not prohibited by the Senior Indenture. The Senior Notes Issuer’s rights under the Senior Proceeds Loan will be assigned to the Security Agent and form part of the Topco Collateral. 19 ----- (5) The Senior Notes Issuer is offering $1,000,000,000 in aggregate principal amount of Senior Notes. The Senior Notes will be general senior obligations of the Issuer, will rank pari passu in right of payment with all of the Senior Notes Issuer’s existing and future indebtedness that is not expressly subordinated in right of payment to the Senior Notes, will rank senior in right of payment to all existing and future indebtedness of the Senior Notes Issuer that is expressly subordinated in right of payment to the Senior Notes, will be effectively subordinated to all existing and future indebtedness of the Senior Notes Issuer that is secured by property and assets that do not secure the Senior Notes or that is secured on a first-priority basis over property or assets that secure the Senior Notes on a second-priority basis, in each case to the extent of the value of the property and assets securing such obligation or indebtedness, including obligations under the Senior Secured Notes and the Senior Secured Credit Facilities Agreement and certain hedging obligations. The Senior Notes will not be guaranteed on the Issue Date. Subject to and in accordance with the Agreed Security Principles, on the Escrow Release Date, the Senior Notes will be guaranteed (the “Senior **Note Guarantees”) on a senior basis by the Parent and on a subordinated basis by the Senior Secured Notes Issuer, the Company, and Ardonagh Finco Plc, Ardonagh Services Limited and the New SFA Borrowers (the “Subsidiary Guarantors” and together with the Company and, in respect of the Senior Notes only, the Parent and the Senior Secured Notes Issuer, the “Guarantors”). Given the regulated nature of our business, we have limited ability to grant upstream credit support. As a result, the Issuers and the Guarantors will represent approximately 4.3% of our Adjusted EBITDA (including Retail) for the twelve months ended September 30, 2023. We have granted security in respect of the Senior Secured Notes from additional non-guarantor entities, which together with the Issuers and the Guarantors, represent 52.1% of our Adjusted EBITDA (including Retail) for the twelve months ended September 30, 2023. Concurrently with the closing of the Offering, the initial purchasers will deposit the gross proceeds of the Senior Notes into one or more escrow accounts (the “Senior Escrow Accounts”) in the names of the Senior Notes Issuer, but controlled by the Escrow Agent pending funding under the New Term Facilities, and pledged on a first-ranking basis in favor of the Trustee on behalf of the holders of the Senior Notes. Subject to the Agreed Security Principles, the Intercreditor Agreement and certain perfection requirements, the Senior Notes and the Senior Note Guarantees will be secured on or about the date the proceeds of the Notes are released to the Issuers from the Escrow Accounts (the “Escrow Release Date”), on (a) a first-ranking basis, by security over (i) the shares of the Parent held by Ardonagh Midco 1 Ltd. (“Topco”); (ii) structural intercompany receivables owed to Topco by the Parent (if any); (iii) the shares of the Senior Notes Issuer held by the Parent; and (iv) the Senior Proceeds Loan and any other structural intercompany receivables owed to the Senior Notes Issuer by the Parent (collectively, the “Topco Collateral”); and (b) a second-ranking basis, by security over (i) the shares of the Company held by the Parent and (ii) structural intercompany receivables owed to the Parent by the Company (if any) (collectively, the “Shared Collateral”). See “Description of the Senior _Notes,” “Service of Process and Enforcement of Civil Liabilities” and “Certain Insolvency Law Considerations.”_ (6) The Company, which will be a Guarantor of the Senior Notes and the Senior Secured Notes, is the top entity in the restricted group under the Senior Secured Indenture and the direct parent of the Senior Secured Notes Issuer. Upon consummation of the Offering, the Senior Secured Notes Issuer will on-loan the proceeds of the Senior Secured Notes Offering to the Company and enter into the Senior Secured Proceeds Loan. (7) The Senior Secured Notes Issuer is a private limited liability company incorporated under the laws of Jersey for the purpose of the Transactions and other potential transactions and is not expected to engage in any activities other than those related to its formation, the Transactions and other future transactions permitted by the Senior Secured Indenture. The Senior Secured Notes Issuer is a wholly owned, direct subsidiary of the Company. The Senior Secured Notes Issuer’s only material assets and liabilities will be its outstanding indebtedness under the Senior Secured Notes, the receivables under the Senior Secured Proceeds Loan, any other future indebtedness and certain intercompany balances, and any other assets or liabilities that arise as a result of transactions not prohibited by the Senior Secured Indenture. The Senior Secured Notes Issuer’s rights under the Senior Secured Proceeds Loan will be assigned to the Security Agent and form part of the Senior Secured Notes Collateral. (8) The Senior Secured Notes Issuer is offering $500,000,000 in aggregate principal amount of Dollar Senior Secured Notes and €500,000,000 in aggregate principal amount of Euro Senior Secured Notes. The Senior Secured Notes will be general senior obligations of the Senior Secured Notes Issuer, will rank pari passu in right of payment with all of the Senior Secured Notes Issuer’s existing and future indebtedness that is not expressly subordinated in right of payment to the Senior Secured Notes, will rank senior in right of payment to all existing and future indebtedness of the Senior Secured Notes Issuer that is expressly subordinated in right of payment to the Senior Secured Notes, will be effectively subordinated to all existing and future indebtedness of the Senior Secured Notes Issuer that is secured by property and assets that do not secure the Senior Secured Notes, in each case to the extent of the value of the property and assets securing such obligation or indebtedness. Concurrently with the closing of the Offering, the initial purchasers will deposit the gross proceeds of the Senior Secured Notes into one or more escrow accounts (the “Senior Secured Escrow Accounts”) in the names of the Senior Secured Notes Issuer, but controlled by the Escrow Agent pending funding under the New Senior Secured Credit Facilities, and pledged on a first-ranking basis in favor of the Trustee on behalf of the holders of the Senior Secured Notes. Subject to and in accordance with the Agreed Security Principles, the Senior Secured Notes will be guaranteed on the Escrow Release Date a senior basis by the Company and by and the Subsidiary Guarantors on the terms described herein. The Senior Secured Guarantors will also guarantee (or otherwise be obligors in respect of) the obligations under the New Senior Secured Credit Facilities Agreement on a senior basis. Subject to the Agreed Security Principles, the Intercreditor Agreement and certain perfection requirements, the Senior Secured Notes and the Senior Secured Note Guarantees will be secured, on a first-ranking basis, by security over the Shared Collateral and the other Collateral and on the timeframes as further described in “Description of the Senior Secured Notes—Security.” (9) New subsidiaries that are wholly owned, direct subsidiaries of the Company will be incorporated in the Netherlands, Australia and Delaware, the United States prior to the Escrow Release Date in connection with the Transactions to act as borrowers, or coborrowers, under certain of the New Senior Secured Credit Facilities (the “New SFA Borrowers”). The legal names of the SFA Borrowers may be different once incorporated. Certain proceeds of the New EUR Term Facility and the New USD Term Facility will be on-lent to the Company. 20 ----- (10) The SFA Borrowers, among others, are expected to enter into the Senior Secured Credit Facilities Agreement on or prior to the Escrow Release Date. The Guarantors (other than the Parent) will guarantee the Secured Credit Facilities on a pari passu basis with the Senior Secured Note Guarantees (although any liabilities in respect of obligations under the Revolving Credit Facility will have priority with respect to the application of the proceeds from the distressed disposal of, or enforcement of, the Collateral) and on a senior basis to the Senior Note Guarantees. The Secured Credit Facilities and certain hedging obligations will be secured on a first-priority basis by the Shared Collateral. See “Description of Other Indebtedness and Financing Arrangements—Senior _Secured Credit Facilities Agreement.”_ (11) As of the date of this offering memorandum, we had a 100% interest in our subsidiaries other than as specified under “Business— _Our Subsidiaries.” See also “Management.” The minority shareholders in our subsidiaries may receive certain distributions ahead_ of distributions made to holders of the Notes. From time to time, we have bought out and we may continue to buy out minority interests as and when market opportunities are aligned with our business strategy. See “Risk Factors—Risks Related to our _Financial Profile—Despite our substantial leverage, we may still be able to incur more debt under the Indenture governing the Notes.” Further, the percentages set forth the respective economic rights in connection with a distribution or dividend on ordinary_ shares but are disapplied in circumstances in which a liquidity event may apply. See “Management—Management Equity Interests” for information on these voting rights. (12) We expect to receive an approximately £400 million promissory note receivable from the RP Entity as a portion of the consideration for the Retail Transaction, which we expect to distribute to a parent entity of the Parent following the completion of the Retail Transaction. The RP Entity is wholly owned by our shareholders and will, with Retail management, receive a 23% equity stake in the Merged Business. See “—Recent Developments—Retail Transaction.” 21 -----
