Subject to the Agreed Security Principles, the Intercreditor Agreement and certain perfection requirements, the Senior Secured Notes and the Senior Secured Note Guarantees will be secured on the Escrow Release Date, or in respect of any security provided by a person other than a Guarantor, within 30 days of the Escrow Release Date, on a first-ranking basis by: • third-party, limited recourse security over (i) the shares of Company held by the Parent; and (ii) structural intercompany receivables owed to the Parent by the Company (if any) (the “Shared Collateral”); • security over the shares owned by any Guarantor in the capital of any other Guarantor; • security over the material bank accounts of each Guarantor which are located in its jurisdiction of organization (without control over use); • security over any intercompany receivables owed to any Guarantor by the Company or any Restricted Subsidiary; • security by way of a springing security interest over substantially all assets of each Guarantor organized under the laws of Australia pursuant to an Australian law general security deed; 29 ----- - security over (i) the shares of Senior ###### Secured Notes Issuer held by the Company; and (ii) the Senior Secured Proceeds Loan and any other structural intercompany receivables owed to the Senior Secured Notes Issuer by the Company; - security over substantially all assets of ###### each Guarantor organized under the laws of England pursuant to an English law debenture; - security over substantially all the assets of ###### each Guarantor organized under the laws of the United States (or any state or political sub-division thereof) which are located in the United States or any state thereof (including the District of Columbia) and where such security is capable of being registered and perfected solely by customary UCC-1 filings in the grantor’s jurisdiction of incorporation or formation, pursuant to a New York law security agreement; - security (on a third party, limited recourse ###### basis, where granted by a person other than a Guarantor) over (i) the shares held by Ardonagh Advisory Broking Holdings Limited (formerly known as Ardonagh Advisory Holdings Limited) in the capital of Advisory Insurance Brokers Limited (formerly known as Towergate Underwriting Group Limited), (ii) Ardonagh Specialty Holdings Limited’s shares in the capital of Ardonagh Specialty Limited (formerly known as Price Forbes & Partners Limited), (iii) Nevada Investments Holdings Limited’s shares in the capital of Ardonagh Specialty Holdings Limited, (iv) Arachas Bidco Designated Activity Company’s shares in the capital of Arachas Corporate Brokers Limited, (v) Ardonagh Services Limited’s shares in the capital of Nevada 5 Topco Limited, (vi) Nevada Investments Topco Limited’s shares in the capital of Atlanta Investment Holdings 3 Limited, (vii) Paymentshield Group 30 ----- ###### Holdings Limited’s shares in the capital of Paymentshield Limited and (viii) Swinton (Holdings) Limited’s shares in the capital of Atlanta Insurance Intermediaries Limited (formerly known as Swinton Group Limited), provided that the security in foregoing clauses (vi) to (viii) shall be released upon completion of the Retail Transaction; and - security over the Company’s shares in the ###### capital of each borrower of the Term Facilities, and each such borrower shall grant security over its relevant assets the foregoing, together with any and all assets from time to time in which a security interest has been or will be granted pursuant to any security document to secure obligations under the Senior Secured Indenture, the Senior Secured Notes and/or any Senior Secured Note Guarantee, the “Senior Secured Notes Collateral”) Senior Notes Collateral ........................... On the Issue Date by security over the Senior Escrow Account into which the gross proceeds of the Senior Notes will be deposited. Subject to the Agreed Security Principles, the Intercreditor Agreement and certain perfection requirements, the Notes and the Note Guarantees will be secured on or about the Escrow Release Date on a first-ranking basis, by security over - the shares of the Parent held by Topco; - structural intercompany receivables owed ###### to Topco by the Parent (if any); - the shares of the Senior Notes Issuer held ###### by the Parent; and - the Senior Proceeds Loan and any other ###### structural intercompany receivables owed to the Senior Notes Issuer by the Parent, collectively, the “Topco Collateral”; and on a second-ranking basis, by security over: - the shares of the Company held by the ###### Parent; and 31 ----- ###### Optional Redemption Senior Secured Notes Optional Redemption ....................................... - structural intercompany receivables owed ###### to the Parent to the Company (if any),] collectively, the “Shared Collateral” and together with the Topco Collateral, the “Senior Notes Collateral” and the Senior Notes Collateral together with the Senior Secured Notes Collateral, the “Collateral.” The Shared Collateral will also secure the Senior Secured Credit Facilities and certain hedging obligations, and may secure other future indebtedness, on a first-ranking basis. For more information about the Collateral, see “Description of the Senior Secured Notes— Security” and “Description of the Senior Notes— Security” and for more information on potential limitations to the security interests, see “Risk Factors—Risks Related to the Notes, the Note Guarantees and the Collateral” and “Certain Insolvency Law Considerations.” The security interests in the Collateral may be released in certain circumstances. See “Description of the Senior Secured Notes— Security—Release of Liens,” “Description of the Senior Notes—Security—Release of Liens,” “Description of Other Indebtedness and Financing Arrangements—Intercreditor Agreement” and “Risk Factors—Risks Related to the Notes, the Note Guarantees and the Collateral—There are circumstances other than the repayment or discharge of the Notes under which the Note Guarantees or the Collateral securing the Notes will be released automatically without your consent or the Trustee or the Security Agent obtaining your further consent.” At any time on or after   , 2027, the Senior Secured Notes Issuer may redeem some or all of the Senior Secured Notes at the redemption prices set forth in “Description of the Senior Secured Notes—Optional Redemption” plus accrued and unpaid interest and additional amounts, if any, to the date of redemption. In addition, at any time prior to  , 2027, the Senior Secured Notes Issuer may redeem up to 32 ----- ###### 10% of the Senior Secured Notes during each calendar year commencing on the issue date at a price equal to 103% of the aggregate principal amount thereof, plus accrued and unpaid interest to the redemption date. At any time prior to   , 2027, the Senior Secured Notes Issuer may redeem, at its option, some or all of the Senior Secured Notes at a redemption price equal to 100% of the principal amount of the Senior Secured Notes plus accrued and unpaid interest, if any, to the applicable redemption dates plus the applicable “make whole” premium set forth in “Description of the Senior Secured Notes—Optional Redemption.” At any time prior to    , 2027, the Senior Secured Notes Issuer may also redeem up to 40% of the original aggregate principal amount of the Senior Secured Notes (including the aggregate principal amount of any additional Senior Secured Notes) at a redemption price equal to     % plus accrued and unpaid interest and additional amounts, if any, provided that at least 50% of the original aggregate principal amount of the Senior Secured Notes (excluding the aggregate principal amount of any additional Senior Secured Notes of the same series) remain outstanding, with the net proceeds of one or more specified equity offerings. See “Description of the Senior Secured Notes—Optional Redemption.” Senior Notes Optional Redemption ........ At any time on or after   , 2027, the Senior Notes Issuer may redeem some or all of the Senior Notes at the redemption prices set forth in “Description of the Senior Notes—Optional Redemption” plus accrued and unpaid interest and additional amounts, if any, to the date of redemption. At any time prior to   , 2027, the Senior Notes Issuer may redeem, at its option, some or all of the Senior Notes at a redemption price equal to 100% of the principal amount of the Senior Notes plus accrued and unpaid interest, if any, to the applicable redemption dates plus the applicable “make whole” premium set forth in “Description of the Senior Notes—Optional Redemption.” At any time prior to    , 2027, the Senior Notes Issuer may also redeem up to 40% of the 33 ----- ###### aggregate principal amount of the Senior Notes (including the aggregate principal amount of any additional Senior Notes) at a redemption price equal to    % plus accrued and unpaid interest and additional amounts, if any, provided that at least 60% of the original aggregate principal amount of the Senior Notes (excluding the aggregate principal amount of any additional Senior Notes of the same series) remain outstanding, with the net proceeds of one or more specified equity offerings. See “Description of the Senior Notes—Optional Redemption.” Change of Control ................................... Upon certain events defined as constituting a change of control, the Issuers may be required to make an offer to purchase the outstanding Notes at a purchase price equal to 101% of the principal amount thereof, plus accrued and unpaid interest and additional amounts, if any, to the date of purchase. See “Description of the Senior Secured Notes—Change of Control” and “Description of the Senior Notes—Change of Control.” Redemption for Taxation Reasons ......... If certain changes in the law of any relevant taxing jurisdiction impose certain withholding taxes or other deductions on the payments on the Notes or the Note Guarantees and as a result additional amounts are required to be paid, the relevant Issuer may redeem the relevant Notes, in whole, but not in part, at a redemption price of 100% of the principal amount thereof, plus accrued and unpaid interest and additional amounts, if any, to the date of redemption. See “Description of the Senior Secured Notes— Redemption for Taxation Reasons” and “Description of the Senior Notes—Redemption for Taxation Reasons.” Additional Amounts ................................ All payments made by each Issuer or any relevant Guarantor with respect to the Notes will be made without withholding or deduction for, or on account of, any present or future taxes in any relevant taxing jurisdiction unless so required by applicable law. If withholding or deduction for such taxes is required by law in any relevant tax jurisdiction with respect to a payment on the relevant Notes or the relevant Note Guarantees, subject to certain exceptions, the relevant Issuer or the relevant Guarantor, as the case may be, will pay the additional amounts necessary so that the net amount received after the withholding or 34 ----- ###### deduction is not less than the amount that would have been received in the absence of the withholding or deduction. See “Description of the Senior Secured Notes—Withholding Taxes/Additional Amounts” and “Description of the Senior Notes—Withholding Taxes/Additional Amounts.” Certain Covenants .................................. The Indentures will contain covenants which, among other things, limit the ability of the Company and its restricted subsidiaries (in respect of the Senior Secured Notes) and the Parent and its restricted subsidiaries (in respect of the Senior Notes) to: - incur or guarantee additional indebtedness ###### and issue certain preferred stock; - make certain restricted payments, ###### including dividends or other distributions; - create or permit to exist certain liens; - sell certain assets; - create certain restrictions on the ability of ###### our restricted subsidiaries to pay dividends or make other payments to us; - merge or consolidate with other entities or ###### transfer all or substantially all of our assets and the assets of our subsidiaries on a consolidated basis; - guarantee certain types of additional debt ###### of the relevant Issuer or a Guarantor without also guaranteeing the relevant Notes; - engage in certain transactions with ###### affiliates; - impair the security interests in the ###### Collateral; and - create unrestricted subsidiaries. ###### These covenants are subject to a number of important limitations and exceptions as described under “Description of the Senior Secured Notes— Certain Covenants” and “Description of the Senior Notes—Certain Covenants.” 35 ----- ###### Transfer Restrictions ............................... The Notes and the Note Guarantees have not been and will not be registered under the U.S. Securities Act or the securities laws of any other jurisdiction and may not be offered or sold, except pursuant to an exemption from, or in a transaction not subject to, the registration requirements of the U.S. Securities Act. We have not agreed to, or otherwise undertaken to, and do not intend to register the Notes (including by way of an exchange offer). See “Notice to Investors.” Escrow of Proceeds; Special Mandatory Redemption ....................................... Concurrently with the closing of the Offering, the initial purchasers will deposit the gross proceeds of the Notes into the segregated Escrow Accounts in the names of the respective Issuers, but controlled by the Escrow Agent pending funding under the New Senior Secured Credit Facilities, and pledged on a first-ranking basis in favor of the Trustee (as defined herein) on behalf of the holders of the respective series of Notes. The release of the escrow proceeds will be subject to the satisfaction of certain conditions. If the conditions to the release of the escrow proceeds have not been satisfied on or prior to the Escrow Longstop Date or upon the occurrence of certain other events, the Notes will be subject to a special mandatory redemption. The special mandatory redemption price of the Notes will be equal to 100% of the aggregate issue price of the respective Notes, plus accrued and unpaid interest and additional amounts, if any, to, but excluding such special mandatory redemption date. Use of Proceeds ....................................... We intend to use the proceeds of the Offering, together with proceeds from drawings under the Term Facilities and certain proceeds from the Retail Transaction, (i) to fund the Existing Notes Redemption; (ii) to repay drawn amounts under the Existing Senior Secured Credit Facilities; (iii) to pay the fees and expenses incurred in connection with the Transactions, including fees and expenses incurred in connection with the Offering and redemption costs incurred in connection with the Existing Notes Redemption; and (iv) for general corporate purposes, including one or more acquisition opportunities in the near 36 ----- ###### term and funding cash to our balance sheet. See “Use of Proceeds” and “Capitalization.” U.S. Federal Income Taxation of OID ... If the stated principal amount of a series of Notes exceeds their issue price by an amount greater than or equal to a statutorily defined de minimis amount, then such Notes will be considered to be issued with original issue discount (“OID”) for U.S. federal income tax purposes in an amount equal to the excess of the stated principal amount over the issue price of such Notes. If Notes are issued with OID, a holder of such Notes subject to U.S. federal income taxation generally will be required to include such OID in gross income (as ordinary income) for U.S. federal income tax purposes as it accrues (on a constant yield to maturity basis), in advance of the receipt of cash attributable to such OID, irrespective of such holder’s regular method of tax accounting. See “Certain Tax Considerations—Certain United States Federal Income Tax Considerations— Original Issue Discount.” Listing ..................................................... Application will be made for listing particulars to be approved by the Exchange and for the Notes to be listed on the Official List of the Exchange. Governing Law........................................  The Indentures, the Notes and the Note Guarantees will be governed by New York law. The Intercreditor Agreement is governed by English law. The Security Documents will be governed by English, Irish, Australian, Dutch, Cayman and Jersey law. Trustee .....................................................  Ankura Trust Company, LLC. Security Agent .........................................  Ankura Trust Company, LLC. Dollar Paying Agent and Transfer Agent  Ankura Trust Company, LLC. Euro Paying Agent ..................................  Elavon Financial Services DAC. Registrar ..................................................  Ankura Trust Company, LLC. Escrow Agent ..........................................  Ankura Trust Company, LLC. 37 -----

Subsubsection Text: (1) On May 31, 2022, The Ardonagh Group Limited, the entity at which we previously reported our results, merged into the Group’s new indirect parent company, Tara Topco Limited. Following this merger, on June 1, 2022, AGHL acquired Ardonagh New Midco 3 Limited, including the Group companies that were previously owned by The Ardonagh Group Limited, and became the reporting entity for the Group. AGHL’s first reporting period included all transactions since its incorporation on December 8, 2021 to December 31, 2022, but only includes four months of the results of operations and cash flows of the consolidated operations of AGHL due to the timing of the Tara Transactions. In order to present meaningfully comparable financial information, we present the financial information of (i) the Company for the years ended 2020, 2021 and 2022 and (ii) AGHL for the nine months ended September 30, 2023 and the twelve months ended September 30, 2023 in this table. See “Presentation of Financial Information” and note 1 to the Unaudited Interim Financial Statements. (2) The consolidated statement of profit and loss of AGHL for the period ended September 30, 2022 includes all transactions from the incorporation of AGHL on December 8, 2021 to September 30, 2022, but only includes four months of the results of operations of the consolidated operations of AGHL due to the timing of the Tara Transactions. As a result of the limited comparability between the consolidated statement of profit and loss of AGHL for the period ended September 30, 2022 and the nine months ended 2023, we have not presented the consolidated statement of profit and loss of AGHL for the period ended September 30, 2022 in this table. See “Presentation of Financial Information” and notes 1 and 26 to the Unaudited Interim Financial Statements. (3) As a result of the Retail Transaction, Retail is presented as a discontinued operation in the consolidated statement of loss and other comprehensive income in the financial information of AGHL for the nine months ended September 30, 2023 and the twelve months ended September 30, 2023, and therefore excluded from the results presented in the above table. See “Presentation of Financial _Information” and note 26 to the Unaudited Interim Financial Statements._ 40 ----- (4) In the 2022 Audited Financial Statements, the Parent changed the presentation of investment income and it is now presented as part of finance income. This change in presentation was reflected also in the comparative period. As such, the line items investment income, operating profit and finance income for the year ended 31 December 2021 included in this offering memorandum and derived from the 2021 Audited Financial Statements differ from the same line items in the 2021 comparative column in the 2022 Audited Financial Statements. The information for the year ended December 31, 2020 also does not reflect this change in presentation. 41 -----

Section Title: SUMMARY HISTORICAL FINANCIAL INFORMATION AND OTHER DATA
Subsubsection Text: (1) See note (1) under “—Consolidated Statement of Profit or Loss” above, “Presentation of Financial Information” and note 1 to the Unaudited Interim Financial Statements. (2) See note (2) under “—Consolidated Statement of Profit or Loss” above, “Presentation of Financial Information” and notes 1 and 26 to the Unaudited Interim Financial Statements. 45 ----- (3) See note (3) under “—Consolidated Statement of Profit or Loss” above, “Presentation of Financial Information” and notes 1 and 26 to the Unaudited Interim Financial Statements. (4) We define profit from disposal of assets as the disposal of property, plant and equipment, right-of-use assets and intangible assets. (5) We define foreign exchange movements as gains/losses arising on the revaluation of monetary items (debtors, creditors, cash, etc.) and on derivatives to which hedge accounting has not been applied. (6) We define MSA recharge as group management services charges which cover the transaction costs associated with previous refinancing or capital structuring projects. (7) The adjustment for transformational hires includes the removal of costs for hiring new teams or individual employees with experience from industries or product lines in which the Group does not have existing operations. It includes costs associated with buying out new hires of existing contracts, bonus schemes, sign-on deals and any net losses associated with new joiners who have annual salaries of at least £80,000 (or the equivalent in jurisdictions outside the United Kingdom) up to the first year after any capacity or covenant restriction. (8) The adjustment for business transformation costs includes the removal of certain costs incurred in achieving synergies from enhancing existing business processes, such as restructuring and investing in new systems, cost savings and process improvements. (9) The adjustment for legacy costs includes the removal of the costs associated with resolving legacy issues within the Group that are not related to the Group’s current trading activity and have been corrected over time. The amount of adjustments related to legacy costs has reduced period-on-period during the periods presented. (10) We define other costs as costs that are outside of the normal course of business, including (i) costs incurred in 2020 and 2021 that are directly attributable to the COVID-19 pandemic that would not have been incurred otherwise, (ii) professional fee relating to a transaction involving an equity investment into The Ardonagh Group Limited, including post-deal advice to the Group’s investors in relation to non-cash MIPs; and (iii) non-cash MIP and share based payment charged in the Ireland P&C segment of the Global P&C platform relating to Arachas. (11) We define regulatory costs as costs associated with one-off regulatory reviews and with changes in the regulatory and compliance environments. (12) We define acquisition and financing costs as costs associated with acquiring businesses, with disposing of parts of the business, with raising additional financing (legal and accounting advisors, rating agencies, etc.), and with a change in the value of contingent consideration (after the measurement period has ended). (13) Pro Forma for Completed Transactions are adjustments to give pro forma effect to (i) all acquisitions completed during the period, and (ii) financing transactions, in each case, as if they had occurred on the first day of the period. (14) Pro Forma for Q4 2023 Completed Transactions (including AccuRisk Disposal) are adjustments to give pro forma effect to (i) all material acquisitions completed between October 1, 2023 and December 31, 2023, including certain cost and procurement synergies, and (ii) the disposal of AccuRisk following its sale in the fourth quarter of 2023, in each case, as if they had occurred on the first day of the period. (15) Pro Forma for Q4 2023 Organic Growth adjusts for organic growth for the three months ended December 31, 2023, calculated as the Adjusted EBITDA contribution for the three months ended December 30, 2023 less the Adjusted EBITDA contribution for the three months ended December 31, 2022, in each case, on a constant perimeter basis as of September 30, 2023. See “—Recent _Developments—Trading Update.”_ (16) Pro Forma for Cost savings and synergies (excluding AccuRisk) comprises acquisition synergies and operational efficiencies across the Group. Approximately 56% of this adjustment relates to annualizing the impact of benefits not yet realized from initiatives that have already been completed as if they had already been realized on the first day of the period. The remaining adjustment reflects the benefits of initiatives are in process and expected to be completed within 12 months as if they had already been realized on the first day of the period. (17) Pro Forma for Completed Acquisitions (post-December 31, 2023) are adjustments to give pro forma effect to all material acquisitions completed between January 1, 2024 and February 1, 2024, including certain cost and procurement synergies as if they had occurred on the first day of the period. (18) Pro Forma Transactions under LOI are adjustments that give pro forma effect to 36 acquisitions across Europe, Australia, Brazil, the United Kingdom and Ireland that are contractually committed or subject to a signed letter of intent and at an advanced stage of negotiations as of February 1, 2024, expected to complete by the end of the second quarter of 2024, including expected cost and procurement synergies, as if they had occurred on the first day of the period. (19) This adjustment reflects the EBITDA contribution of producer hires, who have not yet reached maturity, assuming their production at 100% maturity, net of assumed bonuses. We estimate the expected contribution of transformational hires at maturity based on the investment case with a 25% haircut at the time of the respective addition to the business and adjusted following regular subsequent sensitivity assessments on a team-by-team basis based on performance and market conditions. In the twelve months 46 ----- ended September 30, 2023, we had (i) seven teams hired in 2020 at a maturity of 75%; (ii) seven teams hired in 2021 at a maturity of 58%; (iii) seven teams hired in 2022 at a maturity of 37%; and (iv) eight teams hired in 2023 who were in the restriction period. (20) This adjustment reflects contribution from (i) completed enhanced and alternative capacity arrangements in place to better serve our existing customers (the costs of which have already been included in our consolidated statement of profit or loss and other comprehensive income) and (ii) further enhanced and alternative capacity arrangements (the costs of which have already been included in our consolidated statement of profit or loss and other comprehensive income) that have already been implemented but are not yet at maturity, as if they had been fully mature during the period. 47 -----

Section Title: SUMMARY HISTORICAL FINANCIAL INFORMATION AND OTHER DATA
Subsubsection Text: (1) See note (1) under “—Consolidated Statement of Profit or Loss” above, “Presentation of Financial Information” and note 1 in the Unaudited Interim Financial Statements. (2) As a result of the Retail Transaction, Total Income for the twelve months ended September 30, 2023 is presented to identify the impact of the Retail segment ceasing to be part of the Group. Retail is presented as a discontinued operation in the consolidated statement of loss and other comprehensive income in the Unaudited Interim Financial Statements of AGHL, and therefore excluded from the results presented in the above table. See “Presentation of Financial Information” and note 26 in the Unaudited Interim Financial Statements. (3) Total Income as presented above comprises the sum of commission and fees, other income, investment income and finance income. (4) Pro Forma for Completed Transactions are adjustments to include the total income of acquisitions completed on or prior to September 30, 2023 and financing transactions, in each case, as if they had occurred on October. (5) Pro Forma for Q4 2023 Completed Transactions (including AccuRisk Disposal) are adjustments to give pro forma for (i) all material acquisitions completed between October 1, 2023 and December 31, 2023, including certain cost and procurement synergies, and (ii) the disposal of AccuRisk following its sale in the fourth quarter of 2023. (6) Pro Forma for Q4 2023 Organic Growth comprises the organic growth of businesses owned by the Group as of September 30, 2023 during the three months ended December 30, 2023 on a constant perimeter basis. See “—Recent Developments—Trading _Update.”_ 48 ----- (7) Pro Forma for Cost savings and synergies (excluding AccuRisk) comprises acquisition synergies and operational efficiencies across the Group. Approximately 56% of this adjustment relates to initiatives that have already been completed, but the benefits have not been annualized for the full period. The remaining initiatives are in process and actions expected to be completed within 12 months. (8) Pro Forma for Completed Acquisitions (as of December 31, 2023) are adjustments to give pro forma for all material acquisitions completed between January 1, 2024 and February 1, 2024, including certain cost and procurement synergies. (9) Pro Forma Transactions under LOI gives pro forma effect to 36 acquisitions across Europe, Australia, Brazil, the United Kingdom and Ireland that are contractually committed or subject to a signed letter of intent and at the advanced negotiation stage as of February 1, 2024, expected to complete by the end of the second quarter of 2024. (10) This adjustment reflects the revenue contribution of producer hires, who have not yet reached maturity, assuming their production at 100% maturity, net of assumed bonuses. We estimate the expected contribution of transformational hires at maturity based on the investment case with a 25% haircut at the time of the respective addition to the business and adjusted following regular subsequent sensitivity assessments on a team-by-team basis based on performance and market conditions. In the twelve months ended September 30, 2023, we had (i) seven teams hired in 2020 at a maturity of 75%; (ii) seven teams hired in 2021 at a maturity of 58%; (iii) seven teams hired in 2022 at a maturity of 37%; and (iv) eight teams hired in 2023 who were in the restriction period. (11) This adjustment reflects contribution from (i) completed enhanced and alternative capacity arrangements in place to better serve our existing customers, (the costs of which have already been included in our consolidated statement of profit or loss and other comprehensive income) and (ii) further enhanced and alternative capacity arrangements (the costs of which have already been included in our consolidated statement of profit or loss and other comprehensive income) that have already been implemented but are not yet at maturity, as if they had been fully mature during the period. (12) Difference in total number and calculation is due to rounding. 49 -----

Section Title: SUMMARY HISTORICAL FINANCIAL INFORMATION AND OTHER DATA
Subsubsection Text: _On May 31, 2022, The Ardonagh Group Limited, the entity at which we previously reported our results, merged into the Group’s new indirect parent company, Tara Topco Limited. Following this merger, on June 1, 2022, AGHL acquired Ardonagh New Midco 3 Limited, including the Group companies that were previously owned by The Ardonagh Group Limited, and became the reporting entity for the Group. AGHL’s first reporting period included all transactions since its incorporation on December 8, 2021 to December 31, 2022. The nine-month period ended September 30, 2022, however, only includes four months of the results of operations and cash flows of the consolidated operations of AGHL due to the timing of the Tara Transactions. Accordingly, AGHL’s results during any period ended in 2022 are not comparable to any other period presented. We have accounted for the Tara Transactions using the acquisition method of accounting under IFRS 3, Business Combinations, applying purchase accounting adjustments that resulted, among others, in the recognition of intangibles (including goodwill) and deferred tax liabilities in our financial information. Due to the application of the acquisition method of accounting, the Unaudited Interim Financial Statements of AGHL are not directly comparable to the Audited Financial Statements of the Parent. See “Presentation of Financial Information—Differences in the Financial Statements of AGHL and the Parent.” To aid comparability between periods, the_ _following summary historical (i) consolidated statement of financial position as of December 31, 2022 and the consolidated statement of profit or loss and consolidated statement of cash flows for the year ended December 31, 2022 have been derived from the 2022 Audited Financial Statements of the Parent which have been prepared in accordance with IFRS and are included elsewhere in this offering memorandum, (ii) consolidated statement of profit or loss and consolidated statement of cash flows for the year ended December 31, 2021 have been derived from the 2021 Audited Financial Statements of the Parent which have been prepared in accordance with IFRS and are included elsewhere in this offering memorandum, (iii) consolidated statement of financial position as of December 31, 2021 have been derived from the comparative column in the 2022 Audited Financial Statements of the Parent, due to the restatement of trade and other receivables and retained losses, (iv) consolidated statement of financial position as of December 31, 2020 and the consolidated statement of profit or loss and consolidated statement of cash flows for the year ended December 30, 2020 have been derived from the comparative column in the 2021 Audited Financial Statements of the Parent and (v) consolidated statement of profit or loss, consolidated statement of financial position, and consolidated statement of cash flows as of and for the period ended September 30, 2022 and the nine months ended September 30, 2023 have been derived from the Unaudited Interim Financial Statements of AGHL which have been prepared in accordance with IAS 34 and are included elsewhere in this offering memorandum. In addition, in September 2023, we announced the Retail Transaction. As a result of this merger and the resulting disposal of the Retail platform, in our Unaudited Interim Financial Statements, we have presented Retail as held for sale on our consolidated statement of financial position as of September 30, 2023 and as a discontinued operation on our consolidated statement of profit or loss and other comprehensive income for the nine months period ended September 30, 2023 and the period ended September 30, 2022. We have not restated or represented any other financial information as of or for any other period for the impact of the Retail Transaction. See “Summary—Recent Developments— Retail Transaction” and note 1 to the Unaudited Interim Financial Statements. Financial information of AGHL for the twelve months ended September 30, 2023 presented in the following summary historical consolidated financial information was calculated by taking the results of operations for the three months ended December 31, 2022 and adding it to the results of operations of AGHL for the nine months ended September 30, 2023._ _The results of operations for the three months ended December 31, 2022 extracted from the accounting records of AGHL have been adjusted to present Retail as a discontinued operation for the purposes of calculating the financial information for the twelve months ended September 30, 2023 presented herein. See “Presentation of Financial Information—Comparability of the Financial Statements—The Retail Transaction.” The financial_ 38 ----- _information for the twelve months ended September 30, 2023 for AGHL is not necessarily indicative of the results that may be expected for the year ended December 31, 2023 and should not be used as the basis for or prediction of an annualized calculation. Such financial information is a non-IFRS measure. We also present certain unaudited financial information on an as adjusted basis to give effect to the Transactions and the Retail Transaction, and the application of the proceeds therefrom, including on our cash and cash equivalents and capitalization as if such transactions had occurred on September 30, 2023 and on our interest expense as if such transactions had occurred on October 1, 2022. The as adjusted financial information has been prepared for illustrative purposes only and does not represent what our debt, cash and cash equivalents and capitalization would have been had such transactions occurred on September 30, 2023, or what our interest expense would have been had such transactions occurred on October 1, 2022, nor does it purport to project our debt cash and cash equivalents and capitalization or interest expense at any future date. This as adjusted financial information has not been prepared in accordance with IFRS. Neither the assumptions underlying such adjustments nor the resulting as adjusted financial information have been audited or reviewed in accordance with any generally accepted auditing or review standards. Unless the context otherwise requires, all references herein to “we,” “our,” “us,” “Group” and “Ardonagh” with respect to any financial information in this offering memorandum are to (i) the Company and its consolidated subsidiaries for any period ended on or prior to December 31, 2022 and (ii) AGHL and its consolidated subsidiaries for the period ended September 30, 2022 and any period after December 31, 2022. This section includes financial information prepared under IFRS and certain non-IFRS financial measures. You should read the information summarized below in conjunction with the information contained in “Presentation of Financial Information,” “Use of Proceeds,” “Capitalization,” “Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations” and our Financial Statements, which are included elsewhere in this offering memorandum._ 39 -----

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks Related to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: Our business may be adversely affected by a decline in economic conditions in the United Kingdom or globally and by other market risks.
Subsubsection Text: We generate a significant portion of our revenues in the United Kingdom. As a result, we are particularly affected by economic developments and regulatory and political changes in the United Kingdom and are also affected by any similar developments across Europe or markets globally that may impact economic conditions in the United Kingdom or in other markets in which we operate. Economic difficulties, increased competition between insurers due to economic downturns and other factors may cause the premium rates on which our commissions are based to decline. In addition, any significant reduction or delay by customers in purchasing insurance or making payment of premiums could have a negative impact on our business. Factors such as declining business and consumer confidence, lower household income and consumer spending, inflation, downturns in the property market and other economic challenges could have a significant negative impact on the buying behavior of our commercial and individual customers. Insolvencies associated with continuing economic uncertainty could adversely affect our business through the loss of customers or by hindering our ability to place insurance. Due to their size, our SME business customers may be more vulnerable to any economic downturn and may be more prone to insolvency than larger commercial customers. Despite an improvement in global economic conditions in 2021 and 2022 following the sharp global economic downturn in 2020 resulting from the first waves of the COVID-19 pandemic, as of the date of this offering memorandum, the outlook for the global economy remains highly uncertain, and certain markets, including Europe, may not achieve the growth rates that they have forecasted or historically observed. Such uncertainty has been exacerbated by rising global turmoil resulting from the ongoing conflict between Russia and Ukraine. In particular, the Russia-Ukraine conflict has resulted in severe political, social and economic consequences in the countries directly involved in the conflict as well as more broadly on the European continent, as tensions between Russia, the European Union, the United States, the United Kingdom and other countries continue to increase. The ongoing war in Ukraine has also been a driver behind a surge in energy and transportation prices in 2022, which has been, and may continue to be, a key factor in driving inflationary pressures and may ultimately adversely affect general economic conditions and in turn our results of operations. Separately, in early October 2023, Hamas and Israel began an armed conflict which may potentially spread to surrounding Middle Eastern countries. The length, outcome and consequences of the Hamas-Israel military conflict remain highly unpredictable. We are unable to predict the short- or long-term implications of these conflicts, which could include but are not limited to further sanctions, uncertainty about economic and political stability, increases in inflation rates and energy prices, supply chain challenges and adverse effects on currency exchange rates and financial markets. The tensions arising from the Russian invasion of Ukraine and a potential escalation of the ongoing military confrontation between Israel and Hamas could also further increase other political tensions and hamper international trade. A new economic recession, energy and logistics issues, further political and economic instability and escalating geopolitical tensions in Europe or globally could have a material adverse effect on the demand for our products, our business and our results of operations. Supply and labor market disruptions caused by various factors, such as the COVID-19 pandemic, accommodative monetary and fiscal policy, have contributed to significant inflation in many of the 51 ----- markets in which we operate. In addition to inflation contributing to reductions or delays by customers in purchasing insurance or making payment of premiums, inflation impacts the costs to attract and retain employees and other costs to run and invest in our business. If our costs grow significantly in excess of our ability to raise revenues, our margins and results of operations may be materially and adversely impacted and we may not be able to achieve our strategic and financial objectives. Furthermore, while our fees are generally calculated as a percentage of transactions, and as such increase proportionally with inflation, inflation could cause clients to request flat fees. Any future developments in respect of the COVID-19 pandemic or any other future outbreak of another virus or other contagious disease are highly uncertain and cannot be predicted, including the scope and duration of an outbreak and actions taken by governmental authorities and other third parties in response thereto, including further quarantine measures. A resurgence in COVID-19 or any future outbreak of another virus or other contagious disease may have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations, financial condition and prospects. Any of the aforementioned factors, individually or in the aggregate, that negatively impact the UK insurance market, the UK economy more generally, or European or global economic growth and stability more generally could increase our operating costs and impose additional regulatory burdens and could also have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations and financial condition. If a significant insurer fails or withdraws from writing certain insurance coverage that we offer our clients, overall underwriting capacity in the industry could be negatively affected, which could reduce our placement of certain lines and types of insurance. An insurer with whom we place business ceasing to operate could also result in errors and omissions claims by our clients. This or any other negative economic developments in the United Kingdom could reduce customer confidence or limit the demand for our insurance products and as a result could negatively affect earnings and have a material adverse effect on our results of operations.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks Related to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: Volatility or declines in premiums, declines in commission rates or increases in applicable premium taxes may seriously undermine our business and results of operations.
Subsubsection Text: We derive most of our revenue from commission and fees for broking and underwriting services. Our commissions are generally based on insurance premiums, which are cyclical in nature and may vary widely based on market conditions. Competition, economic difficulties, changes in the insurance premium tax or other factors may change the underlying cost bases of insurance providers and as a result may cause premium rates to decline. As we cannot determine the timing and extent of premium rate changes, we may not be able to accurately forecast our commission income, including whether it will significantly decline. As insurance companies continue to outsource the issuance of insurance policies to non-affiliated agents and brokers such as ourselves, they may seek to further bring down their expenses by reducing commission rates payable to such organizations. Additionally, changes in the manner in which discount rates or other rates related to claims costs are calculated could result in the rates rising or falling and could lead insurers to adjust commission rates. A significant reduction in commissions, along with general volatility or declines in premiums, could have a significant adverse effect on our business, our generation of revenue and our financial condition. Profit commissions are less predictable than traditional commission and we are consequently less able to forecast the amount of profit commissions that we will receive. On a longer time horizon, the insurance markets might be disrupted by new technologies, “open finance” or new distribution structures, which may give rise to both risks and opportunities for us. We derive a small portion of our income from profit commissions from insurance companies. Profit commissions are typically dependent upon the profitability of the business placed with the insurer. We are less able to forecast profit commissions than premium-based commissions due to the link with variable insurance events and the inherent volatility this brings. As the profitability of our MGA division is in part dependent upon the ratio of claims made to total underwriting business placed, and as a significant amount of the underwriting business that we place insures risk in the United Kingdom, 52 ----- catastrophic events, whether natural or otherwise, may affect the amount of claims being made and therefore the profitability of the business which we placed. Insurance companies may also seek to negotiate profit sharing agreements with less favorable terms to us as a result of a decrease in the profitability of the business we place with them. Furthermore, we have a significant amount of trade accounts receivable from some of the insurance companies with which we place insurance. If those third-parties experience liquidity problems or other financial difficulties, there is a risk we could encounter delays or defaults in payments owed to us. If we are unable to correctly forecast the amount of profit commissions that we will receive for the above or any other reasons, results of operations, financial condition and cash flows could be negatively impacted.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks Related to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: We may not be able to fully realize our commercial and strategic vision.
Subsubsection Text: We may experience difficulties in maximizing collaboration across our portfolio of businesses, including taking advantage of cross-selling opportunities, and may incur higher than expected costs or may fail to realize all of the anticipated benefits of acquisition, transformation and integration activity. Achieving operational efficiencies across our portfolio may involve unforeseen difficulties and may require a disproportionate amount of our management’s attention or of our financial and other resources. While we have generated certain operational efficiencies in the past and believe we can continue to generate such efficiencies, we can provide no assurance that we will realize our goals in a timely manner or at all. Furthermore, while we believe that expected operational efficiencies from recent and planned acquisitions are based on reasonable assumptions and diligence, actual developments may differ significantly from our expectations. The failure to achieve our vision in terms of collaboration across the businesses could adversely affect our financial condition and results of operations. As part of our business strategy, we have identified and continue to identify opportunities to improve profitability by reducing costs and enhancing productivity. Some of our ongoing initiatives focus on streamlining and automating back-office processes, capitalizing on ongoing synergies and identifying cost-savings while integrating new businesses. We have, for example, retained specialist IT services provider Mphasis to deliver tailored infrastructure services across various parts of The Ardonagh Group, and are in the process of transitioning to cloud-based data centers and a cloud-based core finance platform, which we believe will contribute to ongoing operating efficiencies across our businesses. Any operational efficiencies, cost-savings or optimization of middle- and back-office functions that we expect to realize from such efforts may differ materially from our estimates. In addition, any synergies, cost-savings or productivity enhancements that we realize may be offset, in whole or in part, by reductions in income or through increases in other expenses. We can provide no assurance that these initiatives will be completed as anticipated or that the benefits we expect will be achieved on a timely basis or at all. Our calculation of Total Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA includes adjustments for cost savings expected to be realized from these initiatives and cost savings in respect of companies that we have acquired or have committed to acquire. Although we believe these estimates and assumptions are reasonable, investors should not place undue reliance upon the calculation of Total Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA given how it is calculated and the possibility that the underlying estimates and assumptions may ultimately not reflect actual results. See also “—The unaudited pro forma financial information _presented herein is inherently subject to risks and uncertainties.”_

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks Related to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: Our selective acquisition and disposal strategy exposes us to risks, including the risk that we may not be able to successfully integrate acquired businesses or that acquisitions may have liabilities that we are not aware of and may not be as profitable as we may have expected them to be, and that disposals may not have the impact on results of operations that we expected them to have.
Subsubsection Text: We intend to continue to selectively pursue further strategic and financially accretive acquisitions and disposals of businesses, assets or insurance books when and where opportunities exist and fit with our corporate culture, existing operational platform and overall strategy. We may also acquire noncontrolling stakes or enter into joint ventures with other players if we believe such transactions to be conducive to the achievement of our strategy. The success of our strategy is dependent upon our ability 53 ----- to identify suitable acquisition and disposal targets, conduct appropriate due diligence, negotiate transactions on favorable terms, obtain required authorizations and ultimately complete such transactions and integrate the acquired businesses into The Ardonagh Group or reorganize operations following a disposal. We cannot ensure that we will be able to identify attractive acquisition or disposal candidates or complete the acquisition or disposal of any identified candidates at favorable prices and upon advantageous terms. In order to pursue our acquisition strategy, we require financing and we may not have the financial resources necessary to consummate acquisitions or make the necessary investments in acquired businesses or have the ability to obtain the necessary funds on satisfactory terms. In addition to the initial cost of acquisitions, acquisition targets may require substantial capital expenditures to bring them up to our standards. General economic conditions or unfavorable global capital and credit markets could limit the number of financial institutions that are willing to provide financing to companies in our industry or affect the cost of such financing, which could affect the timing and extent to which we successfully acquire or dispose of such targets. Even if we are successful in acquiring target businesses, we may experience difficulties in integrating targets into our business, incur higher than expected costs or fail to realize the anticipated benefits or synergies. Attempting to integrate acquired companies may involve unforeseen difficulties and may require a disproportionate amount of our management’s attention or of our financial and other resources. In addition, the process of integrating acquisitions may also be disruptive to our operations, as a result of, among other things, unforeseen legal, regulatory, contractual (including, for instance, representations and warranties, indemnities, put and call options) and other issues, difficulties in realizing operating synergies, difficulties in integrating diverse business cultures which may be incompatible, problems in integrating IT or other systems between the businesses, disagreements with joint venture partners or minority shareholders or a failure to maintain the quality of services that we have historically provided. Such transactions may also disrupt our relationships with current and new employees, customers, capacity partners and industry colleagues. Our acquisitions may also subject us to more expansive or new regulatory frameworks, new customer segments with different habits than we have catered to and/or new competitive dynamics which could hinder our growth and frustrate the realization of our acquisition objectives. Although we always conduct due diligence investigations prior to each acquisition, we can provide no assurance that we will discover all operational deficiencies or material liabilities of an acquired business for which we may be responsible as a successor owner or operator and actual performance and developments may differ significantly from our expectations or forecasts. Our assessments of acquisition targets may prove to be incorrect, particularly our expectations with respect to growth, financial margins, cash flows and cost and revenue synergies. Additionally, acquisitions may require the approval of governmental or regulatory authorities which can block, impose conditions on or delay the acquisition process, resulting in a failure on our part to proceed with announced transactions on a timely basis or at all, thus hampering our opportunities for growth. We believe that our corporate culture, including our management philosophy, has been a critical component to our success and that our culture creates an environment that drives and perpetuates our overall business strategy. We have invested substantial time and resources in building our team and we expect to continue to hire as we expand in both the United Kingdom and internationally. As we grow and mature and grow internationally, we may find it difficult to maintain our corporate culture. Any failure to preserve our culture could negatively affect our future success, including our ability to recruit and retain personnel and effectively focus on and pursue our business strategy. Any acquisition or other strategic transaction we may undertake in the future could result in the incurrence of debt and contingent liabilities, an increase in interest expenses and amortisation expenses related to goodwill or other intangible assets or in the use by us of available cash on hand to finance any such acquisitions. In identifying acquisition targets we may incorrectly assess the market position, 54 ----- growth prospects or underwriting performance of the target business, or whether the business’ geographic, distribution channel or product mix fits within our existing operations. We may incorrectly assess the commission and fee income streams of the target business, as well as the potential to increase such streams following the acquisition, upon which the price paid for acquisitions is primarily based. Although we conduct due diligence with respect to the business and operations of acquired businesses, we may fail to identify all material facts concerning these businesses. Unanticipated events or liabilities relating to these businesses could have a material adverse effect on our results of operations, financial condition and cash flow. Such failures to achieve our acquisition target performance goals and could in turn have material adverse effects on our business, financial condition and results of operations. See also “The Retail Transaction may be delayed or may not proceed to completion.”

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks Related to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: The Retail Transaction may be delayed or may not proceed to completion.
Subsubsection Text: The Retail Transaction is subject to, and can only occur, upon the satisfaction or (where applicable) waiver of certain conditions under the Retail SPA including, without limitation, the receipt of regulatory approvals (including the approval of the Retail Transaction by the FCA under section 178 FSMA) and the CMA determining not to refer the Retail Transaction to Phase 2 (whether unconditionally or conditional on the CMA acceptance of undertakings in lieu (“UILs”) or, in the event that a reference to Phase 2 is made, concluding either that the Retail Transaction may not be expected to result in a substantial lessening of competition (“SLC”) within any market in the UK or that the CMA accepts final undertakings which it decides remedy that SLC, which are outside of our control. While the parties to the Retail SPA have obligations in relation to the satisfaction of the conditions under the Retail SPA, there can be no assurance that all of the conditions will be satisfied or waived (as applicable) by the Retail SPA Long Stop Date unless extended. The Retail SPA contains covenants and agreements applicable to the Retail Group prior to completion of the Retail Transaction. Any failure on the part of the Retail Seller to comply with any of its obligations under the Retail SPA could result in the completion of the Retail Transaction being delayed or not taking place at all. Moreover, while the Retail Purchaser has demonstrated it has funds available to finance the cash consideration under the Retail SPA, in the event that the Retail Purchaser does not have sufficient funding to satisfy the cash consideration at completion, completion of the Retail Transaction may not proceed even if all conditions under the Retail SPA have been satisfied or waived and there can be no assurance that we would be able to recover any losses as a result thereof. Therefore, Retail Transaction may be delayed or may not complete at all. If the Retail Transaction does not proceed to completion, we will not receive the expected proceeds from the Retail Transaction and there is no guarantee that we would be able to enter into any other transaction on favorable terms or at all. Any failure to complete the Retail Transaction may negatively impact the perceived value of the Retail Business and could increase the risk that the value of the Retail Business may decrease over time if the Group is not able to invest the resources necessary to drive and to deliver the growth potential of the Retail Business. In addition, if the Retail Transaction does not proceed to completion, our ratio of as adjusted total net debt to Total Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA would be 5.8x, as calculated by adjusting as adjusted total net debt to remove the net proceeds from the Retail Transaction, including Retail Total EBITDA, and adding Lease Liabilities associated with the Retail Divestiture. We have also incurred significant costs in connection with the Retail Transaction that we will be responsible for paying irrespective of whether the Retail Transaction completes.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks Related to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: The entry into new geographies and markets exposes us to risks.
Subsubsection Text: Our expansion and growth may, from time to time, lead us to start operating in geographies or markets where we currently have little or no presence to increase the size and geographic scope of our operations or to pursue growth and/or other opportunities. We have in recent years strengthened our international operations and global reach and have entered into new markets such as Australia, the Netherlands, Portugal, Brazil, Greece, and Switzerland. We have a robust M&A pipeline (85% of which consists of 55 ----- targets outside of the United Kingdom), and we continue to explore larger transaction opportunities globally with a strong focus on market-leading platforms. Our expansion may introduce dependencies on new market conditions in new geographical locations. A broader geographical distribution of our business portfolio may also result in additional costs in connection with the management of our businesses and reduce the benefits of economies of scale. The occurrence of any of the foregoing factors may have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations. Our entry into new geographies and markets may entail numerous risks, including: - changes in laws and regulations with a significant impact on our business, our products and our operations; - competition with established competitors in new markets, who may have greater knowledge of those markets and/or resources to expend in those markets than we do; - difficulties in understanding and adapting to local cultural norms, including, but not limited to, consumption patterns, seasonal effects, consumer trends and preferences, as well seasonal effects; - diversion of management’s attention and difficulties in staffing and managing global operations and the increased travel, infrastructure, and legal compliance costs; - certain other risks involved in entering markets in which we have limited or no prior experience; and - reputational and other risks regarding our ability to enter new geographies or markets successfully, including obtaining financing which could result in an increase in our indebtedness. We have also recently entered the reinsurance market. In 2021, we launched Inver Re, a new reinsurance broker. As a new player in the reinsurance market, we may face strong competition from established players. In addition, the lack of strong barriers to entry into the reinsurance business means that we may compete with new companies that may be formed to enter the insurance and reinsurance markets. We may also experience increased competition as a result of the consolidation in the reinsurance industry. Competition in the types of reinsurance that we underwrite is based on many factors, including the perceived and relative financial strength, pricing and other terms and conditions, services provided, ratings assigned by independent rating agencies, speed of claims payment, geographic scope of business, reputation and experience in the lines of business to be written. If competitive pressures reduce our prices, we would expect to write less business. In addition, competition for customers would become more intense and we could incur additional expenses relating to customer acquisition and retention, further reducing our operating margins. Furthermore, insurance-linked securities, derivatives and other non-traditional risk transfer mechanisms and alternative vehicles are being developed and offered by other parties, which could impact the demand for traditional insurance or reinsurance. A number of new, proposed or potential industry or legislative developments could further increase competition in the reinsurance industry. New competition from these developments could cause the demand for reinsurance to fall or the expense of customer acquisition and retention to increase, either of which could have a material adverse effect on our growth and profitability. As a result of new and alternative capital inflows into the industry and cedants retaining more business, there is an excess supply of reinsurance capital which is also driving pricing lower and putting pressure on terms and conditions. See also “—Competition in our industry is intense, and if we are unable to compete effectively, our _business may be adversely affected.”_ 56 ----- Any failure to successfully enter new geographies or markets could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations. In addition, there can be no assurance that we will be able to identify suitable geographies or markets.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks Related to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: The loss of key personnel could negatively affect our financial results and impair our ability to implement our business strategy.
Subsubsection Text: Our success substantially depends on our ability to attract and retain key members of our senior management team and key leaders throughout our platforms. If we were to lose one or more of these key employees, we may not be able to replace them on a timely basis with other professionals capable of making comparable contributions to the business, and our ability to successfully implement our business plan and the value of the business could be adversely affected. We maintain what we believe to be a comprehensive range of staff retention and incentive mechanisms, but we can provide no assurances that we will not lose one or more key members of the senior management team or key leaders in any of our platforms.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks Related to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: Disruption to our infrastructure, interruption or loss of our information systems, including our data integrity or other digital distribution channels or a failure to maintain secure information systems could have a material adverse effect on our business.
Subsubsection Text: Our success depends, in part, on our ability to develop and implement technology solutions that anticipate and keep pace with changes in industry information technology (“IT”) platforms, industry standards, client preferences and internal control standards, and our capacity to service our customers depends in part on storing, retrieving, processing and managing information. We may not be successful in anticipating or responding to these developments on a timely and cost-effective basis. We can provide no assurance that our IT infrastructure and software systems, or the IT infrastructure of our third-party service providers will not be disrupted or interrupted. An interruption to or loss of our information processing capabilities through the loss of stored data, a failure of our computer equipment or software or telecommunications systems or some other technology disruption could have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations and financial condition. Disruptions may include terrorist activities, disease pandemics, war or military activity, or disruption to the electrical, communications or other services used by our company, our employees or third parties with whom we conduct business. While we have developed a disaster recovery plan for our IT services as well as our cloud-based IT data center, there can be no assurance that in the event of a disaster our systems will be fully effective. We rely on (“PCWs”) to distribute certain of our products and are as such exposed to interruptions to the processing systems in the services provided by PCWs. We are also dependent on certain third parties to enable us to complete transactions relating to the pricing and placement of insurance products. A significant failure of any of our platforms or any of these third parties could have a negative impact on our ability to service our customer and complete transactions, could have a material adverse impact on our financial control frameworks and our ability to carry out our internal financial processes. Our computer systems store information about our customers, some of which is sensitive personal data. Database privacy, identity theft and related computer and internet issues are matters of growing public concern and are subject to changes in rules and regulations. Any failure to adhere to or successfully implement processes in response to changing regulatory requirements in this area could result in legal liability or harm to our reputation. Unauthorized data disclosure could occur through cyber security breaches, as a result of human error, external hacking, malware infection, malicious or accidental user activity, internal security breaches and physical security breaches, among others, and we are exposed to increased risk of data compromise when our employees work from home due to such employees being outside the office environment and are unable to be supervised in person. Some of our businesses have in the past had weak cyber security controls. In particular, with the growing incidence of hacking and other forms of cyberattacks, our IT systems and networks have been, and may in the future be, subject to malicious attacks, including cyber-attacks or the deliberate, accidental or negligent insertion 57 ----- of software viruses or other malicious code, any of which may disrupt or interrupt their normal operation, prevent access to data, cause data loss or corruption, result in the unauthorized distribution of data, including customer or employee data, damage or destroy some or all of our systems or cause unexpected shutdowns. We may be from time to time subject to, and our business may be vulnerable to, cybercrime attacks, such as attempts to gain unauthorized access to, or deliberately breach, our IT systems and networks in order, for example, to manipulate our proprietary business data or customer information, theft of data, and even incidents that do not amount to a breach could result in adverse regulatory and financial consequences including breaches of the Data Protection Act 2018 and the General Data Protection Regulation (the “GDPR”), as well as further regulatory intervention, and could harm our reputation. Such attacks are technologically sophisticated and may be difficult or impossible to detect and defend against. Despite the security measures that we have implemented to prevent unauthorized access to information stored in our database and to comply with relevant data protection regulations, our technology may fail to adequately protect the private information we maintain in our databases from theft or inadvertent leakage. In addition, the transition of our employees to working from home increases data compromise risk due to such employees being outside the office environment and are unable to be supervised in-person. See “—Regulation or other requirements in the areas of privacy, information security and data protection _could increase our costs and affect or limit how we collect and/or use personal information and our business opportunities.”_ If unauthorized parties do gain access to our networks or databases, they may be able to steal, publish, delete or modify private and sensitive third-party information, and misuse could include committing fraud and identity theft. In such circumstances, we may be held liable to our clients or may be subject to regulatory actions for breaching privacy rules. In addition, our reputation may be harmed. This, in turn, could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations. Furthermore, the failure of any of the PCWs that distribute our products or other third-party IT solutions that support distribution of our products and services to maintain secure information systems could result in customers associating our products or brands with such failures, which could have a negative impact on our reputation and brand. Any resultant litigation, civil penalties, government investigations or adverse publicity could cause us to incur expenses to resolve these issues, could deter intermediaries and customers from dealing with us or could damage our reputation more broadly.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks Related to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: We continue to implement IT initiatives in order to realize internal efficiencies and deliver scale advantages across our business, often in reliance on third-parties. Any adverse challenges to our implementation of new technologies, systems or processes could have a material adverse effect on our business.
Subsubsection Text: Although we have been successful in realizing benefits from our IT initiatives, we can provide no assurance that we will realize all of the benefits of our various IT initiatives, including increasing costsavings or achieving synergies between our various divisions. For example, we have partnered with Mphasis to deliver tailored infrastructure service across various parts of The Ardonagh Group while leveraging Microsoft’s Azure cloud platform across several applications. Any or all of the composite segments of the program may be delayed, be more expensive than we may have expected or may not result in the same IT efficiencies, synergies or costs savings for some offices, product markets, or regions as for others, if at all. The installation of certain technologies or systems may prove difficult for our staff to fully utilize such that the expected benefits are not fully realized, if realized at all. Implementation of any IT initiatives may distract management’s attention from other aspects of the business, which could have a material adverse effect on our results of operations and financial condition. In addition, we have outsourced certain financial and other functions to third-party service providers, including Microsoft and Mphasis, in an effort to maximize operating efficiencies. Inadequate 58 ----- management or training of any of these providers could lead to an inability to effectively manage and execute the applicable processes. We are at risk of data security breaches, losing visibility and control of the applicable processes and potential language barriers. Furthermore, the IT platforms for our premium financing are provided by various premium credit providers, including third parties, and thus we have no control and can provide no assurances with respect to risk of data breaches on this platform. See “—Regulation or other requirements in the areas of privacy, information security and data _protection could increase our costs and affect or limit how we collect and/or use personal information and our business opportunities.” If we do not effectively manage outsourcing relationships, if third-_ party providers do not perform efficiently or in a timely manner or if we experience problems with transitioning work to a third-party provider, we may experience disruptions in transaction processing or IT services. Furthermore, to the extent that any of the third-party service provider agreements are determined not to benefit us in their current form, we may not be able to renegotiate or rescind any or all of the agreements. If any of the above risks were to materialize, it could negatively impact our business processes, reputation and customers. The various technologies, systems, processes and third-party relationships that comprise our IT initiatives are intended to operate in a complementary manner, connecting our offices, standardizing our systems and processes and capitalizing on scale advantages across our business. There is a risk that if any one or more individual IT initiatives proves difficult to implement, does not become fully integrated or does not achieve all expected results, the full integration and expected performance of other specific IT initiatives, as well as the impact of the IT initiatives taken as a whole, may be adversely affected. See also “—Disruption to our infrastructure, interruption or loss of our information systems, _including our data integrity, a failure of PCWs or other digital distribution channels or a failure to maintain secure information systems could have a material adverse effect on our business.”_ The success of our business depends in large part on our ability to achieve operational efficiency which we believe our IT initiatives support, but any of the abovementioned obstacles to the successful implementation of our IT initiatives, or any other challenges to the improvement and integration of our IT systems across our IT platforms and companies, may have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations and financial condition.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks Related to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: We depend on relationships with third-party brokers, third-party MGAs and other capacity and product providers.
Subsubsection Text: Our success depends in part on the quality of services provided by, and our relationships with, the thirdparty brokers (including insurance brokers and mortgage brokers), third-party MGAs and insurers through which we distribute a portion of our insurance products. Our relationships with these trading partners are significant factors relating to our success. If a carrier partner relationship terminates or there is loss of strategic support or alignment, we may be unable to transition to a new relationship without some short-term disruption, which could have a degree of financial impact. If carriers were to experience liquidity problems or other financial (such as rating agency downgrades) or operational difficulties, we could encounter business disruptions as a result, and our results of operations may suffer. A failure to maintain our existing relationships with carriers, or a failure to build relationships with new entrants to the market, could have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations and financial condition. Any of the aforementioned, or any other deterioration in our relationships with third-party brokers or mortgage intermediaries could have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations and financial condition.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
