Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Overview
Subsubsection Text: We are a highly diversified, leading independent insurance broker based in the United Kingdom (“UK”) operating at scale across numerous segments of the non-life insurance market in the UK and internationally. We provide a full range of non-life insurance products and related services across commercial, personal and wholesale insurance. As an insurance distribution intermediary, our business primarily consists of working with insurers to design, price, and administer insurance-related products and services, and as such, we do not assume any underwriting or principal risk. From our formation in 2017 to the end of 2023, we have increased our revenue (excluding Retail) by over three times and our Adjusted EBITDA (excluding Retail) by over five times, due to consistent strong organic growth and our proven acquisition strategy. The foundations laid over the past five years have provided a platform for further growth, which has positioned us, pro forma for all material acquisitions and disposals completed or committed as of November 2, 2023, as a top 10 independent insurance broker and a top 20 insurance broker globally according to Reinsurance News. In September 2023, we announced the merger and sale of our Retail Business to Markerstudy in a transaction valuing the business at £1.2 billion. See “Summary—Recent Developments—Retail Transaction.” For the twelve months ended September 30, 2023 and excluding Retail, we generated GWP of £12 billion, commissions and fees of £1.2 billion, Total Pro Forma Income of £1.6 billion, organic growth of 11.6%, Total Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA of £555.8 million and Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA margin of 33%. We offer a broad range of non-life insurance products in multiple geographies, ranging from higher value and lower volume bespoke corporate insurance products placed in the London Market, to SMB business insurance policies. Each aspect of our business is highly diversified with limited concentration or dependence on any single product, channel, carrier, income producer, or supplier. We combine this diversified operating model with a highly collaborative culture across the Group to provide our clients, carriers, and employees with a high-quality product and service offering. We serve a wide range of clients that include large MNCs, SMEs, individual consumers, and other third-party brokers and MGAs. We distribute our insurance products across multiple channels, including through a network of over 120 local offices in the United Kingdom and more than 150 offices worldwide, and online. Our global network provides the basis for deep, embedded local relationships and “trusted advisor” status with clients and benefits from long-standing trusted insurer partner relationships. We also maintain regional hubs to support our businesses through shared resources and expertise.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Significant Factors Affecting Results of Operations
Subsubsection Text: We have a long-term track record and well-established process for identifying, executing, and integrating highly accretive acquisitions across many geographies. We have completed or entered into acquisition agreements for more than 150 acquisitions since our establishment in 2017, which represents an enterprise value of over £3.2 billion with a year-to-date average “add-on” enterprise value multiple of 6.6 times and a “platform” enterprise value multiple of 9.6 times. Acquisitions completed during the fourth quarter of 2023 (including the impact of the AccuRisk disposal) contributed Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA of £13.6 million for the twelve months ended September 30, 2023. We also have further 36 acquisitions that are contractually committed or under signed letter of intent as of February 1, 2024, which would contribute an additional £32.2 million of Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA. Our pipeline includes targets on multiple continents. We intend to continue to pursue further strategic and financially accretive acquisitions of businesses, assets or insurance books when opportunities exist and fit with our corporate culture and overall strategy. Our major acquisitions since mid-2020 include, among others: - Arachas, a commercial insurance broker in Ireland in 2020; - Bravo, which comprises Broker Network and Compass, two established network service providers to regional insurance brokers and Ethos Broking, a highly active acquisition platform focused on the UK regional insurance market, in 2020; - Resilium Pty Limited, the founding business of our Australian platform, in February 2021; - Hemsley Wynne Furlong LLP, a specialist M&A warranty and indemnity insurance broker and advisor, in March 2021; - Usay Group Limited, one of the largest consumer personal medical insurance and protection insurance brokers in the UK, in September 2021; - the Hooper Dolan companies, a client-focused general insurance broker with offices across Ireland, in October 2021; - the insurance operations of BGC Partners Inc., a leading global brokerage and financial technology company, in November 2021; - the Léons Group, a family-owned independent insurance brokerage and consultancy firm based in the Netherlands, in October 2022; - Glennon Insurances, a leading provider of insurance solutions in Ireland, in December 2022; - the MDS Group, an insurance broker and risk management advisor primarily based in Portugal and Brazil, with offices in Angola, Mozambique, Spain, Switzerland and Malta, in December 2022; - Envest PTY Limited, an Australian insurance investment and distribution group, in February 2023; - the Oxford Insurance Group, a Lloyd’s broker with further operations in Switzerland, Liechtenstein and Dubai, in March 2023; - the SRS Group, an Athens-based group whose businesses include an independent wholesale reinsurance broker and a managing general agencies (“MGA”) platform, in June 2023; 97 ----- - Klap Verzekeringsmakelaar, a Dutch specialist commercial lines insurance broker, in June 2023; - Classicus, a high-net-worth broker headquartered in the Netherlands, in August 2023; and - ASSEPRO, one of the largest independent commercial brokers for small and medium-sized enterprises in Switzerland, with additional operations in Austria and Liechtenstein, in November 2023. We also enter into disposals and other similar transactions from time to time. In September 2023, we announced the merger and disposal of the Retail platform with the Markerstudy Group, with our shareholders maintaining a minority stake in the Merged Business. The transaction values Atlanta at £1.2 billion. The Retail Transaction is subject to customary closing conditions and regulatory approvals. As a result of this merger and the resulting disposal of the Retail platform, we have presented Retail as held for sale on our consolidated statement of financial position as of September 30, 2023 and as a discontinued operation on our consolidated statement of profit or loss and other comprehensive income for the nine months period ended September 30, 2023 and the period ended September 30, 2022. See “Summary—Recent Developments—Retail Transaction.” In addition, on October 30, 2023, we agreed to sell the subsidiaries of Alpha Investment Holdings Limited, including the AccuRisk Solutions LLC group of entities, to Ryan Specialty. This transaction is subject to customary closing conditions and regulatory approval. The results of each of these acquisitions and disposals are included or excluded, as applicable, in the Financial Statements from the date the relevant transaction was completed. See “—Significant Factors _Affecting Comparability Between Periods—Historic Acquisitions and Disposals” and note 11 to the_ Unaudited Interim Financial Statements. As a general matter, following an acquisition of a business or group of assets, our results of operations are impacted by the results of the newly acquired business or operations, the purchase accounting for the acquisition, any debt incurred to acquire the business or operations and expenditures made to integrate the newly acquired business or operations. See also “—Business Transformation and _Synergies” below. We incur certain costs and expenses in connection with any potential or completed_ acquisition. We have adjusted for certain acquisition-related costs in our Adjusted EBITDA. See “Summary—Summary Historical Financial Information and Other Data—Other Consolidated _Financial and Pro Forma Data.”_

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Significant Factors Affecting Results of Operations
Subsubsection Text: The general insurance cycle is an insurance market phenomenon that is driven by supply of and demand for insurance and can be particularly pronounced in reinsurance and industrial lines insurance. The insurance market cycle is defined as “softening” and “hardening.” “Soft” periods are characterized by falling or stagnant premium rates and are driven normally by excessive supply of capital from insurance companies and other market participants competing for available business. Soft markets on average result in low profitability for the insurers and as a result lower commissions for brokers. “Hard” periods can be precipitated by catastrophes, such as natural disasters, or similar significant losses, for example, severe credit market losses, that result in insurers’ capital becoming depleted or some insurers no longer being able to participate in the market. The lack of capital and decreased competition drives up premium rates, thereby the potential for greater profitability for the remaining insurers. Additionally, catastrophes or similar significant losses may also precipitate increased customer demand for insurance policies, driving demand for capital and further hardening the market.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Significant Factors Affecting Results of Operations
Subsubsection Text: As an insurance intermediary, we derive our revenue primarily from commission and fees. Our commission income is generally based on insurance premiums and negotiated commission rates, and 98 ----- fees are paid for claims administration or other individual services based on negotiated amounts. We derive a small portion of our commission income from profit commission agreements with our insurers. Profit commissions are typically dependent upon the underwriting profitability of the business placed with the insurer, which is a function of premiums earned less commission paid, claims costs, insurer expenses and the target financial returns for the insurer. We are less able to forecast profit commissions than premium based commissions due to the link with variable insurance events and the inherent volatility this brings. See “Risk Factors—Risks Related to Our Business and Industry— _Volatility or _declines in premiums, declines in commission rates or increases in applicable premium taxes may seriously undermine our business and results of operations.” Furthermore, catastrophic events, whether_ natural or otherwise, can have a significant effect on the number and value of claims being made, and therefore a significant effect on the profitability of the business we place with the insurance company. Changes in profit commissions are largely attributable to economic and market conditions that are outside of our control and that affect premium prices and lead to increases or decreases in overall claims. We also offer customers access to premium finance providers for a fee. A premium finance provider covers the upfront costs of insurance premiums and bills the individual or company in installments to recover the insurance premium cost.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Significant Factors Affecting Results of Operations
Subsubsection Text: We have invested significantly, and continue to invest, in recruiting talent to the insurance broking and health insurance businesses within our Global P&C platform. In our Specialty Broking platform, we focus on retaining and attracting income producers and optimizing our panel of products and capacity providers. Part of our strategy is to drive our existing hires to maturity and hire exceptional individuals who can swiftly add value to our Group. We added Adjusted EBITDA of approximately £30 million for the twelve months ended September 30, 2023 from 29 new producer teams hired since 2020. Organic growth has accelerated since 2021 in part by the maturing income profile of new hires in prior periods. Our investments in new hires often result in losses in the early years while they build up our client base. Costs associated with transformational hires include recruitment costs, sign-on bonuses, cost of retention, and salary costs while hires are under restrictive non-compete covenants or are impacted by insurer capacity restrictions. Teams typically mature to their full profitability potential approximately three years after the expiry of capacity or covenant restrictions. Seven teams hired in 2020 were at 75% maturity as of September 30, 2023, seven teams hired in 2021 were at 58% maturity as of September 30, 2023 and seven teams hired in 2022 were at 37% maturity as of September 30, 2023. In addition, we hired six teams that started trading in 2023. As a result, we expect to realize additional Adjusted EBITDA as a result of these hires over the next three years. We have also focused on expansion into new geographies and into new products and niches. Since 2020, we have expanded our addressable markets in new synergistic geographies through acquisitions such as the MDS Group in Brazil, Klap Verzekeringsmakelaar and the Léons Group in the Netherlands and ASSEPRO in Switzerland and Austria. In addition, in 2021, we launched Inver Re, a new reinsurance broker with ambitions to harness our scale, resources and reach to offer a credible alternative to global brokers and become our industry’s independent reinsurance broker of choice.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Significant Factors Affecting Results of Operations
Subsubsection Text: We have a strong track record of delivering cost down plans and synergies. Since our establishment, we have delivered a transformational improvement in quality of earnings, primarily as a result of significant investments towards transformative cost-savings programs and synergy initiatives in our business to create a scalable and efficient platform that is conducive to future growth, resulting in approximately £150 million of realized cost-savings since the start of 2018 and approximately £110 million since the start of 2020. We have also identified approximately £15.8 million of near-term cost savings that we expect can be delivered within the next 12 months, which are described in the table below: 99 ----- |Col1|Overview|Adjusted EBITDA Benefit| |---|---|---| |Global P&C|UK Advisory • Benefits resulting from a target operating model implementation project, primarily as a result of reduction in headcount through efficiency gains from optimizing policy administration systems • IT transaction as a result of improving the office network, removing legacy applications and outsourcing • Onshoring finance project expected to deliver benefits from process efficiencies and automation|£3.2 million| ||International Advisory • Synergies as a result of a “hub-and-spoke” model (by integrating bolt-on businesses to the main platform which acts as the hub, and from which all functions are centralized and distributed to the bolt- on businesses) and integrating further acquisitions into our existing platforms|£3.9 million| |Specialty Broking|• Technology-led transformation of middle- and back-office functions • Cost synergies identified with the acquisition of Corant Global, including harmonization of reward structures, footprint consolidation and back-office optimization, and the acquisition of the Oxford Insurance Group|£8.2 million| |Corporate|• Back-office optimization|£0.5 million| |Total||£15.8 million|

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Significant Factors Affecting Results of Operations
Subsubsection Text: Our businesses are authorized and regulated by the FCA and firms in our industry must maintain regulatory authorization. Our insurance intermediary activities must comply with FCA rules and guidelines that impose, among other things, a high-level standard on the establishment and maintenance of proper systems and controls and minimum threshold conditions that must be satisfied for an insurance broking firm to remain authorized as well as rules on the conduct of business and treating customers fairly (the “FCA Rules”). The FCA Rules impose minimum “threshold conditions” that must be satisfied as well as robust standards for the establishment and maintenance of proper systems and controls, notably for the conduct of business and the fair treatment of customers. We incur costs to comply with the changing regulatory landscape. The FCA Rules also impose upon us certain minimum capital and liquidity requirements. See “Risk Factors—Risk Factors Related to Our Business and _Industry—If we fail to comply with regulatory requirements or guidelines, we may not be able to_ 100 ----- _conduct business or may be subject to sanctions or substantial fines that may have a material adverse effect on our reputation, results of operations and financial condition.”_

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Significant Factors Affecting Results of Operations
Subsubsection Text: While the majority of our business is conducted in the United Kingdom, we have an increasing number of global operations, which exposes us to fluctuations in currency exchange rates. A significant amount of our income from our Specialty Broking and Global P&C: International Advisory specialty is denominated in U.S. dollars and euros, although Specialty segment costs are incurred substantially in pound sterling. We enter into forward contracts to mitigate the exposure resulting from USD revenue arising on the placement of certain premiums denominated in USD. If we are unable to hedge our foreign currency revenues or otherwise match brokerage and fees received in foreign currencies with costs paid in the same currency, results of operations may be affected by currency exchange rate fluctuations. As a result of the Transactions, we expect to have a significantly improved natural hedging profile, as the proportionate mix of currencies within the anticipated capital structure (Australian dollar, euro and U.S. dollar) much more closely match the currencies in which operational cash flow is generated. Furthermore, as we present our consolidated financial statements in pound sterling, we are required to translate the assets, liabilities, income and expenses of all operations that use a functional currency other than pound sterling, such as U.S. dollars. We translate into pound sterling at then-applicable exchange rates, exposing us to translation risk (i.e., the risk that exchange rates will impact the value of our income, assets, liabilities and expenses reported in pound sterling even if the value has not changed in U.S. dollars) should the pound sterling strengthen against the U.S. dollar. Furthermore, our international expansion strategy exposes us to additional translation risk. Currency translations could significantly affect the comparability of our results between financial periods and could result in significant changes to the carrying value of assets, liabilities and shareholders’ equity.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Significant Factors Affecting Results of Operations
Subsubsection Text: We experience some seasonality in the volumes of insurance policies we place and, consequently, in our commission and fees. Like many of our competitors, we have historically transacted less business from November to February than in other months. Accordingly, commission and fees for the first and fourth quarter tend to be slightly lower than the second and third quarter. In addition, our use of cash is seasonal. For example, we pay certain bonuses to employees (in March of each year) and certain amounts to tax authorities (in April of each year), resulting in higher cash uses during such periods. In addition, we currently have two payment dates for our main debt interest payments in January 2024 and July 2024. A portion of the Retail platform is characterized by highly seasonal revenue as a consequence of traditional policy renewal patterns across the various lines of business. For example, our Carole Nash business experiences seasonality resulting from fewer motorbikes being sold during the winter months and as a consequence fewer motorbike insurance policies are placed during the same period. Following the completion of the Retail Transaction, we expect to reduce some of the impact of seasonality on our business.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Significant Factors Affecting Results of Operations
Subsubsection Text: Our business and results of operations have been affected by certain key factors in the past and we expect these key factors to affect our business in the future. Each of these additional factors is discussed in more detail below. 96 -----

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Significant Factors Affecting Comparability Between Periods
Subsubsection Text: We have a long-term track record and well-established process for identifying, executing, and integrating highly accretive acquisitions across many geographies. We have completed or entered into acquisition agreements for more than 150 acquisitions since our establishment in 2017. We have also completed two disposals during the periods under review, and have entered into agreements for a further two disposals. We also completed 25 acquisitions in 2022, and have completed or executed share 101 ----- purchase agreements or letters of intent for 73 acquisitions since January 1, 2023. See “—Significant _Factors Affecting Results of Operations—Acquisitions and Disposals” for a description of the_ acquisitions and disposals completed during the periods under review. We intend to continue to pursue further strategic and financially accretive acquisitions of businesses, assets or insurance books when and where opportunities exist and fit with our corporate culture and overall strategy. As a result, our financial statements may not be fully comparable from period to period. As a general matter, following an acquisition of a business or group of assets, our results of operations are impacted by the results of the newly acquired business or operations, the purchase accounting for the acquisition, any debt incurred to acquire the business or operations and expenditures made to integrate the newly acquired business or operations which also affects the comparability of our results with the previous period. In addition to increasing our income through increasing our commission and fees, we incur certain costs and expenses in connection with any potential or completed acquisition. See also “Risk Factors—Risks Related to Our Business and Industry—Our selective acquisition and _disposal strategy exposes us to risks, including the risk that we may not be able to successfully integrate acquired businesses or that acquisitions may have liabilities that we are not aware of and may not be as profitable as we may have expected them to be and that disposals may not have the impact on results of operations that we expected them to have.” The Retail Transaction_ In September 2023, we announced the merger and disposal of the Retail platform with the Markerstudy Group, with our shareholders maintaining a stake in the combined business. The transaction values Atlanta at £1.2 billion. The Retail Transaction is subject to customary closing conditions and regulatory approvals. As a result of this merger and the resulting disposal of the Retail platform, in our Unaudited Interim Financial Statements we have presented Retail as held for sale on our consolidated statement of financial position as of September 30, 2023 and as a discontinued operation on our consolidated statement of profit or loss and other comprehensive income for the nine months period ended September 30, 2023 and the period ended September 30, 2022. See “Summary—Recent Developments—Retail _Transaction.”_

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Significant Factors Affecting Comparability Between Periods
Subsubsection Text: _Debt transactions_ Our future results of operations, and in particular our interest expense, may be affected as a result of the refinancing of our Existing Notes and Existing Senior Secured Credit Facilities in connection with the Transactions. The Notes and the New Term Facilities, and potentially amounts drawn under our Revolving Credit Facility and CAR Facility, will be denominated in currencies other than pounds sterling. This will also affect our financial results to the extent these currencies fluctuate against the pound sterling. However, as a result of the Transactions, we expect to have a significantly improved natural hedging profile, as the proportionate mix of currencies within the anticipated capital structure much more closely match the currencies in which operational cash flow is generated. The servicing of our indebtedness will impact, among other things, our cash flows and our cash balances. In addition, as the New Term Facilities will bear interest at a floating rate, we will continue to face interest rates risk going forward. See “Risks Factors—Risks Related to Our Financial Profile— _The New Senior Secured _Credit Facilities will bear interest at floating rates that could rise significantly, increasing our interest cost and reducing cash flow.” While we currently do not envisage entering into any transactions to_ hedge any potential exposure to changes in foreign exchange rates in respect of the Transaction, we expect to enter into interest rate hedging arrangements and will have the option to enter into foreign exchange derivative transactions under the terms of the Indenture. 102 ----- _Equity transactions_ In December 2021, we announced a significant new equity investment whereby our two anchor investors, Madison Dearborn Partners and HPS Investment Partners, agreed to invest capital through new funds as part of the equity investment of over $1 billion. These investments, made through certain co-investments by large global institutions through accounts managed by Madison Dearborn Partners and HPS Investment Partners, increased our Sponsor’s shareholdings and funded minority buy-outs. Following completion of the Tara Transactions, the corporate structure of the Group changed. On May 31, 2022, The Ardonagh Group Limited, the entity at which we previously reported our results, merged into the Group’s new indirect parent company, Tara Topco Limited. Following this merger, on June 1, 2022, AGHL acquired Ardonagh New Midco 3 Limited, including the Group companies that were previously owned by The Ardonagh Group Limited, and became the reporting entity for the Group. AGHL’s first reporting period included all transactions since its incorporation on December 8, 2021 to December 31, 2022. The period ended September 30, 2022, however, only includes four months of the results of operations and cash flows of the consolidated operations of AGHL due to the timing of the Tara Transactions. Accordingly, AGHL’s results during any period ended in 2022 are not comparable to any other period presented. See “Presentation of Financial Information.”

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Significant Factors Affecting Comparability Between Periods
Subsubsection Text: Under IFRS 8 ‘Operating Segments’, we determine operating segments based on the information that is provided to the Group Executive Committee, which is the Group’s chief operating decision maker, and it aggregates its operating segments into reporting segments where aggregation provides useful information to the users of the financial statements and where the operating segments have similar characteristics. Reporting segments are reviewed and revised as necessary following structural changes within the Group or acquisitions of new companies. Since June 22, 2017, we have redefined our operating segments a number of times in accordance with the needs of the expanding business and the new acquisitions. The periodic re-organization of our reporting segments reflects our ongoing business at the relevant time and impacts the comparability of segmental financial information as the underlying inputs will be reallocated based on the revised segmentation. Under “—Results of Operations” below, we refer to our segments by different names than in the Financial Statements. The segments have not been restated or changed. We refer to (i) Ardonagh Advisory as Global P&C: UK Advisory, (i) Ardonagh International as Global P&C: International Advisory, (iii) Ardonagh Specialty as Specialty Broking and (iv) Ardonagh Retail as Retail.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: (1) On May 31, 2022, The Ardonagh Group Limited, the entity at which we previously reported our results, merged into the Group’s new indirect parent company, Tara Topco Limited. Following this merger, on June 1, 2022, AGHL acquired Ardonagh New Midco 3 Limited, including the Group companies that were previously owned by The Ardonagh Group Limited, and became the reporting entity for the Group. AGHL’s first reporting period included all transactions since its incorporation on December 8, 2021 to December 31, 2022, but only includes four months of the results of operations and cash flows of the consolidated operations of AGHL due to the timing of the Tara Transactions. In order to present meaningfully comparable financial information, we present the financial information of (i) the Company for the years ended 2020, 2021 and 2022 and (ii) AGHL for the nine months ended September 30, 2023 and the twelve months ended September 30, 2023 in this table. See “Presentation of Financial Information” and note 1 to the Unaudited Interim Financial Statements. (2) The consolidated statement of profit and loss of AGHL for the period ended September 30, 2022 includes all transactions from the incorporation of AGHL on December 8, 2021 to September 30, 2022, but only includes four months of the results of operations of the consolidated operations of AGHL due to the timing of the Tara Transactions. As a result, the comparability between the consolidated statement of profit and loss of AGHL for the period ended September 30, 2022 and the nine months ended 2023 is limited. See “Presentation of Financial Information” and notes 1 and 26 to the Unaudited Interim Financial Statements. (3) As a result of the Retail Transaction, Retail is presented as a discontinued operation in the consolidated statement of loss and other comprehensive income in the financial information of AGHL for the period ended September 30, 2022 and the nine months ended September 30, 2023, and therefore excluded from the results presented in the above table. See “Presentation of Financial _Information” and note 26 to the Unaudited Interim Financial Statements._ (4) In the 2022 Audited Financial Statements, the Parent changed the presentation of investment income and it is now presented as part of finance income. This change in presentation was reflected also in the comparative period. As such, the line items investment income, operating profit and finance income for the year ended 31 December 2021 included in this offering memorandum and derived from the 2021 Audited Financial Statements differ from the same line items in the 2021 comparative column in the 2022 Audited Financial Statements. The information for the year ended December 31, 2020 also does not reflect this change in presentation (5) Total income as presented above comprises the sum of commission and fees, other income, investment income and finance income. (6) See “Summary Historical Financial Information and Other Data—Other Consolidated Financial and Pro Forma Data” for reconciliation of Adjusted EBITDA to Loss for the Period. Adjusted EBITDA is a non-IFRS measure. See “Presentation of _Financial Information—Non-IFRS Measures.”_

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Results of Operations—Ardonagh Group Holdings Limited—Nine Months Ended September 30, 2023 Compared to the Period Ended September 30, 2022
Subsubsection Text: Total income from continuing operations increased by 190.9%, or £619.4 million, to £943.9 million for the nine months ended September 30, 2023 from £324.5 million for period ended September 30, 2022. This increase was primarily due to the Tara Transactions as the results for the period ended September 30, 2022 only included transactions from June 1, 2022 to September 30, 2022 whereas the results for the nine months ended September 30, 2023 include transactions for the entire period. Other than as related to the Tara Transactions, this increase was primarily due to acquisitions completed during the nine months ended September 30, 2023 and due to organic growth of 11.6% (excluding Retail) in the twelve months ended September 30, 2023, which occurred across all platforms but primarily in Specialty Broking and International Advisory.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Results of Operations—Ardonagh Group Holdings Limited—Nine Months Ended September 30, 2023 Compared to the Period Ended September 30, 2022
Subsubsection Text: Salaries and associated costs from continuing operations increased by 172.9%, or £296.9 million, to £468.7 million for the nine months ended September 30, 2023 from £171.8 million for the period ended September 30, 2022. This increase was primarily due to the Tara Transactions. As a percentage of Total Income, salaries and associated costs from continuing operations decreased from 52.9% for the period 105 ----- ended September 30, 2022 to 49.7% for the nine months ended September 30, 2023. The relative decrease of salaries and associated costs from continuing operations was primarily due to our revenue growth increasing faster than our salary growth in our faster growing markets.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Results of Operations—Ardonagh Group Holdings Limited—Nine Months Ended September 30, 2023 Compared to the Period Ended September 30, 2022
Subsubsection Text: Other operating costs from continuing operations increased by 263.7%, or £179.7 million, to £247.9 million for the nine months ended September 30, 2023 from £68.1 million for the period ended September 30, 2022. This increase was primarily due to the Tara Transactions. As a percentage of Total Income, other operating costs from continuing operations increased from 21.0% for the period ended September 30, 2022 to 26.3% for the nine months ended September 30, 2023. The increase was primarily due to higher acquisition and financing costs as we increased our acquisition activity in 2023.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Results of Operations—Ardonagh Group Holdings Limited—Nine Months Ended September 30, 2023 Compared to the Period Ended September 30, 2022
Subsubsection Title: Depreciation, amortisation and impairment of non-financial assets
Subsubsection Text: Depreciation, amortisation and impairment of non-financial assets increased by 107.8%, or £72.2 million, to £139.2 million for the nine months ended September 30, 2023 from £67.0 million for the period ended September 30, 2022. This increase was primarily due to the Tara Transactions.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Results of Operations—Ardonagh Group Holdings Limited—Nine Months Ended September 30, 2023 Compared to the Period Ended September 30, 2022
Subsubsection Text: Finance costs from continuing operations increased by 61.7%, or £135.4 million, to £355.0 million for the nine months ended September 30, 2023 from £219.5 million for the period ended September 30, 2022. This increase was primarily due to the Tara Transactions. Excluding the impact of the Tara Transactions, the Group’s finance costs decreased as a result of favorable foreign exchange on borrowings movements.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Results of Operations—Ardonagh Group Holdings Limited—Nine Months Ended September 30, 2023 Compared to the Period Ended September 30, 2022
Subsubsection Text: Tax credit from continuing operations decreased by 17.8%, or £5.5 million, to £25.3 million for the nine months ended September 30, 2023 from £30.7 million for the period ended September 30, 2022. This decrease was due to the Tara Transactions and a change in the applicable effective tax rate of 15.3% in 2022 as compared to an effective tax rate of 9.9% in 2023.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Results of Operations—Ardonagh Group Holdings Limited—Nine Months Ended September 30, 2023 Compared to the Period Ended September 30, 2022
Subsubsection Text: Loss for the period from continuing operations increased by 35.5%, or £60.4 million, to £230.2 million for the nine months ended September 30, 2023 from £169.8 million for the period ended September 30, 2022. This increase was primarily due to the Tara Transactions. Excluding the impact of the Tara Transactions, loss for the period decreased primarily due to a decrease in finance costs, an increase in finance income, gains on the revaluation of joint venture and the profit on disposal of business, partially offset by a decrease in operating profit due to inflation and an increase in tax charges.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Results of Operations—Ardonagh Group Holdings Limited—Nine Months Ended September 30, 2023 Compared to the Period Ended September 30, 2022
Subsubsection Text: Adjusted EBITDA increased by 203.5%, or £204.6 million, to £305.1 million for the nine months ended September 30, 2023 from £100.5 million for the period ended September 30, 2022. This increase was primarily due to the Tara Transactions. Excluding the impact of the Tara Transactions, the increase in Adjusted EBITDA was primarily due to a combination of acquisitions and organic growth, seen across all platforms but primarily in the Specialty Broking, UK Advisory and International Advisory platforms, with income growth and the delivery of cost savings and synergies offsetting the pressures of inflation. 106 -----

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Results of Operations—Ardonagh Midco 2 plc—Year Ended December 31, 2022 Compared to the Year Ended December 31, 2021
Subsubsection Text: Total income increased by 30.3%, or £286.2 million, to £1,232.0 million in the year ended December 31, 2022 from £945.8 million in the year ended December 31, 2021. This increase was primarily due to increased commission and fees driven by acquisitions completed in the year ended December 31, 2022 and as a result of organic growth driven by the International Advisory, Specialty Broking and UK Advisory platforms.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Results of Operations—Ardonagh Midco 2 plc—Year Ended December 31, 2022 Compared to the Year Ended December 31, 2021
Subsubsection Text: Salaries and associated costs increased by 34.4%, or £153.6 million, to £600.3 million in the year ended December 31, 2022 from £446.7 million in the year ended December 31, 2021. This increase was primarily due to an increase in the number of employees in 2022. As a percentage of Total Income, salaries and associated costs from continuing operations increase from 47.2% for the year ended December 31, 2021 to 48.7% for the year ended December 31, 2022. The slight increase of salaries and associated costs from continuing operations was primarily due to the increase of the Specialty Broking segment, where employees have higher salaries and associated costs as a share of income, as a share of the total Ardonagh business.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Results of Operations—Ardonagh Midco 2 plc—Year Ended December 31, 2022 Compared to the Year Ended December 31, 2021
Subsubsection Text: Other operating costs increased by 33.7%, or £89.2 million, to £354.1 million in the year ended December 31, 2022 from £264.9 million in the year ended December 31, 2021. This increase was 110 ----- primarily due to growth through acquisitions and underlying cost inflation. As a percentage of Total Income, other operating costs from continuing operations increased from 28.0% for the year ended December 31, 2021 to 28.7% for the year ended December 31, 2022. The increase was primarily due to underlying inflation in other costs outstripping revenue growth.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Results of Operations—Ardonagh Midco 2 plc—Year Ended December 31, 2022 Compared to the Year Ended December 31, 2021
Subsubsection Title: Depreciation, amortisation and impairment of non-financial assets
Subsubsection Text: Depreciation, amortisation and impairment of non-financial assets increased by 49.6%, or £58.3 million, to £175.7 million in the year ended December 31, 2022 from £117.4 million in the year ended December 31, 2021. This increase was primarily due to growth through acquisitions and investments in technology assets across the Group.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Results of Operations—Ardonagh Midco 2 plc—Year Ended December 31, 2022 Compared to the Year Ended December 31, 2021
Subsubsection Text: Finance costs increased by 106.0%, or £216.8 million, to £421.3 million in the year ended December 31, 2022 from £204.5 million in the year ended December 31, 2021. This increase was primarily due to foreign exchange fluctuations resulting in additional expense on the revaluation of the borrowings, increased borrowings, and increases in base interest rates resulting in additional interest expense.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Results of Operations—Ardonagh Midco 2 plc—Year Ended December 31, 2022 Compared to the Year Ended December 31, 2021
Subsubsection Text: Tax credit increased by 99.5%, or £22.4 million, to £44.9 million in the year ended December 31, 2022 from £22.5 million in the year ended December 31, 2021. This increase was primarily due to larger loss before taxation on continuing operations.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Results of Operations—Ardonagh Midco 2 plc—Year Ended December 31, 2022 Compared to the Year Ended December 31, 2021
Subsubsection Text: Loss for the period increased by 290.6%, or £208.9 million, to £280.8 million in the year ended December 31, 2022 from £71.9 million in the year ended December 31, 2021. This increase was primarily due to an increase of £216.8 million in finance costs, an increase of £13.5 million in business transformation costs and changes in foreign exchange gains, and a decrease in operating profit partially offset by an increase in financial income and an increase in tax credit.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Results of Operations—Ardonagh Midco 2 plc—Year Ended December 31, 2022 Compared to the Year Ended December 31, 2021
Subsubsection Text: Adjusted EBITDA increased by 16.6%, or £53.1 million, to £373.4 million in the year ended December 31, 2022 from £320.3 million in the year ended December 31, 2021. This increase was primarily due to a combination of acquisitions and organic growth in all platforms except for Retail, with income growth and the delivery of cost savings and synergies offsetting the pressures of inflation.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Results of Operations—Ardonagh Midco 2 plc—Year Ended December 31, 2021 Compared to the Year Ended December 31, 2020
Subsubsection Text: Total income increased by 32.5%, or £232.0 million, to £945.8 million in the year ended December 31, 2021 from £713.8 million in the year ended December 31, 2020. The increase was primarily due strong organic revenue growth in our Global P&C and Specialty Broking platforms, partially offset by a small decline in Retail resulting from market volatility towards the end of 2021. 114 -----

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Results of Operations—Ardonagh Midco 2 plc—Year Ended December 31, 2021 Compared to the Year Ended December 31, 2020
Subsubsection Text: Salaries and associated costs increased by 29.3%, or £101.2 million, to £446.7 million in the year ended December 31, 2021 from £345.5 million in the year ended December 31, 2020. The increase was primarily due to an increase in the number of employees in 2021. As a percentage of Total Income, salaries and associated costs from continuing operations decreased from 48.4% for the year ended December 31, 2020 to 47.2% for the year ended December 31, 2021. The decrease of salaries and associated costs from continuing operations was primarily due to the impact of various business transformation programs.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS

Subsubsection Text: Other operating costs increased by 28.3%, or £58.5 million, to £264.9 million in the year ended December 31, 2021 from £206.4 million in the year ended December 31, 2020. The increase was primarily due an increase in the number of acquisitions completed in 2021. As a percentage of Total Income, other operating costs from continuing operations decreased from 28.9% for the year ended December 31, 2020 to 28.0% for the year ended December 31, 2021. The decrease was primarily due to the impact of various business transformation programs.

The increase was primarily due to the increase in the number of acquisitions completed from mid-2020 through 2021 (notably the acquisition of Bravo and the acquisition of Arachas).

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Results of Operations—Ardonagh Midco 2 plc—Year Ended December 31, 2021 Compared to the Year Ended December 31, 2020
Subsubsection Text: Finance costs decreased by 13.3%, or £31.3 million, to £204.5 million in the year ended December 31, 2021 from £235.8 million in the year ended December 31, 2020. The decrease was primarily due to an amendment to the terms of the Existing Term Facilities on August 19, 2021. Pursuant to the amendment, the margin on the Existing Term Facilities was reduced by 0.25%, and the option to pay interest in kind was removed. On November 18, 2021, the foregoing margins were further reduced by 0.50% due to the change to the consolidated senior net leverage ratio.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Liquidity and Capital Resources
Subsubsection Text: Liquidity describes the availability of liquid resources and ability of a company to generate sufficient cash flows to meet the cash requirements of its business operations, including working capital needs, capital expenditure, debt service obligations, other commitments, contractual obligations and acquisitions. Proactive and careful management of our liquidity continues to be a key priority for us, utilizing both medium (12 months rolling) and short-term (13 weeks rolling) forecasts. Our liquidity requirements arise primarily to meet our debt service obligations, to fund capital expenditures, to fund salaries and other associated costs and to fund acquisitions. Going forward, our primary sources of liquidity are provided by our cash from operating activities and drawings under the Revolving Credit Facility. In addition, we received net proceeds for issuance of share capital from our shareholders in the amount of £134.9 million in January 2023 and £187.4 million in March 2023. Our debt service obligations consist primarily of interest payments on the Existing Senior Secured Credit Facilities and the Existing Notes, and following the Transactions, including the Offering, will consist of interest payments on the Senior Secured Credit Facilities and the Notes. Although we believe that our expected cash flows from operating activities, together with available borrowings will be adequate to meet our anticipated general liquidity needs and debt service obligations, we cannot assure you that our business will generate sufficient cash flows from operations to meet these needs or that future debt or equity financing will be available to us in an amount sufficient to enable us to fund our liquidity needs, including making payments on the Notes or other debt when due. If our cash flows from operating activities are lower than expected or our capital expenditure requirements exceed our projections, we may be required to seek additional financing, which may not be available on commercially reasonable terms, if at all. Our ability to arrange financing generally and our cost of capital depends on numerous factors, including general economic conditions, the availability of credit from banks, other financial institutions, and capital markets, restrictions in instruments governing our debt, and our general financial performance. See “Risk Factors—Risks Related to our Financial Profile” and “Risk Factors—Risks Related to our Financial Profile—Our substantial leverage and debt service _obligations could adversely affect our business and prevent us from fulfilling our obligations with respect to the Notes, the Note Guarantees and the Collateral.”_

Subsubsection Text: 116 ----- (1) On May 31, 2022, The Ardonagh Group Limited, the entity at which we previously reported our results, merged into the Group’s new indirect parent company, Tara Topco Limited. Following this merger, on June 1, 2022, AGHL acquired Ardonagh New Midco 3 Limited, including the Group companies that were previously owned by The Ardonagh Group Limited, and became the reporting entity for the Group. AGHL’s first reporting period included all transactions since its incorporation on December 8, 2021 to December 31, 2022, but only includes four months of the results of operations and cash flows of the consolidated operations of AGHL due to the timing of the Tara Transactions. In order to present meaningfully comparable financial information, we present the financial information of (i) the Company for the years ended 2020, 2021 and 2022 and (ii) AGHL for the period ended September 30, 2022 and the nine months ended September 30, 2023 in this table. See “Presentation of Financial Information” and note 1 to the Unaudited Interim Financial Statements. (2) The consolidated statement of cash flows of AGHL for the period ended September 30, 2022 includes all transactions from the incorporation of AGHL on December 8, 2021 to September 30, 2022, but only includes four months of the results of operations and cash flows of the consolidated operations of AGHL due to the timing of the Tara Transactions. As a result, the comparability between the consolidated statement of cash flows of AGHL for the period ended September 30, 2022 and the nine months ended 2023 is limited. See “Presentation of Financial Information” and notes 1 and 26 to the Unaudited Interim Financial Statements. _Net cash inflow from operating activities_ The net cash inflow from operating activities increased by £46.3 million to £278.7 million for the nine months ended September 30, 2023 from a net cash inflow of £232.4 million for the period ended September 30, 2022. This increase was primarily due to the Tara Transactions. _Net cash inflow/(outflow) from investing activities_ The net cash flow from investing activities decreased by £1,543.3 million to a net cash outflow of £471.0 million for the nine months ended September 30, 2023 from a net cash inflow of £1,072.3 million for the period ended September 30, 2022. This increase was primarily due to the Tara Transactions as the entire business of the Group was acquired by AGHL on June 1, 2022. _Net cash inflow from financing activities_ The net cash inflow from financing activities increased by £435.2 million to £303.5 million for the nine months ended September 30, 2023 from a net cash (outflow) of £131.7 million for the period ended September 30, 2022. This increase was primarily due to the Tara Transactions.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Group Management Presentation of Cash Flow for the nine and twelve months ended September 30, 2023
Subsubsection Text: In our business activity as a broker, we handle significant amounts of fiduciary cash that is collected from customers and passed on to insurers. Movements in such fiduciary cash balances are included in the cash flow under IFRS reporting. The cash flow figures in this section represent management’s view of cash flow excluding movements in fiduciary cash balances. Our management operating cash flow for the twelve months ended September 30, 2023 was £420 million. Our investment spend for the nine months ended September 30, 2023 was £54 million (compared with £48 million for the same period in the prior year). Our free cash flow, for the nine months ended September 30, 2023 was an outflow of £125 million (compared with an inflow of £3 million for the same period prior year). For the twelve months ended September 30, 2023, free cash flow was an outflow of £40 million. Our net free cash flow for the nine months ended September 30, 2023 was an outflow of £59 million (compared with an outflow of £189 million for the same period in the prior year). For the twelve months ended September 30, 2023, net free cash flow was an outflow of £15 million.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: (1) The Ardonagh Group Limited merged into Tara Topco Limited on May 31, 2022. Following this merger, AGHL acquired Ardonagh New Midco 3 Limited, including the Group companies previously owned by The Ardonagh Group Limited, on June 1, 2022. The first reporting period of AGHL is from its incorporation on December 8, 2021 to December 31, 2022; however, all transactions arose from June 1, 2022 to December 31, 2022. In order to present meaningfully comparable financial information, we present the financial information of (i) Ardonagh Midco 2 plc, the issuer of the Existing Notes, for the years ended 2020, 2021 and 2022 and (ii) AGHL for the period ended September 30, 2022 and the nine months ended 117 ----- 2023 and the twelve months ended September 30, 2023. See “Presentation of Financial Information” and note 1 in the Unaudited Interim Financial Statements. _Net cash inflow from operating activities_ The net cash inflow from operating activities decreased by £517.4 million to £171.1 million in the year ended December 31, 2022 from a net cash inflow of £688.5 million for the year ended December 31, 2021. The decrease was predominantly due to increased losses from continuing operations and a decrease in trade payables given that 2021 benefited from the acquisition of BGC Partners Inc. _Net cash outflow from investing activities_ The net cash outflow from investing activities increased by £4.3 million to £426.8 million in the year ended December 31, 2022 from a net cash outflow of £422.5 million for the year ended December 31, 2021. _Net cash inflow from financing activities_ The net cash inflow from financing activities decreased by £350.5 million to £137.7 million in the year ended December 31, 2022 from a net cash inflow of £488.2 million for the year ended December 31, 2021. The decrease was due to a reduction in proceeds from borrowings in 2022 in comparison to proceeds received in 2021 in addition to an increase in interest paid on Group borrowings.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Qualitative and Quantitative Disclosures About Our Market Risk
Subsubsection Text: Our primary exposure to foreign currency risk arises from (i) our borrowings in U.S. dollars and (ii) settlement in foreign currency, principally U.S. dollars, of brokerage and fees related to the placement of insurance business originating outside of the United Kingdom. We use derivatives, specifically forward contracts to mitigate this risk. We have forward contracts that mitigate our exposure to certain U.S. dollar-denominated revenue arising on the placement of premiums, which is not the presentation nor the functional currency of the Group. Based on forecast transactions, we effectively sell U.S. dollar-denominated revenue by reference to individual brokerage transactions.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Qualitative and Quantitative Disclosures About Our Market Risk
Subsubsection Text: Our main exposure to interest rate risk arises from our floating rate Existing Secured Credit Facilities, and following the Transactions, the Senior Secured Credit Facilities. These loans bear interest at an applicable margin plus EURIBOR or SONIA. We use derivatives, specifically interest rate swaps, to mitigate our interest rate risk. We expect to continue to be exposed to interest rate risk following the Transactions. See “Risk Factors—Risks Related to Our Financial Profile—The New Senior Secured _Credit Facilities will bear interest at floating rates that could rise significantly, increasing our interest cost and reducing cash flow.”_

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Qualitative and Quantitative Disclosures About Our Market Risk
Subsubsection Text: The Group is exposed to market risk through its use of financial instruments and specifically to foreign currency risk and interest rate risk.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Significant Accounting Policies
Subsubsection Title: Critical judgments in applying accounting policies
Subsubsection Text: Certain judgments that have been made in applying accounting policies are considered to be critical. _Acquisitions and Disposals_ AGHL obtained control of Ardonagh New Midco 3 Limited on June 1, 2022. For the year ended December 31, 2022, AGHL applied acquisition accounting in accordance with IFRS 3 Business Combinations to the acquisition of Ardonagh New Midco 3 Limited at fair value on June 1, 2022, which included the recognition of intangible assets arising on a business combination and the recognition of goodwill and non-controlling interests. A critical judgment was applied in the prior year to determine if it was appropriate to apply acquisition accounting, which included consideration of the wider transaction, if there had been a change of control, and who was the acquirer. Acquisition accounting was applied as a business had been acquired and because AGHL clearly obtained control of that business. As at December 31, 2022, we had not completed the acquisition accounting of Ardonagh New Midco 3 Limited. Goodwill recognized in the prior year’s consolidated financial statements was based 119 ----- on provisional fair values of the assets acquired. The initial allocation of goodwill to the cash generating units was also done on a provisional basis in accordance with IAS 36. During 2023, AGHL and its subsidiaries completed the acquisition accounting of Ardonagh New Midco 3 Limited, and the resulting amount of goodwill has been finalized and reallocated to cash-generating units in a manner that is most appropriate to the business. During 2023, AGHL and its subsidiaries entered into negotiations to dispose of the entire share capital of Atlanta Investment Holdings 3 Limited, being the holding company for the Retail operating segment. On September 1, 2023, all material matters fundamental to the deal were agreed upon with the buyer and there were no further matters that could have caused the planned sale to be withdrawn or changed significantly. Consequently, as at that date the disposal group was classified as held for sale in accordance with IFRS 5 Non-current Assets Held for Sale and Discontinued Operations. At that date, the carrying values of all assets and liabilities within the disposal group were measured in accordance with applicable IFRS and then compared to the fair value less cost to sell of the disposal group. The excess, if any, of the carrying value of the disposal group over its fair value less cost to sell is required to be recognized as an impairment loss. There was no material difference between the carrying value and the fair value less cost to sell of the disposal group and therefore no impairment loss was recognized. Furthermore, in accordance with IFRS 5, from the date of classification as held for sale, non-current assets within the disposal group are not subject to depreciation or amortisation.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Significant Accounting Policies
Subsubsection Text: _Impairment of assets_ We test annually whether goodwill and intangible assets that have indefinite useful lives have suffered any impairment. Other assets are reviewed for impairment whenever events or changes in circumstances indicate that the carrying amount of the assets may exceed their recoverable amounts. The last annual impairment test was performed as of July 1, 2023. An impairment test of an asset or cash-generating unit (or group of cash-generating units) is performed by comparing its carrying amount with its recoverable amount. The recoverable amount is the higher of its fair value less costs of disposal and its value in use, where its value in use is the present value of its future cash flows. An impairment test requires the application of significant judgment because it relies on key assumptions, including forecast cash flows, a discount rate, a terminal growth rate and an Adjusted EBITDA multiple. Accordingly, the resulting estimates are significant estimates because there is a significant risk of a material adjustment to the carrying amounts of affected balances within the next financial year. Goodwill arising from a new business combination is, for the purposes of impairment testing, allocated to those cash-generating units that are expected to benefit from the goodwill that was acquired. Impairment testing is performed at the level of the smallest groups of cash-generating units at which goodwill is monitored, known as the divisions. Forecast cash flows used in the value in use calculation were determined by considering historic business performance, by overlaying it with assumptions to reflect areas where growth or income improvement was expected, and by taking into account the expected results of cost management programs to which we are committed. The forecasts were extrapolated to subsequent years using a steady growth rate being the forecast CPI inflation rate of 2%, and a terminal value was calculated using the perpetual growth model. The discount rate of 9.55% to 11.45% that was applied to the forecasts was a market participant weighted average cost of capital calculated by reference to the Capital Asset Pricing Model. The fair value of AGHL and its subsidiaries was calculated based on multiples of forecast 2024 Adjusted EBITDA and on information provided by external advisors, where that information is based on recent transactions in the insurance broking industry. The fair value of an operating segment was estimated by apportioning the fair value of our group between the operating segments based on the 120 ----- value in use of each operating segment. The estimated costs of disposal are assumed, based on market experience, to be 1.5% of the fair value of the operating segment. As of September 30, 2023, there were no indications of impairment and therefore no impairment test has been performed. 121 -----

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Significant Accounting Policies
Subsubsection Text: Significant accounting policies are those that (i) are relevant to the presentation of our financial condition and results of operations and (ii) require management to make judgments, estimates and assumptions that affect the application of accounting policies and the reported amounts of assets and liabilities, income and expenses. In order to provide an understanding of how we form our judgments, including the variables underlying their estimates and assumptions and the sensitivity of those judgments to different circumstances, we have identified the significant accounting polices discussed below. While we believe that all aspects of our financial statements should be studied and understood in assessing our current and expected financial condition and results of operations, we believe the following significant accounting policies warrant particular attention.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: INDUSTRY OVERVIEW Overview
Subsubsection Text: Providing insurance coverage to customers entails a series of activities, including (i) providing risk capital, a service exclusively provided by insurance and reinsurance companies; (ii) underwriting insurance policies, a service that requires in-depth technical knowledge; and (iii) distribution, a service that requires knowledge of the customer base and of the risks to the customer. The amount of financial risk an insurance or a reinsurance company is willing to assume in relation to its insurance policies is a function of underwriting appetite and capital or capacity. The participants in the intermediation of insurance products are principally brokers, underwriting agencies and aggregators as well as insurers selling directly to customers. The chart below shows the participants across the insurance distribution chain.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Insurance products
Subsubsection Text: General non-life personal lines insurance is sold to individual customers and includes accident and sickness coverage, household insurance, motor insurance, along with travel and personal accident insurance. In these segments, specialist non-life personal lines insurance products are sold to individual customers in niche areas within a segment or those with non-standard risk profiles, such as classic car insurance or insurance for learner drivers.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Insurance products
Subsubsection Text: General non-life commercial lines insurance is sold to commercial customers and includes construction insurance, commercial property insurance, commercial combined insurance, office and contents insurance, professional indemnity insurance, fleet insurance, employer liability insurance, agriculture 122 ----- insurance, marine insurance and transport insurance. SME commercial lines insurance is sold to SMEs. Specialist non-life commercial lines insurance is also sold to commercial customers in niche markets.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Insurance products
Subsubsection Title: Life, pensions and other financial services insurance
Subsubsection Text: Life, pensions and other financial services insurance is sold to individual customers and includes life insurance, pensions, annuities and investment products.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Insurance products
Subsubsection Text: Insurance products, both specialist and non-specialist, can be broadly classified into three types: (A) General non-life personal lines insurance; (B) General non-life commercial lines insurance, which includes SME commercial lines insurance; and (C) Life, pensions and other financial services insurance.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Insurance supply chain
Subsubsection Text: Risk taking activity in the insurance supply chain is undertaken by insurance companies who underwrite insurance and expose their balance sheets to loss. Insurance companies earn income (i) from premiums; and (ii) by investing their available reserves, that is, the amount of money at any given time collected in premium but not yet paid out in claims. Traditionally, insurance companies sold indirectly through intermediaries such as brokers and underwriting agencies but in certain markets and product areas they now also sell insurance directly, via telephone or online. Traditionally, insurance companies also performed all the services necessary for providing insurance, including underwriting, administering insurance policies and handling insurance claims and renewals. Today, many insurance companies outsource these services to intermediaries.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Insurance supply chain
Subsubsection Text: The distribution of insurance products is carried out by brokers, underwriting agencies and through PCWs. In certain markets and product areas, insurers also distribute products directly to customers. _Brokers_ Broking is the process by which a broker negotiates insurance policy terms for a customer and places that customer’s risk with an appropriate insurance company either directly or through an underwriting agency. Customers include businesses, individuals and public institutions, and, in the case of wholesale brokers, other brokers. Brokers connect insurance companies and underwriting agencies with customers in the insurance supply chain and so act as a distribution channel for insurance products. Insurance companies and underwriting agencies, as the case may be, compensate brokers by means of commissions based on premium levels and fees for individual services. In certain cases, brokers will forego some or all of the commission payable by the insurance company and instead be compensated by the customer for the placement service (particularly in personal lines). _Underwriting agencies_ An underwriting agent serves as an intermediary between an insurance company and a broker or the customer. In addition to providing underwriting services, some underwriting agencies act as MGA by issuing and administering insurance policies and handling insurance claims and renewals on behalf of insurance companies. Such underwriting agencies operate as “virtual insurers”, performing most functions of a traditional insurance company including underwriting and pricing, but excluding the provision of capital and the incurrence of liability in respect of insurance claims. The performance of an underwriting agency can be judged by its underwriting results, the amount of total premiums earned minus the cost of claims and operating expenses. Notably, there may be “loss-sharing” arrangements put in place between the insurance company and the underwriting agency that can impact profitability, depending on underwriting performance. 123 ----- _Price Comparison Websites (PCWs)_ PCWs are internet portals that allow insurance companies and insurance intermediaries to make their insurance products available directly to customers via the internet. Customers can obtain several quotes from insurance companies and insurance intermediaries on aggregator websites by making only one data entry. The insurance company or insurance intermediary with the most appealing (by terms or price) quote issues the insurance policy to the customer and compensates the PCW by means of a referral fee. PCWs are predominantly used to sell personal motor insurance policies and, to a lesser extent, household insurance policies as well as other personal lines products. PCWs have had a limited impact on the sale of commercial lines (except commercial auto) of insurance due to the complexity of the products and the “off-line” advice sought by commercial customers for most commercial insurance products. In many cases, the PCW is reliant on another insurance intermediary, such as a broker or an underwriting agency, to fulfill a number of critical activities such as managing the panel of insurers whose products are available on the website. Similarly, an insurer may contract with a broker to manage the insurer’s presence on a number of PCWs.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Insurance supply chain
Subsubsection Text: _Network service providers_ Network service providers offer independent brokers access to insurance products that are not typically available to independent brokers as well as enhanced agency terms, in effect operating as a buying club. Network service providers also offer independent brokers access to certain business support services such as handling of client money, risk & compliance and marketing. _Service companies_ As insurers, MGAs, brokers and other participants in the insurance market look to improve cost efficiencies in fulfillment, specialists offering business process outsourcing have become more significant in the market. The initial focus of these service providers have been on claims fulfillment, including completion of the first notification of loss, claims validation, litigation services, and other associated claims services. These service providers have also branched out into other areas such as customer services, sales campaign management, premium finance and white-labelled products.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Insurance market structure and size
Subsubsection Text: _Competitive landscape_ The competition for business has been one of the primary factors that has been driving broker consolidation by non-vertically integrated players in the highly competitive UK market in recent years. Consolidation is driven by the need to gain scale to effectively compete with larger, vertically integrated players, particularly in the personal lines market. A variety of other factors have also driven these acquisitions, including the increase in compliance and administrative costs resulting from new FCA regulations, the aging broker demographic, recognition of the potential for economies of scale and the consequent enhanced ability to compete effectively on price to drive increases in win-rates. The group has a proven track record of M&A across all of its platforms, and believes there remain significant opportunities to acquire brokers of varying sizes, which can add capabilities and customer volumes. _UK Insurance distribution trends_ Brokers are the primary distribution channel in the UK non-life market. Client purchasing behavior differs between customer types. Accordingly, brokers account for differing percentages of GWP depending on the type of insurance being transacted with a large majority of commercial premium transacted by brokers compared with a smaller amount of personal lines premium. 125 ----- Brokers will likely remain the largest SME market distribution channel due to the complexity of covers required and development of digital capabilities. With the expansion of the internet, the amount of personal insurance products sold by means of PCWs has grown significantly. Expansion is expected to continue at a more modest rate as customers continue to use PCWs. PCWs will likely continue to dominate the standard personal insurance markets, but will increasingly look to other markets both geographically and from a product perspective. PCWs have previously tried to sell other insurance products directly; however, they experience greater success when partnering with existing product specialists. PCWs allow existing product specialists to make their insurance products available directly to customers via the internet, and as such, PCWs are not direct competitors of existing product specialists, but rather serve as intermediaries between them and end customers. _New emerging risks_ The broker’s role in connection with non-standard risks is becoming increasingly important. The market is experiencing an increased appetite for newer risk categories, including cyber, supply chain and legislative, and as more customers look to insure against these new risks, the role of advice and significance of choice will become more important and the use of on brokers will subsequently increase. This is in particular relevant to any complex, large or otherwise sophisticated risks, which demand a broker-advised sale as opposed to a low involvement sale through PCWs. _Increase in divestment / redistribution of unprofitable products or processes_ As all participants in the insurance market seek to improve profit margins, there is an increasing trend for organizations to divest and outsource unprofitable products or processes to specialists who charge an administrative fee or take a cut of commission. More of the larger insurers and other insurance intermediaries, such as banks and retailers, are actively using white-labelled products from other insurance providers.
