We are committed to creating value for our stakeholders by embedding ESG considerations throughout all stages of the insurance process. We have adopted a Sustainability Charter based on five sustainability pillars. Our Sustainability Charter underpins all our conversations, business decisions and the culture of our businesses. The five sustainability pillars of our Sustainability Charter are outlined below. - _Integrity. We seek to conduct our business in an honest and ethical manner. - _Innovation. We seek to be proactive and responsive to our evolving client needs. - _People. We seek to ensure the welfare of our employees and those we work with. - _Society. We seek to enhance the wellbeing of the communities we serve. - _Environment. We seek to protect the environment and become net zero. We believe that we do not have any material environmental compliance costs or environmental liabilities.

Section Title: BUSINESS
Subsection Title: Ardonagh Community Trust
Subsubsection Text: We believe it is important to support the communities that we live and work in. This belief led us to establish the Ardonagh Community Trust (“ACT”) in 2018, a registered charity through which we implement our community-focused charitable activities. To date, employees raised over £700,000 for significant causes and ACT matched the effort with an additional £270,000, helping over 600 different charities. Since its establishment, ACT has raised £5.5 million. Through a quarterly grant program, our employees can also each access financial support of up to £5,000 for charitable causes and community projects. In 2023, £66,000 was awarded in grants, helping 14 charities worldwide. Employees receive one paid day a year to volunteer and support a charity or community project. We have also partnered with leading mental health charities such as Mind, as well as Samaritans, which provides listening services across the UK and Ireland for suicide prevention. Over £320,000 was raised for these two partnerships. In 2024, ACT aims to partner with Médecins Sans Frontières, a global humanitarian charity providing medical care around the world. We consider ACT to be one of our proudest achievements, and we continue to be passionate about the communities we live and work in and believe in the importance of supporting them in becoming stronger, better and brighter. 149 -----

Section Title: BUSINESS
Subsection Title: Real Estate
Subsubsection Text: We lease office space in various locations throughout the world in countries where we have operations, including in Australia, Austria Bermuda, Brazil, Chile, Dubai, Germany, Greece, Hong Kong, Ireland, Italy, Jersey, Malaysia, Portugal, Peru, Singapore, South Africa, Switzerland, the United Kingdom, the Netherlands and the United States. Each of our businesses has historically managed its respective property portfolios internally, supported by our central resources and external specialists where appropriate. These internal property teams are responsible for ensuring that each site is in compliance with any relevant statutory requirements, including health and safety requirements as well as disposition of surplus property.

Section Title: BUSINESS
Subsection Title: Insurance
Subsubsection Text: Our underlying businesses are subject to various actual and potential claims, lawsuits and other proceedings relating principally to alleged errors and omissions in connection with the placement of insurance in the ordinary course of business. We believe that each of our underlying businesses has adequate insurance coverage against all material risks that are typically insured by similar companies with comparable risk exposure. Insurance cover is regularly reviewed and adjusted when necessary; however, one or more of our underlying businesses may incur losses that are not covered by existing policies or that exceed the coverage levels stipulated in the applicable insurance policies.

Section Title: BUSINESS
Subsection Title: Regulation
Subsubsection Text: UK-domiciled trading entities within our Group are authorized and regulated by the FCA to carry on insurance broking and other insurance mediation activities in the United Kingdom pursuant to FSMA and its related statutory instruments. Our insurance mediation activities must comply with the FCA Rules and guidelines that impose, amongst other things, a high-level standard on the establishment and maintenance of proper systems and controls and minimum threshold conditions that must be satisfied for an insurance broking firm to remain authorized. The FCA Rules impose certain minimum capital and liquidity requirements on firms as well as an ongoing obligation to regularly provide the FCA with certain information. The FCA has extensive investigative and disciplinary powers. In addition, individuals performing various ‘Senior Management’ functions are required to be approved by the FCA. A number of senior management personnel located within our regulated entities are approved and are required to satisfy certain fitness and propriety criteria. The FCA maintains an active supervision of the Group, via a dedicated supervisor, to assess our compliance with regulatory requirements. This also allows us to work closely with the FCA to address areas of potential regulatory scrutiny. The FCA plays a critical role in the insurance intermediary industry and is an important stakeholder for our Group. The FCA has been appraised of the development of our Group from the outset of its conception by our management team. We have engaged with the FCA with full transparency and acted swiftly and appropriately when required, and will continue to do so in connection with the future development of our Group. This track record of working with the FCA is demonstrated by the resolution of historic regulatory concerns. Some of our businesses have temporarily failed to meet regulatory expectations in the past, including those concerning governance and control frameworks and client money. Some of these previous failings were referenced in change of control approvals when the Group acquired these 151 ----- businesses, and the Group has implemented structured remediation plans to address these failings to the FCA’s satisfaction. For example, the FCA concluded that the previous Towergate Group had significant failings in respect of its governance arrangements, business model, financial stability and with elements of its operational and client money controls which needed to be strengthened. For these reasons, the FCA had put the Group on its ‘Watchlist’, denoting a high regulatory risk profile. The management of the Group has worked closely with the FCA to resolve these concerns over time, including overhauling risk, compliance and governance arrangements. During this remediation process (at the end of 2018), our Group acquired Swinton, which was also on the FCA Watchlist. We therefore extended our regulatory remediation plans to address the risks that applied to Swinton (which also included governance and risk management concerns). In January 2020, the FCA confirmed it was satisfied with the remediation of all Watchlist items, including those applying to the previous Towergate and Swinton businesses, and therefore removed the Group’s businesses from its Watchlist. Since then, the Group has continued to work with its FCA supervisor to provide assurance over the effective management of UK regulatory change and demonstrate it has addressed any industry-wide concerns or matters of note. Our board and executive team continue to work closely with the FCA to demonstrate ongoing progress in regulated areas in which previous control weaknesses were identified. Since the formation of the Group, and following subsequent acquisitions, we have extended consistent control and governance improvements across the whole Group, regularly updating the FCA and meeting the timescales we communicated for such integration. The Paymentshield business has sold and continues to sell mortgage payment protection insurance (“MPPI”) which has been the subject of industry-wide scrutiny by the FCA and the Competition and Markets Authority (“CMA”). Paymentshield’s products are not analogous to the payment protection insurance products that have attracted the most FCA scrutiny. Paymentshield’s MPPI has no cancellation fees and proportionate refunds are offered, and premiums are payable monthly and are not capitalized upfront as part of the principal amount of the customer’s loan. Therefore, the FCA excluded Paymentshield from its 2017 Policy Statement “PS17/3 Payment protection insurance complaints: feedback on CP16/20 and final rules and guidance,” as its products were not in scope for this industry inquiry which led to significant customer redress for higher risk products. In addition, Paymentshield policies are distributed by third-party regulated brokers responsible for the sales processes, so any misselling complaints would likely relate to the third-party brokers rather than Paymentshield. We maintain diverse but individually smaller operations outside of the UK, including several trading entities in the following EU member states: the Republic of Ireland, the Netherlands, Switzerland, Austria, Portugal and Greece. A number of these businesses have a similar regulatory profile to the UK businesses within the Group, and the Group has significant experience in respect of the regulations that apply to these operations given that shared legislation (which previously applied in the UK prior to it formally separating from the EU on December 31, 2020) such as the EU Insurance Distribution Directive (IDD) and data protection regulation have a common EU source. We also maintain subsidiaries in Australia, South Africa, Bermuda, Dubai, Brazil, Malaysia and the United States, among others, and part of a joint venture in Hong Kong. In each case, local management have established practices which comply with local regulatory requirements and all businesses adhere to the Group’s overall governance and risk management frameworks, which have been updated to allow for the increased diversity of the Group. We have received no material regulatory scrutiny on non-UK operations but have proactively engaged with some regulators in more material territories, including presenting our plans and governance arrangements to the Central Bank of Ireland. Changes to the UK regulatory framework are likely in the near term as a result of the Financial Services and Markets Act 2023 (the “2023 Act”), which received Royal Assent on June 29, 2023. Although certain provisions came into force on that date, the UK Government is taking a phased approach to its implementation and other provisions will come into force on days to be appointed (unless already 152 ----- specified). The 2023 Act permits the revocation of all retained EU law relating to financial services, including the Insurance Distribution Directive, although such revocation will only take effect once regulators have drafted and consulted on replacement rules and are ready to enforce them. Other changes implemented by the 2023 Act include: (a) a new statutory objective for the FCA requiring the regulator to act in a way which facilitates the long-term growth and international competitiveness of the UK economy; and (b) a requirement for the regulator to consider the sustainable growth in the UK economy in the medium or long term in a manner consistent with the UK’s net zero emissions commitments.

Section Title: BUSINESS
Subsection Title: Legal Proceedings
Subsubsection Text: From time to time, we become involved in various actual and potential claims, lawsuits and proceedings relating principally to alleged errors, omissions or unfair provisions in connection with the placement of insurance or the provision of financial services advice in the ordinary course of business. As we often assist customers with matters involving substantial amounts of money, including the placement of insurance coverage and the handling of related claims and the provision of financial services advice, errors and omissions claims against us may arise that allege our potential liability for all or part of the amounts in question. Claimants can seek damages awards that are material for the operation of our business and these claims can involve potentially significant defense costs. We are currently not involved in any legal proceedings which, either individually or in the aggregate, are expected to have a material adverse effect on our reputation, financial position or results of operations. We note, however, that the outcome of legal proceedings can be extremely difficult to predict, and we offer no assurances in this regard. See also “Risk Factors—Risks Related to Our Business and Industry—Our business, _results of operations and financial condition may be materially adversely affected by the outcome of certain actual and potential claims, lawsuits and other proceedings.”_ 153 -----

Section Title: MANAGEMENT
Subsection Title: John Tiner CBE (Chairman) appointed June 29, 2015:
Subsubsection Text: John has been Chairman of the Ardonagh Group (formerly Towergate) since 2015. From 2011 to 2019, he was also an independent non-executive director of the board of Credit Suisse Group. In 2016 he founded The Salcombe Brewery Co. where he remains Chairman. For 25 years, up to June 2001, he worked for accountants Arthur Andersen, becoming head of their global financial services practice. There, he led the team that produced the official report investigating the 1995 collapse of Barings Bank for the Bank of England’s Board of Banking Supervision. In June 2001, John joined the UK Financial Services Authority (FSA) as Managing Director of the Consumer, Investment and Insurance Directorate. In September 2003, he was appointed Chief Executive of the FSA. In this role, he led the Tiner Review which reformed the regulation of both the life and general insurance industries and which initiated and led a program to improve consumers’ understanding of personal finance. Between 2008 and 2013, he was CEO of the Resolution Group, a private investment company which sponsored the formation through M&A of The Friends Life Group Plc, a FTSE 100 company prior to its acquisition by Aviva in 2015. John chairs the Remuneration and Nomination Committee.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT
Subsection Title: Patrick Butler (Director) appointed April 8, 2016:
Subsubsection Text: Pat spent 26 years of his career at McKinsey, where he led the firm’s Retail Financial Services Practice for Europe, the Middle East and Africa (EMEA). Pat is the Chairman of Aldemore Bank and is a NonExecutive Director of Hikma Pharmaceuticals plc. He was previously also a Partner of The Resolution 154 ----- Group, which spans financial services restructuring, the Resolution think tank and Prospect magazine. Pat is a member of the Ardonagh Audit Committee.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT
Subsection Title: Martyn Scrivens (Director) appointed October 21, 2022:
Subsubsection Text: Martyn’s career in audit, risk management and governance spans four decades, including operating at Board level in both the private and public sector. Martyn spent five years at Credit Suisse Group where he was Global Head of Internal Audit and prior to that he oversaw group audit functions at Lloyds Banking Group as Group Audit Director for nine years. Before joining Lloyds, Martyn spent 24 years at international professional services firm Arthur Andersen in the UK, Switzerland and Australia. Martyn is a fellow of the Institute of Chartered Accountants and chairs the Institute’s Internal Audit Advisory Panel. In addition to his Ardonagh role, Martyn also serves on the Board of Somerset NHS Foundation Trust and director and Audit Committee chair of Hampshire Trust Bank. Martyn chairs the Ardonagh Audit Committee.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT
Subsection Title: Vahe Dombalagian (Director) appointed December 16, 2016:
Subsubsection Text: Vahe is a Managing Director and Co-Head of the MDP Financial Services team. Prior to joining MDP, he was with Texas Pacific Group and Bear, Stearns & Co. Inc. Vahe currently serves on the Boards of Directors of The Amynta Group, Ankura Consulting Group, The Ardonagh Group, Blue Lantern Health, Great Gray Trust Company, MoneyGram, Navacord, and Towergate & Nevada Investments Topco Limited, and formerly served on the Board of Directors of Cinemark, EVO Payments International, and L.A. Fitness International. Vahe holds an M.B.A. from Harvard Graduate School of Business Administration and a B.S. from Georgetown University. Vahe is a member of the Remuneration and Nomination Committee as well as the Group’s Investment Committee.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT
Subsection Title: Scot French (Director) appointed April 2, 2015:
Subsubsection Text: Scot is a Governing Partner of HPS and is the Portfolio Manager of the HPS Strategic Investment Partners Funds. Prior to joining HPS in 2007, Scot spent three years at Citigroup as a Managing Director and Head of Private Investments for Citigroup Global Special Situations, a credit-focused, on-balance sheet proprietary investment fund. Within Citigroup Global Special Situations, Scot managed a portfolio of private mezzanine and private equity investments in North America, Europe and Latin America. Prior to joining Citigroup, Scot worked in the Investment Banking Division at Goldman Sachs from 1999 to 2004 and in Mergers & Acquisitions at Salomon Brothers Inc. from 1994 to 1999. Scot began his career at Price Waterhouse from 1992 to 1994. Scot is a graduate of the University of Illinois and a member of the Ardonagh Audit, Remuneration, and Nomination Committees as well as the Group’s Investment Committee.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT
Subsection Title: Shant Babikian (Alternate Director) appointed May 31, 2022:
Subsubsection Text: Shant is a Managing Director at HPS Investment Partners. Prior to joining HPS in 2014, Mr. Babikian was a Vice President at Oaktree Capital Management, where he focused on investing in privately structured debt and equity transactions. Prior to joining Oaktree, Mr. Babikian was an Analyst in JPMorgan’s Syndicated and Leveraged Finance Group. Mr. Babikian holds a BBA with Honors from CUNY Baruch College with a concentration in Economics.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT
Subsection Title: Matthew Raino (Alternate Director) appointed June 11, 2019:
Subsubsection Text: Matt is a Managing Director at MDP, a leading private equity investment firm based in Chicago and significant investor in The Ardonagh Group. Matt currently serves as an Alternate Director for Vahe Dombalagian. Matt is a member of MDP’s Financial and Transaction Services team. He currently serves on the boards of directors of Ankura Consulting Group, Navacord, Nevada Investments Topco Limited, NFP Corp. and EVO Payments International, and formerly served on the board of directors of The Amynta Group. Prior to joining MDP, Matt held positions with Credit Suisse First Boston. He was also 155 ----- an Associate at MDP for two years. Matt holds an M.B.A. from Northwestern University J.L. Kellogg Graduate School of Management and a B.B.A. from University of Michigan.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT
Subsection Title: David Ross (Chief Executive Officer) appointed June 2017:
Subsubsection Text: David’s appointment as Chief Executive Officer of The Ardonagh Group represented the culmination of a two-year process by shareholders and management to create the market leading independent distribution group in the UK. David became the CEO of Towergate, the original investment by HPS in the UK insurance intermediary industry, in November 2015 and led the business through a period of turnaround and transformation which included stabilising revenue, people, financials, infrastructure and governance. The demonstrable progress made with the Towergate transformation during 2016 and 2017 enabled the creation of the Ardonagh Group in June 2017. David advised MDP and HPS on the acquisition of the other assets required to fulfil the vision during 2015 and 2016. An INSEAD alumnus, David’s career has spanned 29 years on the front line of the insurance industry. This included a 25-year career at Arthur J Gallagher, most recently as the CEO of the International Division, during which time the company underwent a defining period of growth and expansion.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT
Subsection Title: Diane Cougill (Chief Financial Officer) appointed June 2018:
Subsubsection Text: Diane is The Ardonagh Group’s CFO. She previously held the positions of CFO and Executive Director Insurance at RAC from 2010 to 2018, and led the sale of the company to the Carlyle Group from Aviva in 2011 and subsequently to GIC and CVC. Prior to RAC, Diane held senior positions in Aviva where she worked for seven years, including Chief Risk Officer, Portfolio Director and Financial Control Director. Prior to that, Diane worked in the energy sector with senior finance positions at TXU Europe and Yorkshire Electricity Group. Diane is a qualified chartered accountant and a member of the Ardonagh Investment Committee.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT
Subsection Title: The Group Board
Subsubsection Text: Our board is accountable for the success of the Group for the benefit of its shareholders as a whole and setting risk appetite and frameworks of effective risk management and control. It sets strategic priorities, including the securement of debt and equity and the deployment of capital and, in doing so, it has regard to its stakeholder responsibilities including colleagues, investors, customers, suppliers, regulators and the communities in which the Group operates. Our board delegates authority to the Chief Executive Officer who, through his Executive Committee, ensures that the collective vision, policies, culture and behaviour set by the Board are effectively communicated and embedded. Delegation from Group Board to Platform and Segment Boards and to individuals across the Group is set out in the Ardonagh Accountability Framework. Our board has devolved powers set out in the Group Delegated Authority Framework to empower the Boards of our Platforms and Segment businesses across the Group to discharge detailed oversight and challenge over business performance and the management of risk and take investment decisions within shareholder approved limits.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT
Subsection Title: Principal Committees of the Group
Subsubsection Text: Our board has delegated specific responsibilities to two standing Board Committees in order to consider and provide oversight over certain matters as set forth below: (i) the Audit Committee and (ii) the Remuneration and Nomination Committee. Each Board Committee has its terms of reference and an agenda plan which is reviewed and approved on an annual basis. The board has also established the Investment Committee which is not a Board Committee, but which draws up the Group’s strategy regarding acquisitions and disposals as set forth below. 156 -----

Section Title: MANAGEMENT
Subsection Title: Audit Committee
Subsubsection Text: The principal purpose of the Audit Committee is supporting our Board in overseeing: - the integrity of external financial reporting; - the framework of internal controls and risk management systems in relation to the financial reporting process and protection of client assets; - the independence and effectiveness of our external auditor and the audit process; and - the independence, effectiveness, resourcing, audit plans and work of the internal audit function. Martyn Scrivens is the chair of the Audit Committee.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT
Subsection Title: Remuneration and Nomination Committee
Subsubsection Text: The principal purpose of the Committee is: - to set the over-arching principles and parameters of remuneration policy across the Ardonagh Group; - to consider and approve the remuneration and performance targets for senior management and executive officers and those discharging key functions; - to consider and approve the remuneration of the Chairman and Executive Directors on the Group board and to determine the remuneration of the Independent Non-Executive Directors of the Group board and segment boards; - the award of rights under long term incentive plans and the approval of new bonus and incentivization schemes; - to approve the terms of and hiring packages for any new hire above limits determined by the Group board from time to time; - to approve the leaver status and the fair market value for management equity schemes; - to ensure that the Group board retains an appropriate balance of skills to support the strategic objectives of the Group and has a formal, rigorous and transparent approach to the recruitment of directors and senior management; - ensure there is an effective framework for succession planning for the Group board and senior management; - to review the structure, balance, size, composition, working arrangements and capability (including the skills, knowledge, experience and diversity) required of the Group and Segment boards and make recommendations to the Group board and segment boards regarding any changes to their composition; and - keep the Group and segment board governance arrangements under review and make recommendations to the Group and segment boards, as appropriate. John Tiner is the chair of the Remuneration and Nomination Committee. 157 -----

Section Title: MANAGEMENT
Subsection Title: Investment Committee
Subsubsection Text: The principal purpose of the Committee is to formulate, monitor, review and execute the Group’s strategy regarding acquisitions and disposals. Aurelio Cusaro and Diane Cougill are the chairs of the Investment Committee.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT
Subsection Title: Platform Boards
Subsubsection Text: Following the announcement of the Retail Transaction, our business has been organized into two main reporting segments, which we refer to as platforms, that focus on distinct but complementary aspects of the insurance brokerage and services value chain. Global Property and Casualty, which is comprised of two subsegments: (a) UK Advisory and (b) International Advisory; and Specialty Broking. The composition of each platform board includes at least one independent director, a Group board representative director and the platform’s CEO and CFO as members. The purpose of each platform board is to exercise oversight and challenge over the execution of the annual plan and the effective management of risk. Each platform board has established a Risk & Audit committee and a Remuneration committee. The platform boards and Committees have all adopted common terms of references and operate within a clearly defined delegated authority set out in the Delegated Authority Framework and also within a clear escalation policy that ensures material matters are escalated to the Group on a timely basis. Each platform board and Committee has an annual agenda plan which is reviewed and approved on an annual basis. The platform boards and Risk & Audit Committees meet quarterly and on an ad-hoc basis when required. The platform Remuneration Committees meets at least twice a year and as and when required to consider matters within its remit and make recommendations as appropriate to the Group Remuneration Committee.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT
Subsection Title: Management Equity Interests
Subsubsection Text: We implemented the Ardonagh MIP III schemes (comprising the Tier 1 arrangements) in 2022 and the Enterprise Growth Plan scheme in early 2023. Both schemes are equity-settled share-based payment schemes, with the corresponding shares being the MIP III A and MIP III B shares, respectively. These shares are issued by Ardonagh Holdco Limited. In addition, Tara Topco Limited issues B ordinary shares (the “Topco B Shares”) to certain of our employees and key management at fair value. These shares have no dividend or voting rights and have tag-along rights on a liquidity event, an IPO or a winding up. The number of shares held by employees or third parties (excluding leavers) under the equity-settled share-based payment arrangements is as follows:

In most cases those shares have a tag-along right in the event of an Ardonagh Group or local legal entity change of control. 158 -----

Section Title: MANAGEMENT
Subsubsection Text: _Certain details about our board of directors, which includes our Chief Executive Officer and our Chief Financial Officer, are outlined below._

Section Title: SHAREHOLDERS
Subsubsection Text: The Senior Secured Notes Issuer is a direct, wholly owned subsidiary of the Company and the Senior Notes Issuer is a direct, wholly owned subsidiary of the Parent. The Company and the Parent are indirectly owned by AGHL. AGHL is indirectly owned by Tara Topco Limited. Tara Topco Limited is indirectly majority-owned through certain funds or accounts managed, advised and/or controlled by HPS and MDP. As of the date of this offering memorandum, 31.15% of the voting interests in Tara Topco Limited are owned by funds managed, advised and/or controlled by HPS or its affiliates, 67.48% of the voting interests are owned by entities affiliated with MDP and the remaining 1.37% of voting interests are held by other minority shareholders. See “Management—Management Equity Interests.” HPS Investment Partners is a leading global investment firm that seeks to provide creative capital solutions and generate attractive risk-adjusted returns for our clients. We manage various strategies across the capital structure that include syndicated leveraged loans and high yield bonds to privately negotiated senior secured debt and mezzanine investments, asset-based leasing and private equity. The scale and breadth of our platform offers the flexibility to invest in companies large and small, through standard or customized solutions. At our core, we share a common thread of intellectual rigor and discipline that enables us to create value for our clients, who have entrusted us with approximately $108 billion of assets under management as of December 2023. MDP, based in Chicago, is a leading private equity investment firm. Since its formation in 1992, MDP has raised eight funds with aggregate capital of approximately $28 billion and has completed investments in more than 160 companies. MDP invests across a broad spectrum of industries, including: technology and government; basic industries; financial and transaction services; and health care. A flexible investment approach, encompassing both buyout and growth equity investments and a focus on upper middle market and middle market companies have been and continue to be key tenets of MDP’s investment strategy. 159 -----

Section Title: RELATED PARTY TRANSACTIONS
Subsection Title: Management Equity Interests
Subsubsection Text: In 2022 and 2023, we introduced two new management incentive plan schemes – both schemes are equity-settled share-based payment schemes. See note 31 of Ardonagh 2022 Financial Statements for the status of share based payments as of December 31, 2022. See also “Management—Management _Equity Interests.”_

Section Title: RELATED PARTY TRANSACTIONS
Subsection Title: Ankura Trust Company
Subsubsection Text: Ankura Trust Company, LLC is an affiliate of the Ardonagh Group, as our largest shareholders, investment funds managed by MDP, are indirect equity holders of, and indirectly control, Ankura Trust Company, LLC, which is the Trustee, Security Agent, Registrar, Dollar Paying Agent and Transfer Agent. Additionally, investment funds managed by HPS, our second largest shareholders, have a minority, non-controlling interest in, and are debt investors in, Ankura Trust Company, LLC. See “Risk _Factors—Risks Related to the Notes, the Note Guarantees and the Collateral—The interests of our principal shareholders may conflict with your interests.”_ 160 -----

Section Title: RELATED PARTY TRANSACTIONS
Subsubsection Text: In the ordinary course of business activities, we may enter into agreements and transactions with companies within our group, and related parties may provide lending, advisory or investment services to the Ardonagh Group from time to time, and may receive customary fees and reimbursement of costs in respect thereof. All sales to and purchases of services from related parties are conducted on an arm’s length basis. We believe these agreements are on terms no more favorable to the related parties or our affiliates and are comparable to those currently contracted with unrelated third-party suppliers and service providers. As at September 30, 2023, the Ardonagh Group had related party debtors of £129.1 million and related party creditors of £8.9 million. Of these balances, Tara Topco Limited accounts for £128.0 million of the related party debtor balance and all of the related party creditor balance. The balances arise from transactions where amounts are paid or received by Ardonagh on behalf of Tara Topco Limited. The majority of the related party debtor from Tara Topco Limited relates to non-current term loans. Moreover and from time to time, our shareholders, or affiliates thereof, may also buy a portion of the Notes in the open market or otherwise. In addition, one or more of the shareholders of the Issuer or its or their respective affiliates may be lenders under the Secured Credit Facilities or provide other lending, advisory or investment services to the Ardonagh Group from time to time, and may receive customary fees and reimbursement of costs in respect thereof.

Section Title: DESCRIPTION OF OTHER INDEBTEDNESS AND FINANCING ARRANGEMENTS
Subsection Title: Senior Secured Credit Facilities Agreement
Subsubsection Text: The Company is party to a senior secured credit facilities agreement originally dated June 26, 2020, with, among others, Ares Management Limited as the mandated lead arranger, sole physical bookrunner, administrative agent and security agent, the Joint Bookrunners as defined therein and the Original Lenders thereunder (as most recently amended and restated on 9 January 2023 and as further amended and/or restated from time to time) (the “Senior Secured Credit Facilities Agreement”). The Senior Secured Credit Facilities Agreement provides for senior secured term loan facilities in principal amounts equal to €180,000,000 (“Facility B1 (EUR)”), £1,412,837,837.84 (“Facility B1

Section Title: DESCRIPTION OF OTHER INDEBTEDNESS AND FINANCING ARRANGEMENTS
Subsubsection Text: The proceeds of utilizations made under the Facility B1 were applied towards refinancing certain indebtedness of the Borrower Group outstanding on or about 14 July 2020. The proceeds of utilizations made under Facility B2, Facility B3, Facility B4 and Facility B5 were used for purposes substantially similar to those described below in respect of Facility B6 and satisfying transaction costs. The undrawn Facility B6 commitments may be utilized by the Company and any additional borrower incorporated in the United Kingdom and tax resident in and only in the United Kingdom. The proceeds of any loan under Facility B6 may be applied in or towards (directly or indirectly) financing or refinancing any (i) capital expenditure and expenditure in respect of income hires; (ii) permitted acquisitions, investments (other than investing directly in cash or cash equivalent investments) and/or 161 ----- joint ventures; (iii) operational restructurings and reorganization requirements of the Borrower Group; (iv) arrangement fees, original issue discount, ticking fees, commitment fees and/or other financing fees required to be paid in connection with Facility B6; (v) any other purpose contemplated by the Tax Structure Memorandum; (vi) fees, costs and/or expenses payable in connection with any of the foregoing; and/or (vii) repayment of any Super Senior Revolving Facility utilizations or other revolving debt or replacement cash of the Borrower Group or any acquisition target used for the purpose of any other foregoing, provided that to the extent that such amounts refinance capital expenditure or permitted acquisitions, investments and/or joint ventures and/or operational restructurings and reorganization requirements of the Borrower Group originally funded from other sources pursuant paragraphs (i) and/or (ii) and/or (iii) above, such refinancing must take place within six (6) months thereof and such amounts shall not be used to fund working capital requirements, increase cash held by a member of the Borrower Group (subject to certain exceptions) or to fund an investment in cash equivalent investments. Facility B6 may be utilized in U.S. dollars, euros (provided that not greater than 50% of the commitments under Facility B6 may be utilized in euros). The Super Senior Revolving Facility may be utilized by the Company and any additional borrower incorporated in the United Kingdom (or any jurisdiction or political sub-division thereof), Ireland, Delaware or New York or any other jurisdiction approved by all the lenders under the Super Senior Revolving Facility (acting reasonably). The Super Senior Revolving Facility may be applied in or towards (directly or indirectly): (i) financing or refinancing the general corporate purposes and/or working capital requirements of the Borrower Group and/or (ii) any other purpose contemplated by the Tax Structure Memorandum. The Super Senior Revolving Facility may be utilized in sterling, euros, U.S. dollars, Canadian dollars and certain other currencies readily available in the relevant interbank market (subject to obtaining the consent of all the relevant Super Senior Revolving Facility lenders) by the drawing of cash advances, the issue of letters of credit and ancillary facilities (on a bilateral and fronted basis).

Section Title: DESCRIPTION OF OTHER INDEBTEDNESS AND FINANCING ARRANGEMENTS
Subsubsection Text: Each of the Senior Secured Term Facilities (other than Facility B6) has been utilized in full prior to the date hereof. Facility B6 was originally available for the period from (and including) 23 June 2023 to 23 December 2023. Pursuant to an amendment letter dated 24 November 2023, the availability period in respect of the Facility B6 commitments which remained undrawn at such times was extended to end on 31 March 2024. The remaining Facility B6 commitments are only be available to be utilized if (pro forma for such utilization and the application of the proceeds thereof) the Consolidated Senior Net Leverage Ratio (as defined below) on the applicable date of determination does not exceed 6.50:1. The Super Senior Revolving Facility will be available for the period from (and including) 14 July 2020 to (and including) the maturity date of the Super Senior Revolving Facility, being 14 January 2026.

Section Title: DESCRIPTION OF OTHER INDEBTEDNESS AND FINANCING ARRANGEMENTS
Subsubsection Text: Utilizations of the Secured Credit Facilities are subject to customary conditions precedent.

Section Title: DESCRIPTION OF OTHER INDEBTEDNESS AND FINANCING ARRANGEMENTS
Subsubsection Text: Loans under the Secured Credit Facilities will initially bear cash interest at rates per annum equal to EURIBOR for loans denominated in euro, CDOR for loans denominated in Canadian dollars, Daily Compounded SONIA for loans denominated in sterling and Term SOFR for loans denominated in U.S. dollars (in each case subject to agreed benchmark rate floors), plus an applicable margin and in respect of loans denominated in sterling and U.S. dollars certain credit adjustment spread. In the case of the Senior Secured Term Facilities, the applicable margin will be subject to a margin ratchet based on the ratio of consolidated net debt to consolidated pro forma EBITDA (“Consolidated Net Leverage 162 -----

Section Title: DESCRIPTION OF OTHER INDEBTEDNESS AND FINANCING ARRANGEMENTS
Subsubsection Text: (“Facility B3 (USD)”), €240,000,000 (“Facility B4”), $365,000,000 (“Facility B5”) and $460,000,000 (“Facility B6”). As of the date hereof, each of the senior secured term loan facilities described in the foregoing sentence (the “Senior Secured Term Facilities”) has been utilized in full by the Company as borrower in the currency in which such facility is denominated, other than (i) Facility B3 (GBP) has been utilized in full in euros in the amount of €187,336,217.87 and (ii) Facility B6 has been utilized pursuant to loans with principal amounts of $130,000,000 and €145,776,000, and the remainder of the Facility B6 commitments remain undrawn. In addition, Senior Secured Credit Facilities Agreement provides for a super senior multicurrency revolving credit facility in a principal amount of up to £191.5 million, which is as of the date of this offering memorandum undrawn (the “Super Senior Revolving Facility” and, together with the Senior Secured Term Facilities, the “Secured Credit Facilities”). The Senior Secured Credit Facilities Agreement also includes (in addition to other permissions under the limitation on indebtedness covenant) the ability (without double counting against the limitation on indebtedness covenant) to incur additional indebtedness by way of one or more uncommitted additional facilities within the Senior Secured Credit Facilities Agreement subject to certain customary conditions, provided that no such additional term loan facility may be utilized in U.S. dollars or euros unless Facility B6 has been utilized and/or cancelled in full.

Section Title: DESCRIPTION OF OTHER INDEBTEDNESS AND FINANCING ARRANGEMENTS
Subsection Title: Secured Net Leverage Ratio”).
Subsubsection Text: The loans made under the Senior Secured Term Facilities are required to be repaid in full on their maturity date, being July 14, 2026. No scheduled amortization applies to any Senior Secured Term Facility. In respect of the Super Senior Revolving Facility, each advance will be repaid on the last day of the interest period relating thereto, subject to an ability to roll over cash drawings. All outstanding amounts under the Super Senior Revolving Facility are required to be repaid on the maturity date of the Super Senior Revolving Facility, being January 14, 2026. Amounts repaid by the borrowers on loans made under the Super Senior Revolving Facility may be reborrowed, subject to certain conditions.

Section Title: DESCRIPTION OF OTHER INDEBTEDNESS AND FINANCING ARRANGEMENTS
Subsection Title: Secured Net Leverage Ratio”).
Subsubsection Text: The Senior Secured Credit Facilities Agreement permits voluntary prepayments to be made. The call protection periods applicable to the Senior Secured Term Facilities have expired, such that the Secured Credit Facilities may be voluntarily prepaid at par plus accrued interest and (in the respect of loans which bear interest by reference to term rates, other than Term SOFR) customary break costs when prepayment is made other than on the last day of an interest period. Upon the occurrence of a change of control (as defined in the Senior Secured Credit Facilities Agreement) or a sale of all or substantially all the businesses and assets of the Borrower Group, each lender shall be entitled to require prepayment of its commitments within a prescribed time period. A change of control shall include: - at any time prior to a Listing, the initial investors cease (directly or indirectly) to (i) have the power (whether by way of ownership of shares, proxy, contract, agency or otherwise) to appoint directors or other equivalent officers of the Company which control the majority of the votes which may be cast at a meeting of the board of directors of the Company or (ii) own and control 163 ----- (whether by way of ownership of shares, proxy, contract, agency or otherwise) more than fifty per cent. (50%) of the issued voting share capital of the Company or (iii) have the ability to appoint directors which control the majority of the votes of the board of directors (or equivalent body) of the Company; - upon and at any time after a Listing, (i) the initial investors cease (directly or indirectly) to beneficially own and control (whether by way of ownership of shares, proxy, contract, agency or otherwise) more than thirty per cent. (30%) of the issued voting share capital of the Company or (ii) any person (other than the Initial Investors) or persons acting in concert (other than with any Sponsor Affiliate) (A) owns (directly or indirectly) or controls more voting rights in the Company than the Initial Investors; or (B) gains the ability to appoint directors of the Company and as a result gains control over the majority of votes on the board of directors (or equivalent body) of the Company; or - Ardonagh Midco 2 ceases to directly own and control all of the issued share capital of the Company. The Senior Secured Credit Facilities Agreement will require mandatory prepayment in full or in part in certain circumstances, including: - on an initial public offering which does not constitute a change of control (with the percentage of proceeds to be prepaid subject to Consolidated Senior Net Leverage Ratio); and - from certain net cash proceeds received by the Borrower Group from certain asset disposals and insurance claims, to the extent not otherwise applied for a permitted purpose and required to be applied in prepayment of the Secured Credit Facilities and subject to a de minimis amount (with the percentage of proceeds to be prepaid subject to Consolidated Senior Net Leverage Ratio).

Section Title: DESCRIPTION OF OTHER INDEBTEDNESS AND FINANCING ARRANGEMENTS
Subsection Title: Secured Net Leverage Ratio”).
Subsubsection Text: The Company was permitted (in its sole discretion) to elect that up to 27.5% of the margin payable on any Facility B1 Loan or Facility B2 Loan on the last day of any interest period commencing prior to 19 August 2021 be capitalized at the percentage rate per annum determined in accordance with the margin ratchet described above for the applicable Senior Secured Term Facility loan plus 0.75% per annum on the last day of the applicable interest period and thereafter treated as part of the principal amount of the applicable loan. The Company exercised this option to capitalize certain interest payable on certain of the Senior Secured Term Facility loans prior to such date. A commitment fee will be payable on the aggregate undrawn and uncancelled amount of Facility B6 and the Super Senior Revolving Facility during the availability period applicable to Facility B6 or the Super Senior Revolving Facility (as applicable) at a rate of 30% of the applicable margin for Facility B6 or the Super Senior Revolving Facility (as applicable). Commitment fees will be payable quarterly in arrears (unless otherwise elected by the Company), on the last day of the availability period applicable to the relevant facility and, if cancelled, on the cancelled amount of the relevant lender’s commitment at the time the cancellation is effective. Default interest will be calculated as an additional 1% on the defaulted amount.

Subsubsection Text: The Senior Secured Credit Facilities Agreement contains certain incurrence covenants and related definitions (with, in each case, certain adjustments), including, but not limited to, (i) limitations on indebtedness; (ii) limitations on restricted payments; (iii) limitations on liens; (iv) limitations on sale of assets and subsidiary stock; (v) limitations on affiliate transactions; (vi) merger and consolidation – company; and (vii) merger and consolidation – borrower and guarantors. 165 ----- In addition, the Senior Secured Credit Facilities Agreement also requires the Company and certain of its restricted subsidiaries to observe certain other customary positive and negative covenants, subject to certain exceptions and grace periods, including, but not limited to, covenants relating to: (i) authorizations; (ii) compliance with laws; (iii) pari passu ranking; (iv) insurances; (v) payment of taxes; (vi) pension schemes; (vii) compliance with certain environmental laws; (viii) acquisition agreements; (ix) maintenance of centre of main interests; (x) provision of guarantees and security; (xi) further assurance; (xii) accession to the Intercreditor Agreement; (xiii) controlled debt; (xiv) compliance with sanctions, anti-corruption laws and anti-money laundering laws; (xv) access; (xvi) preservation of assets; (xvii) margin regulations; (xviii) qualifying listings and ratings trigger; (xix) annual, quarterly and monthly financial statements; (xx) compliance certificates; (xix) annual budget; (xxii) presentations; (xxiii) year-end; (xxiv) notification of event of default; and (xxv) “know your customer” checks.

Subsubsection Text: guarantees and security interests were released pursuant to certain deeds of release dated 19 August 2021. (10.00%) or more of consolidated pro forma EBITDA of the Borrower Group or (ii) is not Ardonagh Advisory Broking Holdings Limited (formerly known as Ardonagh Advisory Holdings Limited), Ardonagh Specialty Holdings Limited, Atlanta Investment Holdings 3 Limited, Nevada 5 Topco Limited or a subsidiary of the foregoing and represents (on an unconsolidated basis) five per cent. (5.00%) or more of consolidated pro forma EBITDA of the Borrower Group, the holding company of such member of the Borrower Group shall grant security over its shares in the capital of such member of the Borrower Group (to the extent not already subject to such security) within ninety (90) days of the date by which the relevant annual financial statements or quarterly financial statements evidencing that such member of the Borrower Group satisfied the applicable foregoing requirements were required to be delivered under the terms of the Senior Secured Credit Facilities Agreement. The provision and the terms of the security and guarantees set forth above will in all cases be subject to the Agreed Security Principles and certain other limitations and are at all times and in all cases subject to the requirements of applicable law and the other matters set forth in the Senior Secured Credit Facilities Agreement. _Representations and Warranties_ The Senior Secured Credit Facilities Agreement contains certain representations and warranties (subject to certain agreed qualifications and with certain representations being repeated), including but not limited to: (i) status, binding obligations, non-conflict with other obligations, power and authority, validity and admissibility in evidence, governing law and enforcement, consents, filings and laws applicable to operations and pari passu ranking; (ii) no insolvency, no litigation, environmental laws, taxation, and filing; (iii) no default, financial statements, group structure, and no misleading information in relation to the financial model relating to the Borrower Group and certain diligence reports provided; (iv) no liens, guarantees or indebtedness, except as permitted; (v) legal ownership; (vi) intellectual property and pension schemes; (vii) acquisition documents and investment companies; and (viii) compliance with sanctions, anti-corruption laws and anti-money laundering laws. Certain representations and warranties were made on the date of signing the Senior Secured Credit Facilities Agreement and on the date of first utilisation thereunder and/or completion date of certain acquisitions contemplated thereby and are required to be repeated on the date of each subsequent utilization, on the first day of each interest period and at certain other times.

Section Title: DESCRIPTION OF OTHER INDEBTEDNESS AND FINANCING ARRANGEMENTS
Subsection Title: Covenant” and, together with the Term Facility Financial Covenant, the “Financial Covenants”).
Subsubsection Text: The Senior Secured Credit Facilities Agreement provides for substantially the same events of default as under the Notes. In addition, the Senior Secured Credit Facilities Agreement provides for additional events of default, subject to customary materiality qualifications and grace periods, including, but not limited to, (i) breach of the Financial Covenants, provided that, in the event of such breach, only a majority of the lenders with the benefit of the relevant Financial Covenant will be entitled to take enforcement action; (ii) inaccuracy of a representation or statement when made; (iii) invalidity and unlawfulness; (iv) repudiation or rescission of the Secured Credit Facilities financing documents; and (v) material failure to comply with the Intercreditor Agreement.

Section Title: DESCRIPTION OF OTHER INDEBTEDNESS AND FINANCING ARRANGEMENTS
Subsection Title: Covenant” and, together with the Term Facility Financial Covenant, the “Financial Covenants”).
Subsubsection Text: The Senior Secured Credit Facilities Agreement and any non-contractual obligations arising out of or in connection with it, are governed by, construed in accordance with and will be enforced in accordance with English law (other than the Cayman Islands ESM which is governed by Cayman Islands law) although the information undertakings, restrictive covenants, events of default and related New York 166 ----- law definitions of the Senior Secured Credit Facilities Agreement and such non-contractual obligations arising out of or in connection with such information undertakings, restrictive covenants, events of default and related New York law definitions will be interpreted in accordance with New York law (without prejudice to the fact that the Senior Secured Credit Facilities Agreement is governed by English law).

Section Title: DESCRIPTION OF OTHER INDEBTEDNESS AND FINANCING ARRANGEMENTS
Subsection Title: Covenant” and, together with the Term Facility Financial Covenant, the “Financial Covenants”).
Subsubsection Text: The Borrower Group is currently in negotiations with certain financial institutions to establish certain additional facilities under and otherwise amend the Senior Secured Credit Facilities Agreement for the purpose of (among other things) (i) refinancing any amount of the Senior Secured Term Facilities not otherwise repaid or prepaid from the proceeds of the Notes with new senior secured term loan facilities (the “New Term Facilities”), (ii) establishing new delayed draw senior secured term loan commitments for purposes substantially consistent with the purposes for which Facility B6 may be applied (the “New

Section Title: DESCRIPTION OF OTHER INDEBTEDNESS AND FINANCING ARRANGEMENTS
Subsection Title: Covenant” and, together with the Term Facility Financial Covenant, the “Financial Covenants”).
Subsubsection Text: The Senior Secured Credit Facilities Agreement contains an equity cure provision enabling the shareholders of the Company to make shareholder injections by way of debt and/or equity to the Company to (i) increase the consolidated pro forma EBITDA under the Senior Secured Credit Facilities Agreement (an “EBITDA Cure”) or (ii) decrease consolidated net debt as defined in the Senior Secured Credit Facilities Agreement. The equity cure right may not be exercised on more than five (5) occasions during the term of the Secured Credit Facilities and may not be utilized on more than two (2) occasions during any four (4) consecutive financial quarters and the EBITDA Cure right may not be exercised on more than one (1) occasion during the term of the Secured Credit Facilities, and the amount of any EBITDA Cure may not exceed the amount required to make the relevant cure.

Section Title: DESCRIPTION OF OTHER INDEBTEDNESS AND FINANCING ARRANGEMENTS
Subsection Title: CAR Facilities” and, together with the New Term Facilities, the “New Senior Secured Term Facilities”) and (iii) increasing the total commitments under the Super Senior Revolving Facility and
Subsubsection Text: extending its maturity date. The terms of the New Senior Secured Term Facilities are proposed to be substantially similar to the terms of the Senior Secured Term Facilities, other than (i) the New Senior Secured Term Facilities are proposed to be denominated in U.S. dollars, euros and Australian dollars, (ii) the maturity date of the New Senior Secured Term Facilities is proposed to be the date falling seven years after first utilization of the New Senior Secured Term Facilities, (iii) the interest rate margin is proposed to be 5-5.25% and the benchmark rate floors and commitment fees applicable to the New Senior Secured Term Facilities are proposed to be lower than the corresponding amounts under the Senior Secured Term Facilities and no margin ratchet, PIK-toggle option or credit adjustment spread is proposed to apply to the New Senior Secured Term Facilities, (iv) subject to certain exceptions (A) a prepayment premium of 2.00% of the amount prepaid is proposed to apply to any mandatory prepayment as a result of a change of control or voluntary prepayment under any New Senior Secured Term Facilities made on or prior to the first anniversary of first utilization of the New Senior Secured Term Facilities and (B) a prepayment premium of 1.00% of the amount prepaid is proposed to apply to any voluntary prepayment under any New Senior Secured Term Facilities as a result of a repricing event after the first anniversary but on or prior to the second anniversary of first utilization of the New Senior Secured Term Facilities, (v) the New Senior Secured Term Facilities are proposed to be utilized by certain newly established subsidiaries of the Company organized under the laws of the Netherlands, Delaware and Australia and (vi) the New Senior Secured Term Facilities are not proposed to benefit from the Term Facility Financial Covenant or any other financial maintenance covenant. The terms of the amended Super Senor Revolving Facility are proposed to be substantially similar to the terms of the current Super Senior Revolving Facility, other than (i) the total commitments under the Super Senior Revolving Facility are proposed to be increased to between £240-300 million, drawable in sterling, euros or U.S. dollars, (ii) any member of the Borrower Group organized under laws of Australia, England, Ireland, Jersey, the Netherlands, the United Kingdom, Delaware or New York (or any jurisdiction or political sub-division of the foregoing) or any other jurisdiction agreed with all the lenders of the amended Super Senior Revolving Facility is proposed to be permitted to become a borrower of the amended Super Senior Revolving Facility, (iii) the maturity date of the amended Super Senior Revolving Facility is proposed to be 14 January 2029, (iv) the interest rate margin, benchmark rate floors and commitment fees applicable to the amended Super Senior Revolving Facility are proposed to be substantially as per the current Super Senior Revolving Facility, provided that no credit adjustment spread is proposed to apply, (iv) the Revolving Facility Financial Covenant is proposed to be amended to be set at a Consolidated Senior Secured Net Leverage Ratio of 9.50:1 for life and to be tested only after an agreed holiday period and only if the aggregate principal amount of loans outstanding under all applicable revolving credit facilities (net of cash and cash equivalent investments of the Borrower Group) exceeds 40% of all applicable revolving credit facilities on the relevant quarter 167 ----- date (the “Test Condition”) and (v) the cure provisions in respect of any failure to comply with the Revolving Facility Financial Covenant are proposed to be amended to (A) include deemed cures in the event that (prior to an acceleration) the Test Condition ceases to be satisfied, (B) remove the cap on net debt cures, (C) increase the number of permitted EBITDA Cures to five over the life of the amended Super Senior Revolving Facility, (D) amend the consecutive cure restrictions to provide only that EBITDA Cures may not be made more than twice in any three consecutive quarter dates and (E) remove the restriction on EBITDA overcures. It is proposed that certain other amendments will be made to the Senior Secured Credit Facilities Agreement, including for the purpose of amending certain of the negative covenants and financial definitions to reflect or more closely align to the corresponding provisions of the Notes and to permit the incurrence of the Senior Secured Notes. It is further proposed that the Security Agent under and as defined in the Senior Secured Credit Facilities Agreement may resign and be replaced by Ankura Trust Company, LLC. The commitments, refinancings, amendments and transactions described above are subject to change and there is no certainty that some or all of these commitments, refinancings, amendments and/or will take effect or occur prior to the issuance of the Notes or at all.

Section Title: DESCRIPTION OF OTHER INDEBTEDNESS AND FINANCING ARRANGEMENTS
Subsection Title: Super Senior Letters of Credit
Subsubsection Text: National Westminster Bank Plc has issued two standby letters of credit at the request of Geo Underwriting Services Limited in respect of its regulatory capital requirements. These face values of these standby letters of credit are £3,000,000 and £2,200,000, they were issued on 25 November 2022 and 28 November 2022 respectively and they each expire on 4 November 2025 These letters of credit have been designed as Permitted Super Senior Secured Facilities Agreements under the Intercreditor Agreement, such that the issuing bank in respect of such letters of credit is entitled to receive proceeds from an enforcement over the Collateral (or a distressed disposal in lieu thereof) in priority to the holders to the Senior Secured Notes.

Section Title: DESCRIPTION OF OTHER INDEBTEDNESS AND FINANCING ARRANGEMENTS
Subsection Title: Australian Local Facility
Subsubsection Text: On January 25, 2023, Ardonagh Finco Pty Ltd entered into a facility in aggregate principal amount of AUD 200 million with Macquarie Principal Finance Pty Ltd and Macquarie Syndication (No. 12) Pty Limited as agent and Macquarie Syndication (No. 12) Pty as security trustee (as amended and/or restated, the “Australian Local Facility”) in connection with the acquisition of Envest Pty Ltd. The Australian Local Facility matures in 2028. We intend to refinance the Australian Local Facility in connection with the Transactions. See “Use of Proceeds.” We require third-party permission to refinance the Australian Local Facility and are in the process of securing such permission.

Section Title: DESCRIPTION OF OTHER INDEBTEDNESS AND FINANCING ARRANGEMENTS
Subsection Title: Intercreditor Agreement
Subsubsection Text: To establish the relative rights of certain of our creditors under our financing arrangements, the Senior Secured Notes Issuer, the Senior Secured Notes Trustee, the Senior Notes Issuer and the Senior Notes Trustee will each accede (the “Accession”) to the Intercreditor Agreement between, among others, the Company, the Guarantors, the agent, arrangers and lenders under the Senior Secured Credit Facilities Agreement and the security agent for the Secured Parties other than the Topco Creditors (the “Priority Security Agent” and, together with the Topco Security Agent, the “Security Agents”). It is proposed that on or prior to the Escrow Release Date Ares Management Limited will resign as Priority Security Agent and be replaced by Ankura Trust Company, LLC (and assign the security interests granted to it to Ankura Trust Company, LLC). 168 ----- By accepting a Note, holders of the Notes will be deemed to have agreed to, and accepted the terms and conditions of, the Intercreditor Agreement and to have instructed the Trustee and the security agent to accede to the Intercreditor Agreement. The Intercreditor Agreement is governed by English law and sets out various matters governing the relationship of the creditors to our group including the relative ranking of certain debt of the Issuer, the Guarantors and any other person that becomes party to the Intercreditor Agreement as a Debtor or Third Party Security Provider, when payments can be made in respect of debt of the Debtors or Third Party Security Providers, when enforcement action can be taken in respect of that debt, the terms pursuant to which certain of that debt will be subordinated upon the occurrence of certain insolvency events and turnover provisions and provisions related to the enforcement of shared security. The following description is a summary of certain provisions contained in the Intercreditor Agreement. It does not restate the Intercreditor Agreement in its entirety and we urge you to read that document because it, and not the discussion that follows, defines certain rights of the holders of the Senior Secured Notes and of the Senior Secured Notes Trustee and certain rights of the holders of the Senior Notes and of the Senior Notes Trustee. Capitalized terms used but not defined herein have the meanings given to them in the Intercreditor Agreement. For the purposes of this description: “Senior Secured Group” shall mean the Company and any of its Restricted Subsidiaries. References to the “Senior Secured Notes” shall include (upon Accession) the Senior Secured Notes described in this offering memorandum and any other notes, securities or other debt instruments issued or to be issued by or in relation to which a New Debt Financing (as defined below) which are designated by the Company as Senior Secured Notes. References to the “Topco Notes” shall include (upon Accession) the Senior Notes described in this offering memorandum and any other notes, securities or other debt instruments issued or to be issued by or in relation to which a New Debt Financing (as defined below) which are designated by the Company as Topco Notes. The Intercreditor Agreement uses the term “Senior Secured Notes Liabilities” to refer to (upon Accession) the Senior Secured Notes and certain other indebtedness of the Senior Secured Notes Issuer and “Senior Secured Notes Trustee” to refer to the Senior Secured Notes Trustee. The Intercreditor Agreement uses the term “Topco” to refer to the Senior Notes Issuer, “Topco Notes Liabilities” to refer to (upon Accession) the Senior Notes and certain other indebtedness of the Senior Notes Issuer and “Topco Notes Trustee” to refer to the Senior Notes Trustee.

Section Title: DESCRIPTION OF OTHER INDEBTEDNESS AND FINANCING ARRANGEMENTS
Subsection Title: Intercreditor Agreement
Subsubsection Text: _Priority of Debts_ The Intercreditor Agreement provides that the liabilities owed by the Company and each other debtor under the Intercreditor Agreement (together, the “Debtors”) (other than the Issuer and any member of the Senior Secured Group which is designated as a Topco Borrower under the Intercreditor Agreement provided that no such designation shall be made until the Senior Secured Liabilities under the Senior Secured Credit Facilities Agreement have been discharged in full (a “Topco Borrower”)) shall rank in right of priority and payment in the following order and are postponed and subordinated to any prior ranking liabilities as follows: 169 ----- (i) first, liabilities owed to (A) the lenders, issuing banks and ancillary lenders in relation to the Senior Secured Credit Facilities Agreement or any future senior secured facilities agreements (a “Permitted Senior Secured Facilities Agreement”) (to the extent it holds senior commitments) (the “Senior Lender Liabilities” and creditors thereof being the “Senior Lenders”), (B) the lenders, issuing banks, and ancillary lenders in relation to the Senior Secured Credit Facilities Agreement or any future super senior facilities agreement (a “Permitted Super Senior Secured

Section Title: DESCRIPTION OF OTHER INDEBTEDNESS AND FINANCING ARRANGEMENTS
Subsection Title: Liabilities” and together with the Second Lien Lender Liabilities, the “Second Lien Liabilities”),
Subsubsection Text: The Intercreditor Agreement provides that the Transaction Security shall rank and secure the applicable secured obligations (but only to the extent that such Transaction Security is expressed to secure those liabilities) in the following order: (i) first, the Senior Lender Liabilities, the Super Senior Lender Liabilities, the Cash Management Facility Liabilities, the Hedging Liabilities and the Senior Secured Notes Liabilities (and, in each case, the Agent Liabilities and liabilities owing to any arranger in respect thereof) pari passu and without any preference between them; (ii) second, the Second Lien Lender Liabilities and the Second Lien Notes Liabilities pari passu and without any preference between them; and (iii) third (to the extent of Topco Shared Security), the Topco Liabilities pari passu and without any preference between them, in each case, as applicable, subject to the provisions set out under “—Application of Proceeds” below. For the avoidance of doubt, to the extent any facility agreement or other document or instrument (the “Applicable Finance Document”) is intended to include one or more senior facilities and one or more super senior facilities, any term of the Intercreditor Agreement intended to apply in respect of senior facilities (and the related documents and persons) and/or the super senior facilities (and the related documents and persons) shall apply (i) in respect of terms relating to both senior facilities and super senior facilities, to all the senior facilities and super senior facilities under the Applicable Finance Documents (and the related documents and persons); (ii) in respect of terms relating only to senior facilities (and not super senior facilities), to all the senior facilities under the Applicable Finance Document (and the related documents and persons) and not to any super senior facility under the Applicable Finance Document (and not to the related documents and persons, as they relate to such 171 ----- super senior facilities and not any senior facility) or (iii) in respect of terms relating only to super senior facilities (and not senior facilities), to all the super senior facilities under the Applicable Finance Document (and the related documents and persons) and not to any senior facility under the Applicable Finance Document (and not to the related documents and persons, as they relate to such senior facilities and not any super senior facility). For the purposes of this description only: “Debt Documents” means the Intercreditor Agreement and the documents creating or evidencing the Cash Management Facility Liabilities, the Hedging Liabilities, the Second Lien Liabilities, the Senior Secured Liabilities, the Senior Secured Notes Proceeds Loan Liabilities, the Topco Liabilities, the Topco Proceeds Loan Liabilities, the unsecured liabilities of any unsecured creditors who are party to the Intercreditor Agreement, the Subordinated Liabilities and the Intra- Group Liabilities (each as defined in this description) and any other document designated as such by the Priority Security Agent or the Topco Security Agent and the Company. “Finance Documents” means the Senior Secured Credit Facilities Agreement, any Permitted Senior Secured Facilities Agreement, any Permitted Super Senior Secured Facilities Agreement, the indenture in respect of any Senior Secured Notes, any Second Lien Facility Agreement, the indenture in respect of any Second Lien Notes, the facility agreement or other document or instrument documenting any Topco Facility, the indenture in respect of any Topco Notes and any document designated by the Company as an unsecured finance document under and in accordance with the Intercreditor Agreement. “Secured Creditors” means the Senior Secured Creditors, the Second Lien Creditors and the Topco Creditors (each as defined below). “Secured Debt Documents” means the documents relating to the Senior Secured Liabilities, the Second Lien Liabilities, the Topco Liabilities and the Hedging Liabilities. “Third Party Security Provider” means the Issuer and any person that has provided Transaction Security (including Topco Shared Security) but is not a Debtor in respect of any direct borrowing or guarantee liabilities of the applicable secured obligations to which that Transaction Security relates and which is designated by the Company (in its discretion). “Topco Independent Transaction Security” refers to security (other than Transaction Security) which in relation to a Topco Borrower or any member of the Senior Secured Group that directly holds shares in a Topco Borrower or any such person that is not a member of the Senior Secured Group which is designated as such by the Company (in its discretion) (together, the “Topco Independent Obligors”) (i) is created, or expressed to be created, in favor of the Topco Security Agent as agent or trustee for the other Topco Secured Parties (or a class of Topco Secured Parties); (ii) in the case of any jurisdiction in which effective security cannot be granted in favour of the Topco Security Agent as agent or trustee for the other Topco Secured Parties (or a class of Topco Secured Parties), is created, or expressed to be created, in favor of (x) all the Topco Secured Parties (or a class of Topco Secured Parties); or (y) the Topco Security Agent under a parallel debt and/or joint and several creditorship or similar structure for the benefit of all the Secured Parties (or a class of Secured Parties). In the case of a Topco Independent Obligor which is a member of the Senior Secured Group and a direct shareholder of a Topco Borrower, such security shall be limited to shares in and receivables owed to it by the relevant Topco Borrower which are not required to be subject to the Transaction Security pursuant to the Finance Documents. Topco Independent Transaction Security shall secure all liabilities and present and future obligations of each Topco Independent Obligor to the Topco Secured Parties under the Topco Finance Documents. “Topco Shared Security” refers to security at any time which is created, or expressed to be created, over any of the following (i) the shares in the Company held by any direct shareholder of the Company, (ii) all receivables owed by the Company to a Topco Investor, Subordinated Creditor or other holding company or shareholder of the Company (including any Topco Proceeds Loan and the Topco Proceeds 172 ----- Loan Liabilities, as applicable), (iii) the shares in any Topco Borrower which is a member of the Senior Secured Group, (iv) all receivables owed by a member of the Senior Secured Group under any Topco Proceeds Loan (or, in the case of a Topco Borrower which is a member of the Senior Secured Group, any Senior Secured Notes Proceeds Loan), (v) any escrow account relating to the proceeds of any Topco Liabilities and (vi) any other assets not falling within limbs (i) to (v) of this paragraph of a Topco Borrower, and (to the extent that the Company has confirmed to the Topco Security Agent that the granting of such security in favor of the Topco Shared Security Secured Obligations is not prohibited by the terms of any applicable prior ranking financing agreements) any other member of the Senior Secured Group, in each case designated as Topco Shared Security by the Company (in its discretion) in favor of the Topco Security Agent as agent or trustee for the other Secured Parties (or if such trustee arrangements are not legally possible, in favor of all the Secured Parties or in favor of the Topco Security Agent under a parallel debt or similar structure). Topco Shared Security shall secure all liabilities and present and future obligations of any member of the Senior Secured Group and at any time after the incurrence of any Topco Liabilities by a Topco Borrower that is not a member of the Senior Secured Group, such Topco Borrower and each of its Restricted Subsidiaries (the “Topco Group”), each Debtor and any Third Party Security Provider to the Secured Parties under the Secured Debt Documents. “Transaction Security” refers to security (from the Senior Secured Group, any Third Party Security Provider and Topco Shared Security (but excluding, for the avoidance of doubt, Topco Independent Transaction Security), as defined below) which (i) is created, or expressed to be created, in favor of the Priority Security Agent and the Topco Security Agent as agent or trustee for the other Secured Parties (or a class of Secured Parties) and (ii) in the case of any jurisdiction in which effective security cannot be granted in favor of the Priority Security Agent and the Topco Security Agent as agent or trustee for the Secured Parties (or a class of Secured Parties), is created, or expressed to be created, in favor of (x) all the Secured Parties (or a class of Secured Parties) or (y) the Priority Security Agent and the Topco Security Agent under a parallel debt and/or joint and several creditorship or similar structure for the benefit of all the Secured Parties (or a class of Secured Parties). Transaction Security which is not Topco Shared Security shall secure all liabilities and present and future obligations of the Debtors and Third Party Security Providers to the Secured Parties (other than the creditors under the Topco Liabilities (the “Topco Secured Parties”)) under the Debt Documents (other than the finance documents relating to the Topco Liabilities (the “Topco Finance Documents”)). Transaction Security which is Topco Shared Security shall secure all liabilities and present and future obligations of any member of the Topco Group, the Debtors and Third Party Security Providers to the Secured Parties under the Debt Documents (the “Topco Shared Security Obligations”). The Senior Secured Notes and Senior Secured Note Guarantees will be Senior Secured Notes Liabilities for the purposes of the Intercreditor Agreement and be designated as such on or prior to the Escrow Release Date. The Senior Notes and Senior Note Guarantees will be Topco Notes Liabilities for the purposes of the Intercreditor Agreement and be designated as such on or prior to the Escrow Release Date. On the Issue Date, no Second Lien Lender Liabilities or Second Lien Notes Liabilities will be outstanding. Such liabilities and liabilities in respect of other new debt financings may only be incurred and/or designated if not prohibited under the terms of the Debt Documents, including, without limitation, the covenants applicable to the Notes described under “Description of the Notes — Certain _Covenants.”_ 173 ----- _Guarantees and Security: Topco Creditors_ The Topco Creditors have the right to take, accept or receive the benefit of: (i) any Topco Shared Security from any member of the Senior Secured Group or from a Third Party Security Provider in respect of the Topco Liabilities if and to the extent legally possible and subject to any agreed security principles, at the same time it is also offered either: (A) to each Security Agent as agent or trustee for the applicable other Secured Parties (or applicable class thereof) in respect of their Liabilities; or (B) in the case of any jurisdiction in which effective security cannot be granted in favor of a Security Agent as agent or trustee for the Secured Parties (or applicable class thereof): (I) to the other Secured Parties (or applicable class thereof) in respect of their Liabilities; or (II) to each Security Agent under a parallel debt structure, joint and several creditor structure or agency structure for the benefit of the other Secured Parties (or applicable class thereof), and ranks in the same order of priority as described under “Priority of Security” above, provided that all amounts received or recovered by any Topco Creditor with respect to such Topco Shared Security are immediately paid to the Priority Security Agent for application as set out under “Application of Proceeds” below;
