Similar moratoria on enforcement and other action, which can be taken by creditors and other third parties generally apply in relation to a restructuring process under Part 5.3B of the Corporations Act, as apply under a voluntary administration. A restructuring proposal devised by the company is required to be put to creditors. If a majority in value of creditors accept the restructuring plan, it will bind the company and its unsecured creditors and, in certain circumstances, its secured creditors.

Section Title: CERTAIN INSOLVENCY LAW CONSIDERATIONS
Subsection Title: Guarantor”). Australian insolvency laws will be relevant upon the insolvency of this entity and the
Subsubsection Title: Summary of limitations on the validity and enforceability of Note Guarantee and security interests provided by Australian Guarantor under Australian law
Subsubsection Text: _General_ Under Australian law, the enforceability of the Note Guarantee and security interests provided by the Australian Guarantor is subject to various limitations, some of which are summarized below. _Breach of Directors’ Duties_ The decision to provide the Note Guarantee and/or security interests by the Australian Guarantor may be found to have been in breach of the duties owed by the directors of the Australian Guarantor, including the duty to act in good faith in the best interests of the Australian Guarantor, and for a proper purpose. If a Court were to find that the directors of the Australian Guarantor breached those duties in connection with providing the Note Guarantee and/or security interests it provided, in certain circumstances, they may become voidable. If the Note Guarantee from the Australian Guarantor is avoided, it is possible that holders of Notes would be left with a claim solely against the Issuer and the other Guarantors. _Personal Properties Securities Act 2009 (Cth)_ 498 ----- In Australia, the _Personal Properties Securities Act 2009 (Cth) (the “PPSA”) establishes a national system for the registration of security interests, a system of priority and other provisions, which will affect most collateral classes (described as “personal property” under the PPSA) other than interests in land, fixtures attached to land, statutory licenses and general law liens. Perfection of security interests granted by an Australian entity or granted by any entity over assets located in Australia, which (in each case) are deemed “personal property” for the purposes of the PPSA (“Australian PPSA Collateral”) is achieved through registration on a central register established under the PPSA and known as the Personal Property Securities Register (the “PPSR”), or the secured party having possession or control of Australian PPSA Collateral. Among other things, security interests perfected by control over certain financial assets (for example bank accounts held with an authorized deposit taking institution, shares and letters of credit), subject to limited exceptions, would rank in priority over prior registered secured interests (like those of the holders of Notes) regardless of notice. In certain circumstances, purchasers and lessees of Australian PPSA Collateral can acquire it free of a security interest even when they had notice of that security interest. Generally, where a security interest over personal property is granted by means of a security agreement, then (unless perfection occurs by possession or control), a failure to register that security interest on the PPSR within the first to occur of 20 business days after signing of the security agreement and the company entering into insolvency or, if later, at least six months before the commencement of a winding-up or administration of the grantor of that security interest, will result in that security interest vesting in the grantor, such that the secured party’s interest will in effect no longer exist and will not be enforceable. Also, the secured creditor’s priority may be adversely affected, as perfected security interests generally take priority over unperfected security interests and third parties leasing or taking transfer of the collateral will generally take free of all unperfected security interests. _Risks Arising in a Winding-Up Voidable transactions_ If the Australian Guarantor is subject to a winding up, the liquidator may apply to an Australian Court for orders that the entry into the Note Guarantee and/or security interests by the Australian Guarantor or a transaction in connection with the Note Guarantee and/or security interests by the Australian Guarantor constitutes a voidable transaction and should be set aside. The most commonly brought voidable transactions claims include the following: - an “unfair preference,” (sections 588FA and 588FC of the Corporations Act) being a transaction between the company and a creditor carried out at a time when the company was insolvent (or the company became insolvent as a result of the transaction) that results in the creditor receiving from the company, in respect of an unsecured debt, more than the creditor would receive on a winding up of the company if the transaction were set aside; - an “uncommercial transaction,” (sections 588FB and 588FC of the Corporations Act) being a transaction carried on at a time the company was insolvent (or the company became insolvent as a result of the transaction) that a reasonable person in the company’s position would not have entered into, having regard to the benefits and detriment to the company of entering into the transaction, the benefits to the other parties to the transaction of entering into it and any other relevant matters; - an “unreasonable director-related transaction” or an “unfair loan” (sections 588FDA and 588FD, respectively, of the Corporations Act); or - a “creditor-defeating disposition,” (section 588FDB of the Corporations Act) being a disposition of property of a company where (a) the consideration payable to the company was less than the lesser of (i) the market value of the property and (ii) the best price reasonably 499 ----- obtainable, and (b) the disposition has the effect of preventing the property from becoming available for the benefit of the company’s creditors in a winding-up or hindering, or significantly delaying, the process of making the property so available. _Green security_ A security interest granted by the company in respect of “circulating assets” in the 6 month period leading up to the liquidator’s appointment or, if the liquidation was preceded by voluntary administration then the commencement of the voluntary administration, will be void except so far as the security interest secures: - a new advance (other than an advance to discharge an unsecured debt owed to the secured party which must be given as consideration for the circulating security interest); - interest on such an advance; - the amount of a liability (e.g. under a guarantee) undertaken at or after that time on behalf of, or for the benefit of, the company; or - an amount payable for property services supplied to the company at or after that time or interest on an amount so payable. The security interest will not be void if the company is proven to have been solvent immediately after the time it granted the security interest. _Impact of the above on entry by the Australian Guarantor into the Note Guarantee and/or security interests_ The extent to which the entry into the Note Guarantee and/or security interests by the Australian Guarantor is susceptible to challenge on the bases set out above depends, among other things, on when the relevant transaction was entered into relative to the commencement of the winding up (or, if a voluntary administration precedes the winding up, the commencement of the voluntary administration). Different time periods apply depending on the circumstances of the relevant transaction and the identity of the parties to it. _Ipso facto reforms_ On September 18, 2017, the Treasury Laws Amendment (2017 Enterprise Incentives No. 2) Act 2017 (“TLA Act”) was enacted in Australia. With effect from July 1, 2018, this legislation introduced new provisions into the Corporations Act, which provide for an automatic stay on the enforcement of certain rights and self-executing provisions (known as “ipso facto” rights) arising under certain contracts (such as a right entitling a creditor to terminate the contract or to accelerate payments or providing for automatic acceleration) (“Automatic Stay”), if the reason for the enforcement of those rights or provisions is: (a) the contractual counterparty being under administration, having a managing controller or receiver appointed over the whole or substantially the whole of its property, or announcing, applying for or being the subject of a scheme of arrangement (for the purpose of it avoiding being wound up in insolvency), or being under a restructuring process under Part 5.3B of the Corporations Act; (b) the contractual counterparty’s financial position during any of those affected procedures; or (c) a reason that is in substance contrary to the TLA Act (known as “prescribed reasons”). 500 ----- Notably, the procedures under which the Automatic Stay would apply do not include being subject to winding up or liquidation (unless those processes are consequent to a voluntary administration or a scheme) or where a deed of company arrangement has been executed (unless the deed administrators are able to obtain a court order for a stay to operate) or the restructuring process under Part 5.3B ends. Relevantly, the Automatic Stay does not apply to other types of contractual defaults – for example, if the company has failed to meet its payment or other performance obligations under the relevant agreement. The length of the Automatic Stay depends on which formal insolvency process applies to the company, as follows (subject to courts order extending the stay): - in the case of a scheme of arrangement: the stay will end within three months of the announcement, or where an application is made within that three months, when the application is withdrawn or dismissed by the court or when the scheme ends or the company is would up; - in the case of a receivership or managing controllership: the stay will end when the receiver’s or managing controller’s control ends; and - in the case of a voluntary administration: the stay will end on the latest of when the administration ends or the company is would up. The scope of the Automatic Stay, specifically what contract types, rights and self-executing provisions are excluded by the Automatic Stay are set out in the Corporations (Stay on Enforcing Certain Rights) _Regulations 2018 (“Regulations”) and the_ _Corporations (Stay on Enforcing Certain Rights) Declaration 2018 (“Declaration”)._ The Declaration declares the various rights (including self-executing clauses that, when executed, provide those rights) that are excluded from the operation of the Automatic Stay and those rights that remain available to the parties should a trigger event occur. The Automatic Stay applies to ipso facto rights arising under contracts, agreements or arrangements entered into at or after July 1, 2018, subject to certain exclusions set out in the Corporations Act, subordinate regulations and a Declaration related to the TLA Act that also came into effect on July 1, 2018. The subordinate regulations prescribe that a right contained in a kind of contract, agreement or arrangement for the underwriting of an issue, or sale, of bonds or that is, or governs, bonds, is not subject to the Automatic Stay. Rights exercised with the consent of the relevant administrator, managing controller, scheme administrator, restructuring practitioner (or a liquidator if a liquidation follows the administration or scheme) and the right to appoint a controller (in respect of security over the whole or substantially the whole property) during the decision period following the appointment of administrators are excluded. In addition to the exclusions currently applicable as a result of related subordinate regulations and the Declaration that came into effect on July 1, 2018, rights prescribed by regulations or Ministerial declarations following July 1, 2018 may also be excluded. Any such subordinate legislation that may be implemented following July 1, 2018 may also prescribe additional reasons to which the automatic stay on enforcement applies. The Automatic Stay does not apply retrospectively (i.e., for agreements entered into prior to the new provisions coming into force on 1 July 2018). The ipso facto legislation also gives the Court the power to impose stay orders in respect of a potentially broader range of contractual rights (where the court is satisfied that the relevant right is being exercised, is likely to be exercised or there is a threat that it might be exercised because of one of the prescribed reasons described above) or lift the Automatic Stay (where the Court is satisfied that doing so is in the interests of justice) and extend the duration of the Automatic Stay. 501 ----- The effect of the _ipso facto reforms means that, in the event of a Guarantor being subject to the appointment of a voluntary administrator, a managing controller over the whole or substantially the whole of its property or a scheme of arrangement (for the purpose of avoiding it being wound up in insolvency), the rights of any counterparty to a contract with a Guarantor that would otherwise be enlivened by those insolvency events (or triggered by its financial position whilst affected by one of those affected procedures) may be unenforceable. This may affect the exercise of rights under the Note Guarantee provided by the Australian Guarantor as against the Australian Guarantor. Until judicial consideration of the new provisions of the Corporations Act as introduced by the TLA Act, the subordinate regulations and the Declaration and any changes in market practice, the scope of the _ipso facto reform and its potential effect on the Note Guarantee provided by the Australian Guarantor remains uncertain. 502 -----

Section Title: CERTAIN INSOLVENCY LAW CONSIDERATIONS
Subsection Title: Guarantor”). Australian insolvency laws will be relevant upon the insolvency of this entity and the
Subsubsection Text: application of these laws may affect the enforcement of, and the ability to recover funds under, the Note Guarantee given by the Australian Guarantor. The primary source of regulation for corporate insolvency in Australia is the Corporations Act, the _Corporations Regulations 2001 (Cth) (Regulations), the_ _Federal Court (Corporations) Rules 2000_ (Cth) and similar rules, which are in force in the Supreme Court of each State and Territory of Australia. There are four main forms of formal insolvency processes in Australia: voluntary administration, deed of company arrangement, receivership and winding-up (also called liquidation). Corporate reorganizations can also be effected by schemes of arrangement (which can be a solvent or insolvent procedure) or, in the case of small companies, by a restructuring process under Part 5.3B of the Corporations Act, in circumstances where the company the subject of the corporate reorganization has liabilities (excluding employee entitlements) of less than A$1 million.

Subsection Title: LISTING AND GENERAL INFORMATION Listing
Subsubsection Text: An application will be made for each series of Notes to be admitted to the Exchange and to be admitted for trading on the Official List of the Exchange thereof. It is expected that such admission will become effective after the Issue Date. On and after the grant of listing of the Notes, copies of the following documents may be inspected and obtained at the registered office of the Listing Agent during normal business hours on any business day: - the articles of association of each Issuer and each Guarantor; - the audited consolidated financial statements of AGHL for the preceding two years; - the Indenture governing the Senior Secured Notes (which includes the guarantees and form of the Senior Secured Notes); - the Indenture governing the Senior Notes (which includes the guarantees and form of the Senior Notes); - the forms of the Notes; - the Intercreditor Agreement; and - the Security Documents. The issuance of the Notes was authorized by the board of directors of the Issuer on  , 2024. The giving of the guarantees has been authorized pursuant to applicable corporate formalities. Except as disclosed in this offering memorandum, we have not been involved in any governmental, legal or arbitration proceeding relating to claims or amounts that are material and may have or have had, during the 12 months preceding the date of this offering memorandum, a significant effect on our financial condition nor so far as we are aware is any such litigation or arbitration pending or threatened. As of the date of this offering memorandum, the most recent consolidated financial statements available for AGHL were as of and for the nine months ended September 30, 2023. Except as disclosed in this offering memorandum, there has been no material adverse change in the prospects of AGHL since September 30, 2023. Except as disclosed in this offering memorandum, there are no material potential conflicts of interest between any member of the board of directors of an Issuer and such Issuer or his duties to such Issuer. The Trustee will be Ankura Trust Company, LLC and its address is 140 Sherman Street, Fourth Floor, Fairfield, CT 06824, United States. The Trustee will be acting in its capacity of trustee for the holders of the Notes and will provide such services to the holders of the Notes as described in the Indenture.

Section Title: CERTAIN INSOLVENCY LAW CONSIDERATIONS
Subsection Title: NOTES TO THE INTERIM CONDENSED CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS 1** **General information
Subsubsection Text: Ardonagh Group Holdings Limited (the Company) is a private company limited by shares with registered number 13789356. It was incorporated and registered in England and Wales on 8 December 2021. The address of its registered office is 2 Minster Court, Mincing Lane, London, EC3R 7PD. These interim condensed consolidated financial statements comprise the Company and its subsidiaries (the Group) and have been prepared in connection with the shareholders’ deed, the USD 500.0m PIK toggle notes due 2027 indenture and the privately placed term loan facilities agreement due 2026 (incorporating the term, CAR and RCF facilities). A newly created company Tara Topco Limited (‘Tara’) obtained a significant new equity investment led by long-term shareholders in the former Ardonagh holding company, The Ardonagh Group Limited (‘TAGL’), alongside new co-investors through accounts managed by MDP and HPS. The new equity investment resulted in TAGL merging into Tara on 31 May 2022. Following this merger, the Company acquired Ardonagh New Midco 3 Limited (‘NM3L’), including the group of companies previously owned by TAGL, on 1 June 2022 and the Ardonagh Group activities are thereafter overseen by the Company as an indirect subsidiary of Tara. The prior period comparatives therefore reflect the fact that during the nine-month period to 30 September 2022 the Company had only four months of trading. As announced on 15 September, Ardonagh and Markerstudy Group (‘Markerstudy’) have agreed a merger between Markerstudy and Ardonagh’s Atlanta Group of businesses to create a major new player in the UK insurance market with the transaction subject to customary conditions (including regulatory approvals). Owing to the forthcoming merger, the financial information presented in this interim report is shown to identify the impact of Ardonagh Retail ceasing to be part of Ardonagh. This includes the presentation of Ardonagh Retail as held for sale on the statement of financial position, as a discontinued operation on the income statement and the cash flow statement, as well as other explanations in note 26 of section 2. The financial information contained in these interim results does not constitute statutory accounts of the Company within the meaning of the Companies Act 2006 applicable to companies reporting under IFRS. Statutory accounts for the period ended 31 December 2022 were approved by the Board of Directors on 22 March 2023. The report of the auditors on those accounts was unqualified and did not contain an emphasis of matter paragraph.

Section Title: CERTAIN INSOLVENCY LAW CONSIDERATIONS
Subsection Title: 2** **Basis of preparation
Subsubsection Text: The interim condensed consolidated financial statements of the Group have been prepared in accordance with IAS 34 Interim Financial Reporting, as adopted by the United Kingdom. They do not include all the information required for a complete set of IFRS financial statements. However, selected notes are included to explain events and transactions that are significant to an understanding of the Group’s financial position and performance. The interim condensed consolidated financial statements are presented in GBP sterling (£). Amounts shown are rounded to the nearest thousand, unless stated otherwise. The interim condensed consolidated financial statements have been prepared under the historical cost convention, as modified to use a different measurement basis where necessary to comply with or permitted by IFRS. The Group’s business or the revenues received are not subject to significant seasonality or cyclicality. The consolidated financial statements comprise the Company and its subsidiaries (the Group) and have been prepared in accordance with International Financial Reporting Standards (IFRS) as adopted by the United Kingdom (UK-adopted IFRS) and the Companies Act 2006 applicable to companies reporting under IFRS. The consolidated financial statements are presented in pounds sterling (£), being the functional currency of the company, and in thousands unless otherwise stated. The consolidated financial statements have been prepared under the historical cost convention, as modified to use a different measurement basis where necessary to comply with or permitted by IFRS. Going concern The financial statements of the Group set out on pages 48 to 54 have been prepared on the basis that the Group is a going concern. At 31 December 2022, the Group had net liabilities of £111.4m (2021: net assets of £82.2m (restated)) and net current assets of £312.0m (2021: £366.6m (restated)). The Group reported an operating profit of £76.5m (2021: £102.7m) for the year ended 31 December 2022, net cash inflows from operating activities of £171.1m (2021: £688.5m), net decrease/(increase) in cash and cash equivalents of £118.0m (2021: £754.1m). Available cash of £269.6m (2021: £411.3m) was reported on 31 December 2022. The Directors have assessed the Group’s financial position and its ability to meet its obligations as and when they fall due. In making the going concern assessment the Directors have taken into account the following: - The Group’s capital structure, operations and liquidity. - Base case and stressed cash flow forecasts over the calendar years 2023 and 2024. - The impact on the base case and stressed cashflow forecasts arising from material acquisitions and capital injections subsequent to year end. - The principal risks facing the Group. and its systems of risk management and internal control. - The Group’s capital management, among other things, aims to ensure that it meets financial covenants attached to its interest-bearing loans and borrowings. There have been no breaches of the financial covenants of any interest-bearing loans and borrowing in the reporting period. - Post year-end operating results and cashflows of the Group continue to be positive. Key assumptions that the Directors have reflected in the base case cash flow forecasts include that: - The Group will continue to benefit from a £191.5m Revolving Credit Facility that is not drawn at the date of this report. - Client retention and renewal rates remain robust, despite the current economic uncertainty, as the 2022 trading performance continues to demonstrate resilience across the Group. - Interest costs are modelled using current forward interest and FX rates (other than where interest rates on debt have been fixed through interest rate swaps). ###### FINANCIAL STATEMENTS

Section Title: CERTAIN INSOLVENCY LAW CONSIDERATIONS
Subsection Title: Going concern
Subsubsection Text: The interim condensed consolidated financial statements of the Group set out on pages 12 to 20 have been prepared on a going concern basis. At 30 September 2023, the Group had net assets of £2,992.0m (31 December 2022: £2,924.5m) and net current assets of £1,408.4m (31 December 2022: £279.6m). The Group reported an operating profit of £54.1m for the nine months ended 30 September 2023 (30 September 2022: £13.1m), net cash inflows from operating activities of £278.7m (30 September 2022: £232.4m) and cash inflows of £111.2m (30 September 2022: £1,173.0m). Available cash, including held for sale, of £202.2m was reported at 30 September 2023 (31 December 2022: £269.6m). ----- ###### FINANCIAL STATEMENTS

Section Title: CERTAIN INSOLVENCY LAW CONSIDERATIONS
Subsection Title: NOTES TO THE INTERIM CONDENSED CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS 2** **Basis of preparation (continued)
Subsubsection Text: The Directors have assessed the Group’s financial position and its ability to meet its obligations as and when they fall due. In making the going concern assessment the Directors have taken into account the following: - The Group’s capital structure, operations and liquidity. - Base case and stressed cash flow forecasts over the calendar years 2023 and 2024. - The impact on the base case and stressed cashflow forecasts arising from subsequent material acquisitions and as a result of Ardonagh Retail ceasing to be part of Ardonagh following the expected merger between Markerstudy and Ardonagh’s Atlanta Group of businesses. - The principal risks facing the Group. and its systems of risk management and internal control. - The Group’s capital management, among other things, aims to ensure that it meets financial covenants attached to its interest-bearing loans and borrowings. There have been no breaches of the financial covenants of any interest-bearing loans and borrowings in the current period. - Actual trading and cashflows of the period and the continued positive results in October 2023. Key assumptions that the Directors have reflected in the base case cash flow forecasts include that: - The Group will continue to benefit from a £191.5m Revolving Credit Facility that is not drawn at the date of this report. - Client retention and renewal rates remain robust, despite current economic uncertainties, with the trading performance continuing to demonstrate resilience across the Group. - Interest costs are modelled using current forward interest rates (other than where interest rates on debt have been fixed through interest rate swaps). Key stress scenarios that the Directors have considered include cumulative stresses to the base plan as a result of: - Shortfalls in base case projected income throughout 2023 and 2024. - Deterioration in base case cash conversion rates over and above the shortfalls in income. - An inflationary cost increase of 2% over the base case assumptions. - Additional interest costs on the term and CAR debt facilities applying the maximum additional margins that can be triggered. - Mitigating actions within management control including delayed capital expenditure, a reduction in discretionary spend and measured reductions in employee headcount and remuneration. The Directors have also modelled reverse stress scenarios, including assessing those that result in a default on the Group’s term debt facilities that would require a technical repayment obligation and those that would exhaust available liquidity. The stresses needed for these outcomes to happen significantly exceed the key stress scenarios above and the Directors consider such conditions to be a remote possibility. Other mitigations which may be possible in the stress scenarios but have not been included in the analysis include seeking shareholder support, securitising premium receivables and further incremental and more prolonged cost reductions. The Directors continue to consider the wider operational and financial consequences and ramifications of global political and economic tensions (including related to the Ukrainian conflict, foreign exchange rates, inflation and increasing interest rates). In particular: - Insurance broking is a resilient and defensive market, which has historically had limited impact from past economic or capital market downturns. The Group is highly diversified and not unduly exposed to a single carrier, customer or market sector. - Although economic developments remain fluid, the stress testing demonstrates the Group’s financial resilience and operating flexibility. - As a result of Russia invading Ukraine, we have seen significant new sanctions legislation from a range of legislators (including the US, EU and UK), with newly sanctioned entities and individuals, and new (or wider in scope) sectoral sanctions targeting Russia (and Belarus). The Ardonagh Group has no appetite for potential breaches of applicable sanctions regimes and applies appropriate controls including automated screening of clients against relevant sanctions lists. We continue to actively monitor the situation as it develops and will respond accordingly as new sanctions are enacted. - The Group continues to monitor the risk of cyber-attacks, but the Group has not identified any significant security risks during the period ended 30 September 2023. Following the assessment of the Group’s financial position and its ability to meet its obligations as and when they fall due, including the further potential financial implications of economic uncertainty included in stress tests, the Directors are not aware of any material uncertainties that cast significant doubt on the Group’s ability to continue as a going concern. ----- ###### FINANCIAL STATEMENTS

Section Title: CERTAIN INSOLVENCY LAW CONSIDERATIONS
Subsection Title: NOTES TO THE INTERIM CONDENSED CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS 3** **Accounting policies
Subsubsection Text: Except as described below, the accounting policies adopted are consistent with those applied in the preparation of the Group’s consolidated financial statements for the period ended 31 December 2022. The Group has adopted the amendment to IAS 12 as a result of the International Tax Reform – Pillar Two Model Rules. The amendment provides a temporary mandatory exception from accounting for deferred taxes arising from legislations enacted to implement the Pillar Two Model Rules. The amendment also introduces additional disclosure requirements that will be applicable to the Group’s consolidated financial statements for the period ending 31 December 2023. Management is actively monitoring the status of legislations that are at different stages of enactment in the jurisdictions in which the Group operates. Management will review the Group’s tax exposure and provide relevant information once the legislations are enacted. There have been no other amendments to accounting standards that have become effective in the year beginning 1 January 2023 that have had a material impact on the Group interim condensed consolidated financial statements.

Section Title: CERTAIN INSOLVENCY LAW CONSIDERATIONS
Subsection Title: 4** **Critical accounting judgements and key sources of estimation uncertainty
Subsubsection Text: Estimates and judgements used in preparing the interim condensed consolidated financial statements are continually evaluated and are based on historical experience and other factors, including expectations of future events that are believed to be reasonable. The resulting accounting estimates will, by definition, seldom equal the related actual results. The estimates and assumptions that have a significant effect on the carrying amounts of assets and liabilities are discussed below.

Section Title: CERTAIN INSOLVENCY LAW CONSIDERATIONS
Subsection Title: Critical judgements in applying accounting policies
Subsubsection Text: The Company obtained control of NM3L on 1 June 2022, which is the owner of Ardonagh Midco 1 Limited (Midco 1) and thus the businesses that were previously part of the Ardonagh Group that existed prior to 1 June 2022 headed by The Ardonagh Group Limited. For the year ended 31 December 2022, the Company applied acquisition accounting in accordance with IFRS 3 Business Combinations to the acquisition of NM3L and, in the consolidated financial statements of the Group, it therefore measured the identifiable net assets acquired of NM3L at fair value on 1 June 2022, which included the recognition of intangible assets arising on a business combination and the recognition of goodwill and non-controlling interests. A critical judgement was applied in the prior year to determine if it was appropriate to apply acquisition accounting, which included consideration of the wider transaction, if there had been a change in control, and who was the acquirer. Acquisition accounting was applied as a business had been acquired and because the Company clearly obtained control of that business. As at 31 December 2022, the Group had not completed the acquisition accounting of NM3L. Goodwill recognised in the prior year’s consolidated financial statements was based on provisional fair values of the assets acquired. The initial allocation of goodwill to the cash generating units was also done on a provisional basis in accordance with IAS 36. During the current year, the Group completed the acquisition accounting of NM3L, and the resulting amount of goodwill has been finalised and reallocated to cashgenerating units in a manner that is most appropriate to the business. During 2023, the Group entered into negotiations to dispose of the entire share capital of Atlanta Investment Holdings 3 Limited (‘AIH3L’), being the holding company for the Retail operating segment (the ‘disposal group’). On 1 September 2023, all material matters fundamental to the deal were agreed upon with the buyer and there were no further matters that could have caused the planned sale to be withdrawn or changed significantly. Consequently, as at that date the disposal group was classified as held for sale in accordance with IFRS 5 Non-current Assets Held for Sale and Discontinued Operations. At that date, the carrying values of all assets and liabilities within the disposal group were measured in accordance with applicable IFRS and then compared to the fair value less cost to sell of the disposal group. The excess, if any, of the carrying value of the disposal group over its fair value less cost to sell is required to be recognised as an impairment loss. There was no material difference between the carrying value and the fair value less cost to sell of the disposal group and therefore no impairment loss was recognised. Furthermore, in accordance with IFRS 5, from the date of classification as held for sale, non-current assets within the disposal group are not subject to depreciation or amortisation. ----- ###### FINANCIAL STATEMENTS

Section Title: CERTAIN INSOLVENCY LAW CONSIDERATIONS
Subsection Title: NOTES TO THE INTERIM CONDENSED CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS 4** **Critical accounting judgements and key sources of estimation uncertainty (continued) Key sources of estimation uncertainty Impairment of assets
Subsubsection Text: The Group tests annually whether goodwill and intangible assets that have indefinite useful lives have suffered any impairment. Other assets are reviewed for impairment whenever events or changes in circumstances indicate that the carrying amount of the assets may exceed its recoverable amount. The last annual impairment test was performed as at 1 July 2023 (see note 8). An impairment test of an asset or cash-generating unit (or group of cash-generating units) is performed by comparing its carrying amount with its recoverable amount. The recoverable amount is the higher of its fair value less costs of disposal and its value in use, where its value in use is the present value of its future cash flows. An impairment test requires the application of significant judgement because it relies on key assumptions, including forecast cash flows, a discount rate, a terminal growth rate and an Adjusted EBITDA multiple. Accordingly, the resulting estimates are significant estimates because there is a significant risk of a material adjustment to the carrying amounts of affected balances within the next financial year. Goodwill arising from a new business combination is, for the purposes of impairment testing, allocated to those cash-generating units that are expected to benefit from the goodwill that was acquired. Impairment testing is performed at the level of the smallest groups of cash-generating units at which goodwill is monitored, known as the divisions. Forecast cash flows used in the value in use calculation were determined by considering historic business performance, by overlaying it with assumptions to reflect areas where growth or income improvement was expected, and by taking into account the expected results of cost management programmes to which the Group was committed. These forecasts were extrapolated to subsequent years using a steady growth rate being the CPI inflation rate of 2%, and a terminal value was calculated using the perpetual growth model. The discount rate of 9.55% to 11.45% that was applied to the forecasts was a market participant weighted average cost of capital calculated by reference to the Capital Asset Pricing Model. The fair value of the Group was calculated based on multiples of forecast 2024 Adjusted EBITDA and on information provided by external advisors, where that information is based on recent transactions in the insurance broking industry. The fair value of a division was estimated by apportioning the fair value of the Group between the divisions based on the value in use of each division. The estimated costs of disposal are assumed, based on market experience, to be 1.5% of the fair value of the division. See note 8 for the carrying values of goodwill and intangible assets at the period end. Further, As at 30 September 2023, there were no indications of impairment and therefore no impairment test has been performed.

Section Title: CERTAIN INSOLVENCY LAW CONSIDERATIONS
Subsection Title: 5** **Segmental analysis
Subsubsection Text: Descriptions of the Group’s operating platforms can be found in Section 1 – Our Businesses. Under IFRS 8 ‘Operating Segments’, the Group determines and presents operating segments based on the information that is provided to the Group Executive Committee, which is the Group’s chief operating decision maker. Operating segments are reviewed and revised as necessary following structural changes within the Group or on significant business combinations. The Group Executive Committee assesses the performance of the operating segments based on an Adjusted EBITDA measure and cash generation forecasts to meet debt obligations to the Corporate segment. The presentation of the segment information reflects that. The Group Executive Committee assesses the financial position of the Group on a consolidated Group basis and therefore does not regularly receive measures of total assets or total liabilities on an operating segment basis. Accordingly, no financial position measures are reported within the Group’s segmental analysis. The results include items directly attributable to an operating segment as well as those that can be allocated on a reasonable basis. The Retail segment was classified as a discontinued operation in the current period and segment information reported on the next pages does not include any amounts for discontinued operations, which are described in more detail in note 26. Of the Total Income disclosed in the consolidated income statement, £498.7m (2022; £159.3m) is attributable to sales made to clients outside the UK. Commissions and fees represent the Group’s revenue from contracts with customers which is recognised in accordance with IFRS 15. The Group’s operating segments reflect its disaggregation of revenue. ----- ###### FINANCIAL STATEMENTS

Subsection Title: NOTES TO THE INTERIM CONDENSED CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS 7** **Income and deferred tax
Subsubsection Text: Income tax credit for the interim condensed consolidated financial statements is recognised based on management’s estimate of the weighted average effective annual income tax rate expected for the full financial year (including the impact of legislated changes to the tax rate), adjusted for the tax effect of certain items recognised in full during the interim period. The effective tax rate in these interim condensed consolidated financial statements is 9.9% giving rise to a tax credit on continuing operations of £25.3m. The tax charge differs from that which would result from applying the standard rate of corporation tax, mainly due to the impact of non-UK earnings, statutory restrictions on the deductibility of interest expense and the recognition of deferred tax assets against future projections of taxable income. The tax charge on discontinued operations in these interim condensed consolidated financial statements is £6.7m. This includes a one-off tax charge of £3.9m which has arisen due to the classification of the disposal group as held for sale. The Group has adopted International Tax Reform – Pillar Two Model Rules – Amendments to IAS 12 upon their release on 23 May 2023. The amendments provide a temporary mandatory exception from deferred tax accounting for the top-up tax, which is effective immediately, and require new disclosures about the Pillar Two exposure from 31 December 2023. The mandatory exception applies retrospectively. However, because no new legislation to implement the top-up tax was enacted or substantively enacted at 31 December 2022 in any jurisdiction in which the Group operates and no related deferred taxes were recognised at that date, the retrospective application has no impact on the Group’s condensed interim financial statements. The relief and the new disclosures will also be reflected in the Group’s consolidated financial statements as at and for the year ending 31 December 2023. ----- ###### FINANCIAL STATEMENTS

Subsection Title: 11** **Business combinations
Subsubsection Text: On 2 February 2023, the Group purchased the entire share capital of Envest Pty Limited for a consideration of AUD 420.0m cash, advance cash consideration of AUD 30.0m already paid and a share buy-out obligation of AUD 43.2m. Envest is an insurance investment and distribution business headquartered in Brisbane, Australia. The acquisition has been included in the International Advisory operating segment. On 1 March 2023, the Group purchased the entire share capital of Oxford Insurance Group Limited for a consideration of USD 24.5m cash, contingent consideration with a fair value of USD 26.5m, less an indemnification asset with a fair value of USD 3.0m relating to bonus compensation payable to existing employees of the acquiree. The acquisition has been included in the Specialty operating segment. On 1 June 2023, the Group purchased 80% of the share capital of K.N.C Holding Company Limited for a consideration of EUR 40.0m cash, working capital adjustment of EUR 1.1m and a share buy-out liability with a fair value of EUR 9.2m (representing the Group’s obligation under put and call options to acquire the remaining 20% shares of K.N.C Holding Company Limited). The acquisition has been included in the International Advisory operating segment. On 5 June 2023, The Group purchased the entire share capital of Insurvest B.V. for a consideration of EUR 88.2m cash, contingent consideration with a fair value of EUR 9.6m, ordinary and preference shares subject to put and call options, accounted for as a share buy-out liability with a fair value of EUR 2.3m and EUR 8.9m respectively. The acquisition has been included in the International Advisory operating segment. The Group purchased other individually not material business combinations, the aggregate consideration for which was EUR 18.8m, AUD 77.6m, GBP 39.0m, ZAR 2.9m, CLP 663.8m, BRL 35.1m and USD 11.2m cash, deferred consideration of AUD 0.9m, GBP 4.1m and ZAR 0.3m, contingent consideration with a fair value of EUR 7.2m, AUD 2.2m, BRL 41.2m, GBP 3.7m, ZAR 1.2m, CLP 4,592.9m and USD 2.4m, share buyout obligation with a fair value of AUD 14.8m, EUR 0.7m and GBP 4.4m, ordinary shares issued with a fair value of AUD 4.6m and other liabilities of AUD 47.7m. ----- ###### FINANCIAL STATEMENTS

Subsubsection Text: The acquisitions were accounted for under IFRS 3 ‘Business Combinations’, which requires that the identifiable assets acquired and the liabilities assumed, including certain contingent liabilities, are measured at their acquisition date fair value. Goodwill is calculated as the difference between the acquisition consideration (grossed up for non-controlling interest) and the acquisition date fair value of the net assets/(liabilities) acquired. Goodwill represents expected synergies from combining operations of the acquiree and the Group, and/or intangible assets that do not qualify for separate recognition, and is allocated to the acquirer’s cash generating units, or groups of cash-generating units, that are expected to benefit from the synergies from combining operations of the acquiree and the Group. The amounts recognised in the interim condensed consolidated financial statements are provisional and adjustment may occur during the remainder of the applicable measurement period. ----- ###### FINANCIAL STATEMENTS

Subsubsection Text: On 2 February 2023, as part of the acquisition of Envest Pty Limited the Group acquired the joint control over the following Australia based brokers as a result of equity holdings and related shareholder rights acquired: 84 Eagle Pty Ltd 50.00% Fitzpatrick & Company Insurance Brokers Pty Ltd* 49.88% Acumen Insurance Pty Ltd* 34.83% All points Surety Pty Ltd 25.00% Aviso All Points Central Coast 25.00% Aviso Tas Pty Ltd 38.00% Blue Zebra Insurance Pty Ltd 30.20% Eighteen33 Pty Ltd 60.00% Grange Insurance Solutions Pty Ltd* 57.50% Insuretech Gateway Australia Pty Limited 38.90% Norton Group Pty Ltd (AR) 20.00% Point Underwriting Agency Pty Ltd 53.50% Redsky Insurance Pty Ltd 43.00% Switz Insurance Pty Ltd 33.00% Triton Broking Services Holdings Pty Ltd (Aviso WA) 39.64% Wymark Insurance Brokers (Melb) Pty Ltd* 50.00% Investment in these joint ventures were subsequently subject to further transactions that resulted in the Group acquiring control as follows: On 30 June 2023 the Group acquired a further 33% of the ordinary shares of Wymark Insurance Brokers (Melb) Pty Ltd and thereby obtained control over the entity. The consideration paid to acquire 33% of the ordinary shares was AUD 2.2m. The previous 50% equity interest was remeasured on 30 June 2023 (a business combination achieved in stages) from its carrying value of AUD 0.7m to AUD 3.3m, giving rise to a AUD 2.6m gain in the income statement, and it was then derecognised. A non-controlling interest of AUD 0.2m was recognised on 30 June 2023. On 3 July 2023, the Group acquired a further 30% of the ordinary shares of Acumen Insurance Pty Ltd and thereby obtained control over the entity. The consideration paid to acquire the additional 30% of the ordinary shares was AUD 3.1m. The previous 34.83% equity interest was remeasured on 3 July 2023 (a business combination achieved in stages) from its carrying value of AUD 0.9m to AUD 3.5m, giving rise to a AUD 2.6m gain in the income statement, and it was then derecognised. A non-controlling interest of AUD 0.7m was recognised on 3 July 2023. On 7 August 2023, the Group amended the shareholders agreement it had with other investors in Grange Insurance Solutions Pty Ltd to remove all joint control provisions from relevant activities. No consideration was paid for this change and as at that date the Group in effect acquired control over the entity. The previous carrying amount of AUD 14.3m was remeasured to AUD 19.4m, giving rise to an AUD 5.1m gain in the income statement, and it was then derecognised as part of the business combination accounting. A non-controlling interest of AUD 1.9m was recognised on 7 August 2023. On 7 September 2023, the Group acquired a further 17.12% of the ordinary shares of Fitzpatrick & Company Insurance Brokers Pty Ltd, taking its shareholding from 49.88% to 67% and as a result acquired control over the entity. As consideration, The Envest Group (formerly Ardonagh Australia Pty Ltd) issued 36,366 shares to the former shareholders of Fitzpatrick & Company Insurance Brokers Pty Ltd, and these shares are subject to a share buyout obligation with a fair value of AUD 7.3m. The previous 49.88% equity interest was remeasured on 7 September 2023 (a business combination achieved in stages) from its carrying value of AUD 18.4m to AUD 21.4m, giving rise to a AUD 3.0m gain in the income statement, and it was then derecognised. A non-controlling interest of AUD 1.3m was recognised on 7 September 2023. ----- ###### FINANCIAL STATEMENTS 30 September** 31 December 2023** 2022 (unaudited)** (audited) Investment in joint ventures **£000** £000 Start of the period **7,779**  Business combinations **23,366** 8,078 Additions **4,690** Remeasurement (business combination achieved in stages) **5,429** Derecognition (business combination achieved in stages) **(13,573)** Foreign exchange movement **(2,294)** Share of profit for the period **3,099** 427 Dividend received **(2,007)** (726) Reclassification to held for sale **(4,501) End of the period** **21,988** 7,779

Subsection Title: NOTES TO THE INTERIM CONDENSED CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS 17** **Financial instruments
Subsubsection Text: Fair value measurement Financial assets and liabilities measured at fair value in the interim condensed consolidated financial statement of financial position are grouped into three levels of a fair value hierarchy. The three levels are defined based on the observability of significant inputs to the measurement, as follows: - Level 1: quoted prices (unadjusted) in active markets for identical assets or liabilities. - Level 2: inputs other than quoted prices included within level 1 that are observable for the asset or liability, either directly as prices, or indirectly derived from prices; and - Level 3: unobservable inputs for the asset or liability. The following table shows the levels within the hierarchy of financial assets and liabilities measured at fair value on an ongoing basis:

Section Title: CERTAIN INSOLVENCY LAW CONSIDERATIONS
Subsection Title: NOTES TO THE INTERIM CONDENSED CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS 17** **Financial instruments (continued)
Subsubsection Text: The following valuation techniques are used for instruments categorised in Levels 2 and 3:

Section Title: CERTAIN INSOLVENCY LAW CONSIDERATIONS
Subsection Title: Derivative financial instruments (Level 2)
Subsubsection Text: The Group’s derivatives are categorised within level 2 of the fair value hierarchy. These contracts are not traded in an active market, but the fair value is determined using valuation techniques and available market data, such as forward exchange rates corresponding to the maturity of the contract observable at the statement of financial position date and an appropriate sector credit spread.

Section Title: CERTAIN INSOLVENCY LAW CONSIDERATIONS
Subsection Title: Trade and other receivables/contingent consideration receivable (Level 3)
Subsubsection Text: Trade and other receivables include contingent consideration receivable with a fair value of £4.2m, which arose from an acquisition by the group previously held by TAGL. This is categorised within level 3 of the fair value hierarchy with the valuation based on management’s best estimate of the probability of the successful completion of the requirements set out in the sale and purchase agreements. Also included in trade and other receivables at 30 September 2023 were assets at fair value through profit or loss that were recognised on business combinations in relation to the Group’s right to variable consideration on contracts with customers for which the performance obligation was satisfied prior to the acquisition. The fair value is a level 3 valuation and is calculated as the present value of future cash flows where those cash flows take into account expected cancellation rates and the life of the underlying insurance product.

Section Title: CERTAIN INSOLVENCY LAW CONSIDERATIONS
Subsection Title: Contingent consideration, share buyout and deferred proceeds (Level 3)
Subsubsection Text: The contingent consideration, deferred consideration and share buyout liability were acquired on the acquisition of NM3L on 1 June 2022 and amounts arising on the acquisition of Stuart Insurances, Lorega Holdings Limited, Leobros B.V., Frank Glennon Limited, Envest Pty Limited, Oxford Insurance Group Limited, the Matrix Group of companies, K.N.C. Holdings Company Limited, InsurVest B.V. and other acquisitions that are individually not material. Share buyout is the liability arising from put options granted to minority shareholders of certain consolidated subsidiaries, giving the holders the right to sell all of their interest in those subsidiaries to the Group. The fair value of the share buyout payments is determined based on the discounted present value of the forecast option strike price, where the discount rate is the pre-tax market participant WACC for the respective division if the strike price is a multiple of forecast EBITDA less net debt. Contingent consideration payments are generally contingent on the post-acquisition performance of the acquired business and achievement of certain performance thresholds. The fair value of contingent consideration is determined based on actual and forecast business performance of the acquired business, discounted using the pre-tax market participant WACC for the respective division as the discount rate.

Section Title: CERTAIN INSOLVENCY LAW CONSIDERATIONS
Subsection Title: Unlisted investments at fair value through other comprehensive income (Level 3)
Subsubsection Text: Unlisted investments are categorised within level 3 of the fair value hierarchy. The valuation technique requires specific market price information in order to support an increase in the fair value measurement.

Section Title: CERTAIN INSOLVENCY LAW CONSIDERATIONS
Subsection Title: Fair value of financial instruments measured at amortised cost
Subsubsection Text: The Directors consider the carrying amounts for trade and other receivables, trade and other payables and the current portion of financial liabilities that are not measured at fair value to approximate their fair values. The fair value of the Group’s borrowings is disclosed in note 21. ----- ###### FINANCIAL STATEMENTS

Subsubsection Text: The Group has economic hedge relationships that mitigate, [i] foreign exchange risk arising from its USD revenue and, [ii] foreign exchange rate and interest rate risk on SOFR, Euribor, and AUD BBSY borrowings, which have been designated in a hedge accounting relationship. The Group manages all other risks associated with these exposures, such as credit risk, but it does not apply hedge accounting for those risks. Derivatives are only used for hedging purposes. The Group has the following derivative financial instruments as at the end of the period: 30 September** 31 December 2023** 2022 (unaudited)** (audited) £000** £000

Section Title: CERTAIN INSOLVENCY LAW CONSIDERATIONS
Subsection Title: NOTES TO THE INTERIM CONDENSED CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS 18** **Derivatives and hedge accounting (continued) Derivatives hedging borrowings
Subsubsection Text: The Group entered into interest rate swaps of USD 200.0m, USD 200.0m and USD 140.0m on 23 June 2022, 1 July 2022 and 26 July 2022 respectively, the purpose of which was to hedge the USD floating rate exposure on its USD 540.0m CAR facility due 2026. The 23 June 2022 and 26 July 2022 swaps mature on 14 January 2027. The 1 July 2022 swap matures on 14 January 2026. On 1 August 2023, the Group entered into an interest rate swap to hedge USD floating rate exposure on USD 200.0m of the B3 USD 540.0m facility from January 2026 to January 2027. All four instruments exchange a floating interest rate with a fixed interest rate. Interest rate swaps referencing USD LIBOR have either been amended to Term SOFR or have transitioned during the period to replacement rates using the standard International Swaps and Derivatives Association transition process. The Group entered into three interest rate swaps of EUR150.0m each on 18 January 2023, 17 February 2023 and 7 March 2023, the purpose of which was to hedge the EURIBOR rate exposure on its B1 EUR 184.2m term facility due 2026, B3 EUR 187.3m CAR facility due 2026 and B4 EUR 240.0m CAR facility due 2026, respectively. These instruments exchange a floating interest rate with a fixed interest rate and will mature on 17 July 2026. The Group entered into an interest rate swap of GBP 250.0m on 20 January 2023, the purpose of which was to hedge GBP SONIA rate exposure on its B2 GBP 300.0m CAR facility due 2026. The instrument exchanges a floating interest rate with a fixed interest rate and has matured on 17 July 2023. The Group entered into an interest rate swap of USD 150.0m on 10 February 2023, the purpose of which was to hedge the USD SOFR rate exposure on the USD 182.5m drawn on its B5 USD 365.0m CAR Facility due 2026. The instrument exchanges a floating interest rate with a fixed interest rate and will mature on 20 July 2026. The Group entered into an interest rate swap of AUD 100.0m on 26 April 2023, the purpose of which was to hedge the AUD-BBSY exposure on AUD 100.0m of the AUD 200.0m AUD facility due 2028. The instrument exchanges a floating interest rate with a fixed interest rate on a quarterly basis and will mature on 4 August 2026.

Section Title: CERTAIN INSOLVENCY LAW CONSIDERATIONS
Subsection Title: Derivatives hedging forecast revenue
Subsubsection Text: The Group enters into forward contracts to mitigate the exposure resulting from USD revenue arising on the placement of certain premiums denominated in USD, which is not the presentation currency nor functional currency of the Group. Based on forecast transactions, the Group effectively sells accumulated USD revenue by reference to individual brokerage transactions. The Group’s track record in receiving USD revenue from long established clients provides a high degree of confidence that forecast transactions are highly probable for hedge accounting purposes. On 1 October 2022, the Group designated its PIK toggle notes in a hedging relationship with this forecast USD revenue. On 9 March 2023, the Group designated a portion of the B3 (USD) facility – USD 540.0m in a hedging relationship with forecast USD revenue that was previously unhedged. ----- ###### FINANCIAL STATEMENTS

Subsection Title: NOTES TO THE INTERIM CONDENSED CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS 24** **Related party transactions
Subsubsection Text: The Group has related party debtors as at 30 September 2023 of £129.1m (31 December 2022: £120.7m) (see note 15) and related party creditors of £8.9m (31 December 2022: £25.2m) (see note 19). Of these balances Tara Topco Limited accounts for £128.0m of the £129.1m related party debtor balance (31 December 2022: £119.6m) and all of the related party creditor balance as at 30 September 2023 and 31 December 2022. Of the related party balance movements in the quarter, transactions with Tara Topco Limited accounted for all the increase in related party debtors and related party creditors. Tara Topco Ltd (‘Tara’) is the Company’s ultimate parent company. The balances arise from transactions where amounts are paid or received by Ardonagh on behalf of Tara. The majority of the related party debtor from Tara relates to non-current term loans.

Section Title: CERTAIN INSOLVENCY LAW CONSIDERATIONS
Subsection Title: 25** **Subsequent events
Subsubsection Text: On 2 November 2023, the Group purchased the entire share capital of Santis HoldCo AG for consideration of CHF 104.4m and deferred consideration with a fair value of CHF 85.5m. Santis HoldCo AG was the ultimate parent of Assepro AG, the largest independent commercial broker for small and medium-sized enterprises in Switzerland. The acquisition has been included in the International Advisory operating segment. The Group completed the acquisition of several individually not material businesses after the reporting period the aggregate consideration for which was £19.7m, EUR 27.7m and AUD 37.9m paid in cash, plus deferred consideration with a fair value of EUR 0.1m and AUD 4.0m, plus contingent consideration with a fair value of £6.8m, EUR 0.1m and AUD 2.4m, plus share buyout liabilities (ordinary shares) with a fair value of AUD 8.4m. On 11 October 2023, the Group entered into a new 15-year lease on its Minster Court offices, resulting in an opening right-of-use asset and lease liability of £15.5m. On 31 October 2023, USD 130.0m of the USD 460.0 m B6 CAR facility was drawn to fund the acquisition of Assepro AG. On 3 November 2023, The Envest Group Pty Limited (formerly Ardonagh Australia Pty Ltd) issued 742,574 Ordinary shares to Reginetti Holdings Pty Ltd (a subsidiary of Macquarie Group) for AUD 150.0m. These shares are subject to a share buyout obligation. On 9 January 2024, USD 182.5m of the USD 365.0 m B5 CAR facility was drawn. On 1 December 2023 the Group completed the disposal of Accurisk Holdings LLC, for consideration of USD 95.9m.

Section Title: CERTAIN INSOLVENCY LAW CONSIDERATIONS
Subsection Title: 26** **Disposal group held for sale and discontinued operations
Subsubsection Text: As announced on 15 September, Ardonagh and Markerstudy Group (‘Markerstudy’) have agreed a merger between Markerstudy and Ardonagh’s Atlanta Group of businesses to create a major new player in the UK insurance market with the transaction subject to customary conditions (including regulatory approvals). It is difficult to predict the timing for the satisfaction of the completion conditions, although the transaction is not expected to complete in 2023. Owing to the forthcoming merger, the financial information presented in this interim report is shown to identify the impact of Ardonagh Retail ceasing to be part of Ardonagh. This includes the presentation of Ardonagh Retail as held for sale on the statement of financial position, as a discontinued operation on the income statement and the cash flow statement, as well as other explanations in this note. During the period, the disposal group contributed £42.2m (2022: £25.2m) to the Group’s net operating cash flows, paid £18.5m (2022: £8.6m) in respect of investing activities and paid £2.7m (2022: £2.4m) in respect of financing activities. ----- ###### FINANCIAL STATEMENTS
